story:
Short Summary

  • My name is Jared Gaines. I work as a youth minister at Stoney Point Church of Christ in Deatsville, AL. My wife Lena is a nurse at one of our hospitals in Montgomery, AL. Recently we have had it on our hearts to take a mission trip to Tanzania, Africa, in hopes of evangelizing to the people there. I went for the first time last year during December to do a children's camp with BackWoods Christian Camp. This year my wife is wanting to go and we ourselves are going to head a missions team to Tanzania. While we are over there we plan on doing campaign work for the church there which includes Bible studies, medical work, VBS for the children in the area of Arusha, and work with the local orphanage.  This campaign holds a special place in our hearts because my family has done mission work in Africa since before I was born. I have always dreamed of one day doing long term work and would appreciate your help in making part of this step come true. We have been praying for a long time for the support to make this dream a reality and you could be a part of our dream and bring a little bit of hope to Africa as well.

What We Need & What You Get

We need about $7,500 for our airfare , food, lodging, and supplies for the VBS we plan on putting on for the children in Arusha. The extra funds we made as the goal was to help out others that are going in our group as well. We have several of our youth that are planning on taking this trip for the first time.  We know that this is a lot to ask for but everyone who contributes to our cause will be helping us share God's love to those who may not yet know it. We believe that those in tough situations are the ones who need God the most. Most of the African population is looking for something to hope in, something to cling on, and a little bit of love as well. By helping support us you will be giving children one the memories my wife and I cherish most, Vacation Bible School. We will be assisting the locals with different tasks they may need, my wife hopes to help out in the clinic, and we will be immersing ourselves in the African culture. I know we don't have any grand incentives but you don't even know the joy that will fill your hearts by helping us spread the Word of God.
The more we can raise the more outreach we can do. Please find a place in your heart to help us save souls in Africa. We are to be the servants of Christ the ones to spread His message and the embodiment of His love. We know that not everyone can go physically, but we are asking you to come with us in spirit and embark on a journey to change lives. We will soon be creating a blog and will let you all know when that is up and running. Thank you again for your donations, prayers, and support of our mission work.
story_txt:
Short Summary
My name is Jared Gaines. I work as a youth minister at Stoney Point Church of Christ in Deatsville, AL. My wife Lena is a nurse at one of our hospitals in Montgomery, AL. Recently we have had it on our hearts to take a mission trip to Tanzania, Africa, in hopes of evangelizing to the people there. I went for the first time last year during December to do a children's camp with BackWoods Christian Camp. This year my wife is wanting to go and we ourselves are going to head a missions team to Tanzania. While we are over there we plan on doing campaign work for the church there which includes Bible studies, medical work, VBS for the children in the area of Arusha, and work with the local orphanage.  This campaign holds a special place in our hearts because my family has done mission work in Africa since before I was born. I have always dreamed of one day doing long term work and would appreciate your help in making part of this step come true. We have been praying for a long time for the support to make this dream a reality and you could be a part of our dream and bring a little bit of hope to Africa as well. 



What We Need & What You GetWe need about $7,500 for our airfare , food, lodging, and supplies for the VBS we plan on putting on for the children in Arusha. The extra funds we made as the goal was to help out others that are going in our group as well. We have several of our youth that are planning on taking this trip for the first time.  We know that this is a lot to ask for but everyone who contributes to our cause will be helping us share God's love to those who may not yet know it. We believe that those in tough situations are the ones who need God the most. Most of the African population is looking for something to hope in, something to cling on, and a little bit of love as well. By helping support us you will be giving children one the memories my wife and I cherish most, Vacation Bible School. We will be assisting the locals with different tasks they may need, my wife hopes to help out in the clinic, and we will be immersing ourselves in the African culture. I know we don't have any grand incentives but you don't even know the joy that will fill your hearts by helping us spread the Word of God. The more we can raise the more outreach we can do. Please find a place in your heart to help us save souls in Africa. We are to be the servants of Christ the ones to spread His message and the embodiment of His love. We know that not everyone can go physically, but we are asking you to come with us in spirit and embark on a journey to change lives. We will soon be creating a blog and will let you all know when that is up and running. Thank you again for your donations, prayers, and support of our mission work.

story:
I am a student at Texas Christian University studying Music with minors in Arts Administration and General Business.

As I was listening to Christmas hymns while talking to my boyfriend, Peter Cline, who is currently doing mission work in Zambia, a simple idea came to me---wouldn't it be nice to send some Christmas gifts to the local kids?

So Peter went to talk to the headmaster and learned the bigger needs of the students in the local school/orphanage called Joseph Center. We were told that the most basic school supplies are unavailable for the students.

So the idea soon expanded and we thought it's a perfect opportunity to help those students out with the advantage of Peter being in Zambia, living with a local apostle, and me being in the US.

We plan to raise a minimum of 975 dollars to purchase school supplies for the kids at Joseph Center. 975 dollars for us might not mean that much, but it means:

760 small ruled note pads PLUS

1200 mechanical pencils PLUS

1240 blue ballpoint pens PLUS

1200 containers of lead refills

And if we raise more than that, we'll be able to purchase some tasty Christmas candies for the kids as well. We plan to ship all the goods by November 25th so that the gifts will be delivered in time for Christmas. 

If you just can't spare any money, we totally understand. While we do sincerely appreciate every cent that comes in, you can also help out by getting the word out. Share this on your favorite social media or use the Indiegogo share tools to help us get the word out!

We are so grateful for God's blessings and we cannot wait to see what God is going to do through this project.


Thank you,

Chloe and Peter

10/12/2013

story:
Hi, my name is Tara Caballero aka Tara Miller:

"I did it! I earned my AA in Psychology this Saturday May 31st 2014 with your help! Thank you!" -TC I am a single, Full-time college Full-time mom. I reside in California with my son, and four pets. Since "97" I have inspired myself and many others to be their physical best in my fitness career as Tara Caballero. Google me;)

I am here to help raise money for college, and to continue to be a full-time mom. (My most important responsibility) I am successfully admitted for my BACHELOR IN SCIENCE OF PSYCHOLOGY to begin following graduation this Saturday. Someday I will make a difference in this world as a life coach, child therapist, possibly even a DOCTOR! and I need your help to get me there.

I cannot wait to pay forward, by serving our community, with my degrees.

I am offering pictures of me, and small video clips for your support and generosity.

Thank you for reading and your time.

Kind Regards, Tara Caballero

story:
Who am I?

I’m a child of God simply wanting to fulfill God’s call to be a light to the nations. I want to take this task before me with the gifts I’ve been given accomplishing all things through Christ Jesus. I am asking that you help me train to be a missionary with YWAM so that I can impact youth all around the world. So join me by investing in my ministry training with YWAM. 

Growing up as a missionary kid in Kenya for 18 years has shaped and stretched me in many ways. It is fair to say my life has been an ongoing journey with the cultures and communities around me whether I’m living in war torn countries and playing music in their villages to even going down to the hospital leading worship in the wards. I found that spending time with the youth around me has stretched me in positive ways .

Something I personally enjoy doing is stepping out of my comfort zone. When you have a guitar the possibilities are great. I really want to invest in the lives of the youth. I believe, that through Youth With A Mission (YWAM) I am able to advance my skill in this matter.

The first 3 months of the Discipleship Training School (DTS) I will be learning about the depths of Christ love for his children, knowing his delight and his affirmation, and the power of the Holy Spirit. During this YWAM program they are to teach me how to fulfill God’s call to be light for the nations around the world.

The second 3 months will involve an outreach to an area in Asia where I will be given the opertunity to put into the practice the things I have learned.

story:
“Education is the most powerful weapon which you can use to change the world.” 

                    ― Nelson Mandela

 

OUR MISSION

The “WIN-Writing Is Necessary” Project was developed as a supplemental tool to help assist and guide students to higher learning and achievement.

Our current goal is to provide 10,000 students with "W.I.N.-Writing Is Necessary" workshop materials including: 

  • Workshop Booklets
  • WIN Pencils & Pens
  • WIN Folders / Notepads
  • WIN T-Shirts 
  • ...and essential motivational materials.

In addition, some of our projects may include the "WIN-Writing Is Necessary" workshop series.

Partnership Model

The "WIN-Writing Is Necessary" Project will work closely with school and program administrators to help develop and distribute tools and techniques to help students enhance their ability and achieve higher test scores.

 

 

OUR GOALS

  • $25,000 - We can reach up to 10,000 students and school aged youth.

  • $50,000 - We can reach up to 25,000 students and school aged youth.

  • $100,000- We can reach up to 50,000 students and school aged youth(*worldwide*)

 

The Impact

“He who opens a school door, closes a prison.”

           -Victor Hugo

We at Next Level Publishing and WIN-Writing Is Necessary have a passion for writing and education. The statistics that associate the lack of education with crime and poverty throughout the world are astonishing.

We believe that it is virtually impossible to do this alone. The impact of a group effort can have remarkable results that will resonate well beyond a local and regional area. Education is the cornerstone of a successful nation and we truly believe the WIN Project can make a difference. 

For the past few years, The WIN-Project has reached students of all ages. The pilot program has been a success and we are ready to spread the project across the globe.

Your contribution can help ensure we educate and motivate the WINNERS of tomorrow.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people are unable to contribute, but that doesn’t mean you cannot help. Here are some ways you can assist us:

  • Please share this campaign with others. (Social Media / Word of Mouth / etc...)
  • Contact your local schools, churches and youth programs and spread the word about this exciting W.I.N. program.
  • Volunteers, Interns and Supporters can reach out on our website http://www.nextlevelpublishing.com/internship/

Thank You!

 

***Anonymous Donors Welcomed***

story:
My name is Cesar Martinez, and I want you to join me in cultivating the leaders we’ve been waiting for: The Young Veterans. Before explaining how we plan to achieve this, I want to answer what most of you are probably  wondering:

“What is a Young Veteran?”

 

Young Veteran: A person who, despite having lived for a relatively short time, presents as incomparably wise and long experienced in life’s challenges. Classification as a Young Veteran necessitates that one embodies three things:

1. A personal commitment to increasing intelligence, broadly defined, insofar as it may be used to serve;

2. A deeply rooted integrity that spans the foundations of any individual character traits or skill sets; And

3. An innate initiative that, in cooperation with one’s intelligence and integrity, shapes personal abilities into tangible and transformative outcomes.

 

I. Executive Summary

This campaign is to launch the inaugural Young Veterans Summer Program - an innovative four-week residential program that aims to cultivate every student-athlete into a socially responsible, civically engaged, well-versed leader who can utilize their unique skills to enhance their communities and create success in a field of their choice. This intensive athletic, personal, and professional development program tailored to under-resourced student-athletes in high school and junior college weaves together 6 major elements*:

  1. Intensive, personalized athletic development and training

  2. Daily community outreach and service engagements

  3. Hands-on workshops with esteemed professionals in a diversity of fields

  4. Academic engagements that will support a healthy student-athlete experience

  5. New and challenging opportunities for personal and social advancement, and

  6. A residential program designed to foster open conversations, mutual respect, and personal discipline.

 

*To read more about each of the aforementioned program components, visit the section entitled “The Program”

 

 

II. The Ask: $17K

At a bare minimum, we will need $17K to launch Young Veterans. However, in order to operate the program as it is intended, we will need $33K. Here is a breakdown of how we plan to use the base $17K that we need:

18% Organizational Operations

This portion of our budget will cover organizational expenses integral to operating the Summer Program well. Line items include: our Young Vets Website, photo/video coverage of the program, and a few small items like thank you notes and business cards.

34% Program Operations

Under program operations, budget items fall into 3 main categories:

    1. Athletic Operations (gym access, training equipment, first-aid kit etc.),

    2. Team Gear (uniforms for Young Vets and a Young Vets polo for business-casual engagements), and

    3. Transportation costs (monthly van rental and gas for college tours, community service, team hikes, games, and workshops)

48% Food & Living Costs

Feeding 8 athletes in training will be expensive. (Food costs alone represent 45% of our total $17K budget!) All of our athletes will be eating fresh, nutritionally packed foods that we prepare for and, many times, in conjunction with our program participants. Hence, this budget subsection’s line items consist of large volumes of fresh foods that are not inflated by costs associated with eating out.

Apart from food, the remainder of this budget subsection includes a modest budget for living expenses while the Young Vets are hosted locally free of charge (i.e. miscellaneous household items like cleaning supplies and a subsidy for projected increases in electricity costs).

0% Staffing Costs

Yes, you’re reading that correctly: we are not asking for any staffing costs as a part of this bare-bones budget. All of our program and summer staff have agreed to volunteer their time to see Young Vets happen. Even if we raise the full $33K, only $4K (12% of the total budget) will be paid to our dedicated staff.

 

 

III. Other Ways You Can Help

It will require immense efforts to bring the Young Veterans Summer Program to fruition. Your monetary contributions are greatly appreciated and will help move us in the right direction. Although we are asking for your financial support via this indieGoGo campaign, we are actively seeking other contributions that may aid us in our efforts to provide a life-changing summer experience to these enthusiastic young men. Although we always invite any ideas and enthusiasm that can add value to our program, here are some specific areas of need:

Housing

Although there is arranged housing available, we are still on the hunt for one centralized place better suited for the Young Veterans to interact and develop together. If you have a house in the Bay Area and would be open to donating use of it to the program or know of a good lead to finding dorm-style housing, please reach out!

Equipment

The depth and intensity of training in the Young Veterans Summer Program requires a great deal of  unique equipment. Although we have a small budget to procure some of these items, donating and/or lending any of the following would be a great help to the program:

Training equipment includes but is not limited to:

  • Speed ladders

  • Resistance Bands

  • Heavy Basketballs

  • Standard Basketballs

  • Cones

  • Hurdles

 

Community Service

Need help with the yard work you’ve been putting off? Work for an organization that could use some helping hands? Contact us if you’d like the Young Veterans to come work with you! We have a number of spots still available in the schedule just waiting for you to fill!

Workshops

Our comprehensive, hands-on workshops distinguish Young Veterans as a high quality program. Whether you feel that your story is one from which the Young Vets can derive inspiration, or you have very direct information to share with them - we welcome and encourage all suggestions, feedback, and input. Please inbox us a quick message with your ideas and inquiries. We’ll be sure to get back to you in a timely fashion.

Support & Spread the Word!

Believe in what we’re doing? Say it!

Whether on facebook or in-person, please tell your friends, families, and trusted networks about The Young Veterans and how they can get involved. You have no idea what kind of difference you can make!

 

 

IV. The Program

From June 17 - July 15, 2013, eight uniquely talented, hard working, and motivated young men that have demonstrated the raw passion and unbridled desire necessary to think, do, and be better will attend The Young Veterans Summer Program.  If you want to learn more about this bi-coastal group of ballers, visit the “Meet the Vets” section (Coming Soon!) below. 

 

Intensive, personalized athletic development and training

For roughly 5 hours on a daily basis, participants engage in intensive athletic trainings tailored to their developmental stage, needs, and goals. Specifically, they will receive:

Initial consultation and personalized training plan to gather baseline data and inform each Young Vet’s individual goals.

Basketball Skills and Development to give them an X-factor on the court that will match the intensity and quality of their character. During these two-a-day sessions, our Player Development coaching staff will be giving participants the real-time feedback and mentorship necessary to elevate their game.

Personalized Strength Training designed to bring each participant to his optimal physical capacity.

Speed & Agility Training based on game-like functional movements to enhance results.

 

Daily community outreach and service engagements

We believe that genuine character and true leadership are closely tied to one’s practiced ability to give without expectation of receiving. To this ends, each Young Vet works with different individuals and organizations in the community every day to do anything that bestows a net positive value. Whether in the form of independently cleaning up a local park, volunteering at a local nonprofit, or helping out a neighbor, we want the Young Veterans to walk away with a set of eyes trained to see endless opportunities to serve.

           

Hands-on workshops with esteemed professionals in a diversity of fields

Twice a week, the Young Vets will spend 5 hours learning and practicing a variety of highly useful things in workshops facilitated by different “Successful Athletes”: a class of people that we define as engaged citizens and professionals who, after extracting key skill sets and character traits from athletic participation at some level, have subsequently applied them to advancement in any realm. A full list of workshops and our incredible Successful Athletes volunteering for this summer’s program will be highlighted on our website in coming weeks, but check out a sneak peak of a few of the topics in the meantime:

Know Your Rights: Understanding the Law

Injury Prevention and Rehabilitation in Sports

Nutrition for Performance and Life

Personal Finance: Investing in your Future

 

Academic engagements that will support a healthy student-athlete experience

Learning how to balance academic and athletic demands are central to having a positive student-athlete experience at any level. With that in mind, a central part of our summer program is the Weekly College Tour. Over the course of the program, the Young Vets will receive a semi-customized tour of 4 different college campuses in the Bay Area. Each tour will be designed to give them real insight into the requirements, opportunities, challenges, and strategies for success unique to the experience of a collegiate student-athlete.

 

New and challenging opportunities for personal and social advancement

Every Friday, the Young Vets will journey beyond the bounds of everyday life for an extended outdoor excursion meant to test their limits and provide the space and time for personal reflection. Currently, we are planning to hike some of the Bay’s myriad of stunningly beautiful natural preserves and mountain ranges. The Young Vets will spend a subset of these adventures engaged in facilitated discussions and independent personal reflection. We believe that, paired with intensive athletic training and equally engaging workshops and community service opportunities, devoting time and energy to outdoor exploration is a necessary outlet to properly synthesize one’s many thoughts and feelings about this period of intensive growth.

 

A residential program designed to foster open conversations, mutual respect, and personal discipline.

Underlying every part of the Young Vets program is the backbone of the residential experience. The place where the Young Vets are being housed is more than just a place to rest their heads at night. We have intentionally designed the residential experience to be a learning experience in:

 

Nutrition

We will be using the residential setting to teach them how to select nutritional foods and actually prepare them because we believe that this is an important life skill for each individual participant to leave the program with.

 

Chores

Everyone living in the house will have a set of chores to complete on a set schedule. We aim to instill a strong sense of personal discipline and social responsibility in each Young Vet by having them complete even the smallest of chores with personal pride.

 

Cooperative Living

Sharing a living space can be hard, but we want to promote the value in adopting a lifelong mindset of cooperative living. As such, all ground rules are focused on being true to oneself while also being kind, respectful, and courteous of the time, space, and personal belongings of others.

For roughly 5 hours on a daily basis, participants engage in intensive athletic trainings tailored to their developmental stage, needs, and goals. Specifically, they will receive:
Initial consultation and personalized training plan to gather baseline data and inform each Young Vet’s individual goals.
Basketball Skills and Development to give them an X-factor on the court that will match the intensity and quality of their character. During these two-a-day sessions, our Player Development coaching staff will be giving participants the real-time feedback and mentorship necessary to elevate their game.
Personalized Strength Training designed to bring each participant to his optimal physical capacity.
Speed & Agility Training based on game-like functional movements to enhance results.
 
Daily community outreach and service engagements
We believe that genuine character and true leadership are closely tied to one’s practiced ability to give without expectation of receiving. To this ends, each Young Vet works with different individuals and organizations in the community every day to do anything that bestows a net positive value. Whether in the form of independently cleaning up a local park, volunteering at a local nonprofit, or helping out a neighbor, we want the Young Veterans to walk away with a set of eyes trained to see endless opportunities to serve.
           
Hands-on workshops with esteemed professionals in a diversity of fields
Twice a week, the Young Vets will spend 5 hours learning and practicing a variety of highly useful things in workshops facilitated by different “Successful Athletes”: a class of people that we define as engaged citizens and professionals who, after extracting key skill sets and character traits from athletic participation at some level, have subsequently applied them to advancement in any realm. A full list of workshops and our incredible Successful Athletes volunteering for this summer’s program will be highlighted on our website in coming weeks, but check out a sneak peak of a few of the topics in the meantime:
Know Your Rights: Understanding the Law
Injury Prevention and Rehabilitation in Sports
Nutrition for Performance and Life
Personal Finance: Investing in your Future
 
Academic engagements that will support a healthy student-athlete experience
Learning how to balance academic and athletic demands are central to having a positive student-athlete experience at any level. With that in mind, a central part of our summer program is the Weekly College Tour. Over the course of the program, the Young Vets will receive a semi-customized tour of 4 different college campuses in the Bay Area. Each tour will be designed to give them real insight into the requirements, opportunities, challenges, and strategies for success unique to the experience of a collegiate student-athlete.
 
New and challenging opportunities for personal and social advancement
Every Friday, the Young Vets will journey beyond the bounds of everyday life for an extended outdoor excursion meant to test their limits and provide the space and time for personal reflection. Currently, we are planning to hike some of the Bay’s myriad of stunningly beautiful natural preserves and mountain ranges. The Young Vets will spend a subset of these adventures engaged in facilitated discussions and independent personal reflection. We believe that, paired with intensive athletic training and equally engaging workshops and community service opportunities, devoting time and energy to outdoor exploration is a necessary outlet to properly synthesize one’s many thoughts and feelings about this period of intensive growth.
 
A residential program designed to foster open conversations, mutual respect, and personal discipline.
Underlying every part of the Young Vets program is the backbone of the residential experience. The place where the Young Vets are being housed is more than just a place to rest their heads at night. We have intentionally designed the residential experience to be a learning experience in:
 
Nutrition
We will be using the residential setting to teach them how to select nutritional foods and actually prepare them because we believe that this is an important life skill for each individual participant to leave the program with.
 
Chores
Everyone living in the house will have a set of chores to complete on a set schedule. We aim to instill a strong sense of personal discipline and social responsibility in each Young Vet by having them complete even the smallest of chores with personal pride.
 
Cooperative Living
Sharing a living space can be hard, but we want to promote the value in adopting a lifelong mindset of cooperative living. As such, all ground rules are focused on being true to oneself while also being kind, respectful, and courteous of the time, space, and personal belongings of others.

story:
A Little History

In September 2011, I went to Thailand on a Fulbright English Teaching Assistantship grant.  Through my placement at Maehorphra Wittayakom School in Chiang Mai, I met and got to know a talented student named Suttipon.

Suttipon is an exceptional young woman, devoted to learning and to helping her family.  She is bright, funny, and more than capable of achieveing her goals given an opportunity.

Suttipon grew up in a small, isolated Karen village in Mae Chaem, Chiang Mai.  As poor, ethnic minorities, Suttipon and the other families in her village lack the opportunity to receive their own education.  Those who can afford must travel down from the mountains to the Thai government schools in order to access any kind of formal education.

Suttipon identifies as a "White Karen."  It is an ethnicity within the large, heterogenous grouping of the Karen people, a people who primarily live in the mountains of southeastern Myanmar and northern Thailand.  The Karen people have historically practiced swidden agriculture and lived as subsistent farmers, while being relatively autonomous from the low land cultures of both the Bamars and the Thais.

The Karen people have little economic, political, or social power now to access institutional education.  As such, many families lack the opportunity and capability to pursue formal education.  

The Scholarship and Your Support

For the past several years, Suttipon and a group of other children from her home village of Mae Ju Sam have lived near and attended a government school together through the support of a Dutch organization called Hill Tribes Children.  However, when Suttipon graduates from high school next year, Hill Tribes Children will no longer be able to fully support her as she tries to attend university and become a teacher.  I hope to raise enough funds to fill the financial gaps and give Suttipon an opportunity to pursue her dream of becoming a teacher.

With your support, we can not only help a deserving young individual become the first woman from her family to graduate from university, but also assist her in living a dignified, happy life.  By achieving her goal of becoming a teacher, Suttipon will also help other rural, poor children from the mountains learn and grow, assist in community development, and allow her family to live a better life.

Suttipon will need $5,000 US dollars to continue her education through university for the next four years.  All of the money raised will go directly towards her tuition cost.

If you choose to support, you can receive letters and pictures from Suttipon, and traditional, handmade Karen bags and other crafts.  Any and all support is greatly appreciated!  

The Impact

I am committed to supporting Suttipon because I know the kind of person she is and what she is capable of.  I sincerely believe that any kind of development and sustainability begins with the education of women.  Your support will go a long way towards helping poor, marginalizd women overcome inequality and hardship.  A teaching scholarship for Suttipon will benefit herself, her family, and the mountaneous children and communities of northern Thailand.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the message and share Suttipon's story with others!

If you have any questions about Suttipon, the scholarship, or anything else, please contact me at my email, tayiokelly4@gmail.com.  You can also contact Hill Tribes Children and learn more about their work and the children they support.  Thanks again!

story:
The Bethlehem Children's School is an independent school for children ages three through eighth grade established in 1995 to provide a positive learning experiences for children. The idea behind our school is that children want to learn, and can do so best in a cooperative multi-age environment, with little stress, more attention from a teacher, and where inquiry-based learning is determined by a child's developmental readiness; the idea is that an initial nurturing educational environment fosters the development of a genuine, life-long passion for learning. The idea also includes the notion of being green - and where each child is encouraged to be a steward of the planet - not just our small corner of the Capital Region of New York State.

What Your Support Provides

There are many families in and around our community who would love to send their children to our school - but are unable to afford tuition. As a school, we offer tuition assistance/discounts to as many families as we can while still meeting our operating expenses but we'd like to offer a full scholarship to a need-based student.

Our elementary and middle school tuition is $9,250.  We charge an additional $125 to cover supplies.  This campaign seeks to raise $9,375 in order to offer one elementary or middle school student a full scholarship for the 2013-2014 school year.


We hope with your support we will reach this goal - but if we fall short of raising the full tuition, we will use any funds raised through this campaign to offset the cost of tuition and offer a family at our school a tuition assistance package.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute financially, would you kindly use the Indiegogo share tools to help spread the word to those who may be in a position to donate?

story:
Who Me?

Hello I am Natasha Huntington and I am trying to raise money so I can go to Center for Sacred Studies. It is an online school for Ministerial Training. The study includes "opportunity to explore specific methodologies, practiceds, theories, traditions, beliefs, scripttures, and philosophies, as well as allowing for the integration of individual spritual experiences." They do not have any financial aid to give. This is why I have setup this campaign. The money raised will go directly to the school for tuition. Anything left over will be put towards the two retreats (which are put on by the school) that I get to attend in California.

I have a four year degree from Central Washington University in Supply Chain Management. I have a large amount of student loans to pay back, which is why I was ecstatic when a friend directed me to indiegogo.com. What an amazing find!

Now that I am done with my degree, I am now able to focus a lot more on my spiritual journey again. The $5,000 I need to raise will cover tuition for the school. I have a friend who is in the program already and has agreed to let me use her books which will help out immensely.

How My Path Choose Me

The same friend recently took me to Lame Deer Montana for the 11th Gathering of the 13 Indigenous Grandmothers as my graduation present for graduationg from CWU. It was there that I realized what I what I want to do with my life. I want to live up to the Healer I know I can be. I am a light worker and I want to further my knowledge so that I can help others further their knowledge. Being connected to Source is one way that we can help ourselves so that we can help others.

I have researched many different path's, but found that no one was perfect for me. So I decided to take all of the teachings that I have received and use what felt right. From this, I have gathered that there is no one right way, that all are the right way as long as they are for the greatest and highest good for the entire universe.

Paying It Forward (How your contributions will help me help all)

With this campaign, I will be able to secure the funding to help better myself so I can send a ripple through my community, Earth. As I am able to strengthen my connection with Source, I will be able to contribute much more to everyone around me. I am on my path to enlightenment and I want to help others find their way also.

By helping myself, I feel that I will be better equipped to help the next generation with their awakening when that time comes. Everyone is connected. We are all on the same planet connected by the same web going all around our world. If we are able to higher our vibrations and raise our frequency as individuals, it will have a great effect on the planet as a whole which will lead us to a better world to live in.


Ways to Help without a financial contribution

You can send links via facebook or tweeter and help spread the word.

story:
My Story

Hi everyone!


As many of you probably know, I am Canadian and on a student visa studying at the New School in Manhattan. I finished my first year at this school (and my third year of my undergrad) last May and was on the Dean's list both semesters. I just recently found out that my sources for loans were not able to give me as much money as I needed in order to graduate. I have tried to get more loans and tried many different sources, but am unable to find someone to co-sign a loan for me from the bank and cannot get a loan from the United States because I am not American. I have been able to get some more scholarship money from my school but not enough.  


All of this said- I still need about $2000 (the exact amount is posted in the gallery on this page) for my tuition payment plan by November 1st in order to stay and complete my second last semester before graduating. 


What happens if I fundraise and make over $2000? I will give the world so many hugs, and any additional money donated above the $2000 needed will go towards tuition for next semester!


The Impact

You will be contributing to my education (every dollar helps!), and helping me finish my degree here in the United States! Otherwise, I'd have to go back to Canada and start over.

Another aspect of it is that I am in a relationship with an American who lives here and if I were to lose my student visa, I would have to go back to Canada. Which would mean that we wouldn't get to see each other very much, if at all. We would be having a relationship that is separated by the Canada/US border and hundreds of miles. 


What We Need & What You Get

Where is the money going? Straight to my tuition. When you donate to this fundraiser, it is going into my education chequing account which will go directly to my school to pay for tuition. None of the money I raise on here will go towards food, clothing, or any of my personal expenses. Every single cent goes toward my tuition.


What do you get out of it? You're helping me. You're giving me a chance to finish my education and move forward in life and make something of myself! Not only that, but you're helping to keep two loving and caring individuals to be together. And one day at our wedding (hahaha) you can say: I helped them stay together by contributing to Sarah's tuition so that she could keep her student visa. 


What else? 

I'm also a singer-songwriter. I wanna offer anything I can as a thank you for your contribution. Of course all my time and money at the moment needs to go toward paying my tuition. However, I do have a Macbook and I would love to use it to record a song for you. Do you have a cover you'd like to see me do? Do you want one of my originals on your ipod? If you donate $100 or more, I will record an original song for you and email it to you. If you donate $500 or more, I will record a cover of your choosing (within my musical abilities) and record it for you and play it for you live if you live in the New York area. No matter what amount you contribute (no matter how small), I will send you a personal thank you outlining the positive impact you have made on my education and my life right now.


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Tell your friends about me and my situation, post it on Facebook, twitter, wherever! Every single dollar helps and I appreciate it more than you know. 


Also, if you're feeling ambitious- hold a bake sale! I'll provide the oven and the supplies and come on over and help us do some more fundraising! 


Thank you, thank you, thank you everyone for your continued support. This means a lot to me and I could not do it without your help.

story:
A Short Summary

  In December, I plan to unicycle from Baltimore, MD to St.Louis, MO, making several stops along the way.  That's about 1000 miles. I'm a long distance unicyclist with a desire to turn my talent into good!  I've been unicycling for more than 13 years, and by now, riding up to 100 miles in a day is something very feasible for me!   

  Believe or not, this trip is a smaller testpiece for a humongous, world record-breaking trip I will be taking to South America next year!  That fundraiser will be coming later, after this (hopefully) successful trip.

Check out my website for pics, vids, and general info: CaryOutThere.com

******PLEASE leave a comment for me!  Even if you couldn't donate!

 

What I Need & What You Get

  I need your contributions! Only $5 gets you a hand-designed drink coaster designed by me! Only $10 gets you a super cool sticker of the same design.  I really appreciate your generosity, EVEN if I've already reached my goal!  I've set my goal to quite a bit lower than it should be, so as to make it more reachable. 75% of all donations will go directly to these charities:

 

**I'll also be doing tshirts (see "Wearin' it out" perk), but I need a minimum order, so please select that perk!!  

 

Arts Charity for U.S. Children: http://dreamingzebra.org/

International Child Art Foundation: http://www.icaf.org/

Sustainable Farming in Central America: http://www.sustainableharvest.org/

International Sustainabilty/Conservation:  http://www.greenpeace.org/international/en/

*I will be posting reciepts for my total donations to these 4 organizations after both the ride and the fundraiser are complete!*

  To make the trip a success, and therefore grow even more support for the causes, 25% will go to support costs, including trip costs and perks for donors.

 

The Impact

  The clichés are true - children are the future.  And we should also strive to preserve this earth for those same children!  These go hand in hand.  As an artist, I believe that harnessing and developing creativity in kids is important.  This carries over positively into their education and life in general.  We should also establish sustainable practices in the poorest regions of the earth, as well as promote responsible stewardship.


 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute, but still think it's cool that I'm a crazy guy on a unicycle?  Make some noise instead!  Comment on this campaign so as to raise the activity level, and/or share this on your facebook page, or join my facebook group: "Unicycling the World - CaryOutThere"

story:
Summary
To bolster the movement we have already started and to change the way we fund education. This will be done In conjunction with the Backbone Campaign  and will mobilize students and borrowers through high visibility direct actions.

We have been working together to combat issues on student debt with little money. We hope that with community donations we will be able to expand our reach to connect with more students on the issues of student debt.

 

Bio's

Natalia Abrams
Natalia Abrams is an educational advocate working toward solutions to provide accessible, quality, affordable education for all students. Natalia's first engagement with activism was protesting the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. She continued her passion by majoring in Women’s Studies at UCLA where she was a student intern at the Feminist Majority Foundation. Upon graduating UCLA in 2009, amid an economic crisis, the issues of education and student debt became the forefront of Natalia’s advocacy.

In 2011, Natalia co-founded the Occupy Colleges initiative. While serving as a the media representative of Occupy Colleges, Natalia wrote for the Student Nation, personally appeared on The Dylan Ratigan show on MSNBC, CBS Sunday Morning and Free Speech TV. In addition, Natalia has been quoted in the New York Times, Huffington Post, The Nation, NPR, Reuters, AP, Nation of Change, among many other media sources. Natalia is passionate about engaging with college students and tackling the issues of student debt.  She currently serves as a Backbone Campaign research fellow and the Co-Founder/Director of Operations for StudentDebtCrisis.org - Follow her on twitter @nataliaabrams

Kyle McCarthy
Kyle currently serves as a “people mobilizer” and new media strategist for nonprofits and social change organizations and the Associate Producer for Krotala Films. In his role, Kyle has led a grassroots campaign around the film, DEFAULT: The Student Loan Documentary working with over 200 campus and community organizations to show the film and is part of the team working on the follow-up film. Stemming from his work with DEFAULT and for starting OccupyStudentDebt.com, Kyle was recently named one of the top 10 advocates fighting for student loan reform and asked to speak at this year’s Left Forum. His projects have appeared in over 200 media while personally appearing in The Associated Press, Huffington Post, Salon, RT America, Free Speech TV, Christian Science Monitor, AlterNet, Tech President, La Presse, The Nation, Backbone Campaign, Nation of Change, American Urban Radio Network (airing on 300 affiliates) appears on nationally syndicated The Norman Goldman Show, and many others.

In addition to his work in higher education, Kyle has been involved with labor rights, corporate accountability, and animal rights. Kyle is a graduate of Mount Saint Mary’s University in Maryland where he received a degree in Business and Marketing and received his M.A. from the University of San Francisco. He currently lives in San Francisco and his role models are his mother and grandparents.

 
-What we will do
-Put together the “go to” website and resource guide for all things student debt which would be located at BackboneCampaign.org/StudentDebt. 

-Write articles on the student debt crisis, tuition hikes, and education being a right.

-Build a media database which will include print, digital, tv, and radio and legislators for each geographical area which can be utilized for campaigns.

-Build a petition website for Backbone which will enable backbone to collect email addresses, reach a wider audience, and more exposure of important issues such as predatory student lending.  The petitions would also encourage more people to submit their student stories and action.
    -Make it more than just a petition tool, but have the ability to target your congressperson,
    and your local media with the database we have already started compiling.

-Possible name: PeopleMobilizer.com / .org


-Assistance with social media and reaching out to media.

-Write press releases for Backbone for student debt and other campaign issues and pushing them out through our contacts.

-Talks with local high schools and colleges on the student debt crisis and working with community on direct actions (Rallies, teach-ins etc) to engage students on the issue of debt and tuition hikes. We would like to institute a  comprehensive program that educates college students to go into high schools for one day lectures on student debt. . We would like to use recent graduates to come and tell their personal debt stories to students currently in high school and college - Occupy Alumni (we own the .com and .org)
                      
-Actions
- Teach a social media and traditional media class possibly at Localize This and/or other conferences such as the National Student Convergence, SDS conference, etc.
- Educate student loan reformers on the importance of getting money out of politics. The two issues need to work in tandem to get anything done.   


-Direct Actions (To keep street heat energy directed toward the issues of student debt)
    -Sept. 17th Solidarity Rally to celebrate the one year anniversary of OWS
        Solidarity actions on college campus with the intent to take over administration buildings
    -October 15-17 Global Rally for Students
    - Teach - In's

 

- Why we need money:  To bolster the movement we have already started and to change the way we fund education.
story_txt:
Summary To bolster the movement we have already started and to change the way we fund education. This will be done In conjunction with the Backbone Campaign  and will mobilize students and borrowers through high visibility direct actions.We have been working together to combat issues on student debt with little money. We hope that with community donations we will be able to expand our reach to connect with more students on the issues of student debt.

story:
Who We Are

My name is Renee Redding Jones and I am the Founder of The Center
for Life and Learning.  

The idea for The Center rode in on the wings of my daughter.
It was my journey with her and understanding her learning differences
that inspired and led me to the vision of creating The Center for Life and
Learning.  

When you first become aware that your child is not developing
typically, and particularly if you’ve received a diagnosis, as a parent or
caregiver you are instantly thrown into a world you didn’t expect.  Some
say, it’s like landing in Holland when you thought you were going to France and
others say it’s like landing in Beirut.  

Whatever your perspective, it’s a foreign land and no one speaks
your language.  Almost everything that anyone has told you or you know
from raising your other children has been rendered useless.  

You run from place to place, specialist upon specialist, trying
various therapies, looking for support groups, and balancing all of this while
taking care of the rest of your family.  

Our goal at The Center is to help the individuals experiencing the
challenge and to ease the stress on their families.  We take care of both
the child or young adult and their parent or caregiver.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are all ready to go, but we need your help.  We have the
expertise, along with the location. However, today we are asking for your
support to help with start up costs.  Funds raised will go towards,
subsidizing families to help them afford our services, paying rent, buying furnishings,
computers, materials for various workshops and classes, PR, marketing, and
salaries.  Please consider assisting us in reaching our financial goal so
we can reach our ultimate goal of serving children and their families.

 

The Impact

At The Center we offer some of the most cutting edge holistic
therapies Reiki, Brain Gym, Feldenkrais, CranioSacral Therapy, small
group inclusive yoga classes and Therapeutic Yoga classes for parents and children.  We couple our holistic therapies with more traditional ones like Music Therapy.  

Our leading traditional method is Rapid Prompting Method (RPM),
created by Soma Mukhopadhyay, a 1:1 modality used for individuals who have low verbal skills or are non-verbal.  Rapid Prompting Method and Soma have been featured on 60 Minutes, Oprah and Larry King Live.  

With RPM we offer young people a profound opportunity to
communicate who may not otherwise be able to do so, lessening challenging
self-injurious behaviors, easing stress to produce better environment for
learning and helping families deal with the stress of raising a child or
children who require extra support academically, emotionally and socially.

It’s important for us to be able to offer these services to every
family regardless of their ability to pay.  We are in the process of becoming
a non-for-profit and a portion of the money raised will be to pay
practitioners to work with those families who can’t afford the services.
This means that no one is turned away.

Other Ways You Can Help

According to the National Census Bureau in 2012, 1 out of 5 people
in the US have a “disability.”  Essentially everyone knows someone, a
friend or family member, with special needs. It may bring them great comfort to
know that a place like TCLL exists.  As a new small business we need your
help to get the word out.  Use Indiegogo share tools and let your friends
know about The Center and our campaign.

story:
Who is Eddie Madril

Eddie Madril is a member of the Pascua Yaqui tribe of Southern Arizona and Northern Sonora Mexico. He is an active member of the Native American community and a representative of his culture through various aspects: as a dancer, singer, artist, teacher, playwright and filmmaker. For over twenty-five years, his involvement and commitment to Native heritage has provided him with the opportunity to share a wealth of information amongst diverse communities. His work has included the presentation of assemblies and residencies in Bay Area schools working with students and encouraging the development of appreciation and respect for American Indian dance, music, culture, history, art and sign language.

He was awarded as a three-year recipient of the California Arts Council Artist-In-Residence grant, as well as the San Francisco Foundation individual artists' grant and a grant from the San Francisco Arts Council. He was nominated for the Isadora Duncan Dance Award as a soloist for his hoop dance presentation in his 2008 original play "SunDagger Solstice” and in 2011 he was recognized by KQED as an Bay Area American Indian Local Hero.


The Fashion Show – Indigenous Couture

Friday Nights at the de Young is part of the Fine Arts Museums’ Cultural Encounters Initiative, and has been overwhelmingly popular, regularly drawing our highest attendance days each week with 2,000 to 4,000 visitors per Friday night. Friday Nights is a festival environment that welcomes all age groups and backgrounds. Themes typically relate to the Museums’ permanent collections and special exhibitions, offering the visitors’ new perspectives and insights into the works of art in the galleries.

During The Fashion World of Jean Paul Gaultier’s run at the de Young, Friday Nights will focus on the multi-cultural aspect of Gaultier’s designs, featuring music, costumes, fashion, regalia, and dance performances by local artisits.

Eddie Madril was awarded the opportunity to present “Indigenous Couture” a fashion show of his design using music, story telling, dance, and the catwalk together to share the culture and beauty of American Indian people through both historical and contemporary reflections of style and the role clothing plays in individuality, family and community as an expression of who we are.

On Friday June 22nd, through Eddie’s vision the talent and collaboration of local Native American Bay Area artists, craftsmen and designers comes together to feature works representing native regions and nations/tribes of North America - from Alaska, Northwest Coast, and California, to the Southwest, Plains, Northeast, and Southeast regions.


What We Need

We are aiming to raise $10, 000 to cover the material costs, tailor fees, artists fees, and production costs associated with this project, including 4 tailors, 5 contributing artists/designers, 10 models, 3 dancers, and material/fabric needed for the creation of over 18 original designs.

The de Young Museum of San Francisco, has been amazingly generous in their support, and while we are overwhelmed by their commitment to this project, all of the costs of this project are not yet covered.  Any contributions, no matter how small, will help us support all the talent that has come together to create this vision.

story:
What is P.L.U.C.E.A?

P.L.U.C.E.A simply means "People Like Us are Changing Education in Africa"

 

Who We Are

We are a Father-Son team genuinely dedicated to improve the educational and Information Technology infrastructure throughout Africa.

Ekwow Spio-Garbrah is a former Ghana Secretary of Education (1998-2002). Papaa coordinates group activities for the youth living in the city of New York which centers on positive leisure activities inlcuding Video games, Karaoke and Movie Screenings

Together, we pledge to educate the people by developing ICT centers for the rural and urban regions throughout the continent of Africa...and BEYOND.

There’s a dire need for computers and modern ICT (Informational and communication Technology) centers especially in the villages where good health and prevention of diseases is a tremendous concern amongs the people. 

Within the Schools, computers will be used to empower academic courses such as Science, Math, Geography and History.

 

 

 

How You Can Help

$10,000: 1 Computer Lab + Accessories for ONE School + Shipping fees $10,000 -

$10,000 - 20,000: 1 Computer Lab + Accessories for THREE Schools + Shipping fees + Cost of P.L.U.C.E.A. website

$20,000+: Covers everything listed above PLUS operation costs for 2 to 5 more Schools in other African countries throughout the year 2013.

 

 

 

 

THANK YOU FOR DONATING

story:
Why is this important?

Hi my name is Bryan Buchanan and I teach Technology Education. I am in the process of trying to reform the Technology Curriculum starting in my class! One of the objectives of technology education is to have the student use manufacturing tools to prototype and manipulate the world. The problem is we are using tools that are from the 19th and 20th century! I teach 7th grade, which means that they will not be in the “real world” for about 10 years. This means that we need to teach them what will be important and what jobs and careers await them. Right now 3D printing has entered the market with consumer friendly 3D printers. This is the time to educate and inspire our future! Technology is the avenue to all the advanced sciences like; Nanotechnology, Biotechnology, and Artificial Intelligence (Which I teach). By inspiring my students with awe I intend on placing the importance of them being scientifically and technologically literate.

 

What is 3D printing? Watch here!

 

What We Need

I have already tried to get the school district to buy these but due to budget cuts and bad economic times this is not a priority

By raising $10000:

This will allow for the purchase of (4) 3D Makerbot 3D Printers, to be shared by 4 technology teachers.

If the goal is not made: I will purchase as many 3D printers as the funds allow.

***Any additional funds over $10,000 will go directly into the purchase of updating the technology room (Making room for projects that include: 3D Projection Mapping, Augmented Reality, Robotics & Automation, Artificial Intelligence, Autonomous Car's, Biotechnology (Regenerative Medicine, Synthetic Biology, Bionic Body Parts) Nanotechnology and Renewable Energy Technologies)

Basically the coolest technology class ever!

Additional funds will also allow me to also purchase more printers for high school classes. So that if the students get interested in design and manufacturing they can continue in a more advanced class.

 

The Impact

It’s important to understand that technology is what’s driving our futures. It’s imperative to excite these young minds with the possibilities that await them and that we provide them with interests and goals. Once inspired by awe it drives us to accomplish anything! I want to provide these students with an education that when they leave 7th grade, they have a clear direction about the future. Too many people now go to college with little understanding about what they want to do.

By reforming Technology Education in the 7th and 8th grade when it is mandated, we will leave all students itching to learn the higher sciences and mathematics.

 

 Please watch one of the most AWE inspiring videos (about these technologies) made by Jason Silva

 

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xdzLCnOMjyQ&feature=g-upl

Other Ways You Can Help

Please get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.

Please Share

story:
WE DID IT! THANK YOU!

IF WE CAN RAISE $1,350 MORE, ALL OF OUR EXPENSES (BANK FEES, PERK COSTS) WILL BE COVERED.

CAN WE DO IT? WE THINK SO! PLEASE KEEP GIVING AND ENCOURAGE OTHERS TO GIVE ALSO.

IF WE RAISE EVEN MORE, WE CAN GROW EVEN MORE!  HOW ABOUT A NEW OVEN FOR THE SCHOOL KITCHEN? A FULL TIME GARDENER? A GREENHOUSE? A KITCHEN CLASSROOM? A GARDEN FOR OUR MIDDLE SCHOOL AND HIGH-SCHOOL?  WITH SUPPORT, THE POSSIBILIITIES ARE ENDLESS.

THANKS AGAIN TO EVERYONE!!!!

 

As we move into Harvest Hudson Valley's second year we are expanding the scope of this project beyond the Mill Road Elementary Garden Classroom, to include our Middle School and High-school students and develop a Cooking program and a district-wide School Lunch Initiative. We believe that all students in the Red Hook Central School District should have the opportunity to grow, cook and eat healthy, fresh food at school and that each stage- growing, cooking and eating- is equally important for the development of lifelong health and nutrition.

The Mill Road Garden Classroom has over 20 classes working in the garden weekly. In collaboration with school administrators and teachers -

  • We are creating more curriculum-based garden lessons for teachers.
  • We are also working with the school’s district-wide Wellness Committee and Athletics department to establish a Cooking Classroom program for the Fall 2013, where students at all grade levels K-12 will learn basic cooking skills and receive nutritional lessons, with the help of local chefs.
  • We are getting our School Lunch Initiative well underway —as of November 1, 2012, every cafeteria in our district is offering salad as daily menu option and the students’ response has been tremendous!

 

What We Need Right Now to GROW - COOK - EAT

For the Garden Classroom

$3,000: Raised beds, including soil, lumber, labor

Raised beds are advantageous to the garden because it delineates garden space neatly and shows children the difference between planted and unplanted space. It helps tremendously in our climate to get a head start on the season with warming and draining the soil faster for directly sown seeds and tender seedlings. It helps to maintain the garden more efficiently and aesthetically with weed control and watering.

             

$500: Outdoor communication center

This will be helpful with school wide communication about garden tasks, responsibilities and events.  This will allow our garden team to pin messages  & schedules to the cork while protecting it from the elements. 

 

$500: Garden Education/curriculum materials Summer Teacher Training

In July of 2013 the Harvest Hudson Valley educator team will offer district teacher training in the form of an on-site workshop. 

           

$2,000: Summer Gardener

We need to keep our garden growing. The summer gardener stipend will ensure that the garden continues weekly management of garden tasks such as weeding, watering, mowing, mulching, composting, harvesting, pest control and succession plantings during the 10 weeks of summer when school is not in session.

The summer gardener will also help us be ready to jump right back in when the kids return in September.

 

For the School Lunch Initiative & Cooking Classroom

 

$6000: Bring cooking back to the kitchen and our schools!

We are so lucky to have Clara Wittek as our Food Services Director.  Let’s help Clara bring homemade cooking with fresh ingredients back to the Red Hook Central School District. She’s made great progress with new salad bars throughout the district, but Clara needs additional kitchen equipment to offer more healthy fresh food options. Our new district wide Cooking program needs mobile kitchen/cooking carts to teach our students the basic of cooking.

           

Needs Include: Mobile cooking carts, cooking cart/mobile kitchen tools sets (pots, pans, burner, etc.), soup kettles, food processor, ice machines (ice is important to keep our new district wide salad bars fresh!), etc…    

 

**Harvest Hudson Valley operates under the fiscal sponsorship of the Red Hook Education Foundation***
story_txt:
WE DID IT! THANK YOU!
IF WE CAN RAISE $1,350 MORE, ALL OF OUR EXPENSES (BANK FEES, PERK COSTS) WILL BE COVERED.
CAN WE DO IT? WE THINK SO! PLEASE KEEP GIVING AND ENCOURAGE OTHERS TO GIVE ALSO.
IF WE RAISE EVEN MORE, WE CAN GROW EVEN MORE!  HOW ABOUT A NEW OVEN FOR THE SCHOOL KITCHEN? A FULL TIME GARDENER? A GREENHOUSE? A KITCHEN CLASSROOM? A GARDEN FOR OUR MIDDLE SCHOOL AND HIGH-SCHOOL?  WITH SUPPORT, THE POSSIBILIITIES ARE ENDLESS.
THANKS AGAIN TO EVERYONE!!!!
 
As we move into Harvest Hudson Valley's second year we are expanding the scope of this project beyond the Mill Road Elementary Garden Classroom, to include our Middle School and High-school students and develop a Cooking program and a district-wide School Lunch Initiative. We believe that all students in the Red Hook Central School District should have the opportunity to grow, cook and eat healthy, fresh food at school and that each stage- growing, cooking and eating- is equally important for the development of lifelong health and nutrition.
The Mill Road Garden Classroom has over 20 classes working in the garden weekly. In collaboration with school administrators and teachers - 

We are creating more curriculum-based garden lessons for teachers. 
We are also working with the school’s district-wide Wellness Committee and Athletics department to establish a Cooking Classroom program for the Fall 2013, where students at all grade levels K-12 will learn basic cooking skills and receive nutritional lessons, with the help of local chefs.
We are getting our School Lunch Initiative well underway —as of November 1, 2012, every cafeteria in our district is offering salad as daily menu option and the students’ response has been tremendous!



 
What We Need Right Now to GROW - COOK - EAT
For the Garden Classroom
$3,000: Raised beds, including soil, lumber, labor
Raised beds are advantageous to the garden because it delineates garden space neatly and shows children the difference between planted and unplanted space. It helps tremendously in our climate to get a head start on the season with warming and draining the soil faster for directly sown seeds and tender seedlings. It helps to maintain the garden more efficiently and aesthetically with weed control and watering.
             
$500: Outdoor communication center
This will be helpful with school wide communication about garden tasks, responsibilities and events.  This will allow our garden team to pin messages  & schedules to the cork while protecting it from the elements. 
 
$500: Garden Education/curriculum materials Summer Teacher Training
In July of 2013 the Harvest Hudson Valley educator team will offer district teacher training in the form of an on-site workshop. 
           
$2,000: Summer Gardener
We need to keep our garden growing. The summer gardener stipend will ensure that the garden continues weekly management of garden tasks such as weeding, watering, mowing, mulching, composting, harvesting, pest control and succession plantings during the 10 weeks of summer when school is not in session.
The summer gardener will also help us be ready to jump right back in when the kids return in September.
 
For the School Lunch Initiative & Cooking Classroom
 
$6000: Bring cooking back to the kitchen and our schools!
We are so lucky to have Clara Wittek as our Food Services Director.  Let’s help Clara bring homemade cooking with fresh ingredients back to the Red Hook Central School District. She’s made great progress with new salad bars throughout the district, but Clara needs additional kitchen equipment to offer more healthy fresh food options. Our new district wide Cooking program needs mobile kitchen/cooking carts to teach our students the basic of cooking.
           
Needs Include: Mobile cooking carts, cooking cart/mobile kitchen tools sets (pots, pans, burner, etc.), soup kettles, food processor, ice machines (ice is important to keep our new district wide salad bars fresh!), etc…    
 
**Harvest Hudson Valley operates under the fiscal sponsorship of the Red Hook Education Foundation***

story:
Short Summary

The goal of the Gift of Education Campaign is to provide scholarships for tuition, room and board to HIV/AIDS impacted children in Tanzania.  Scholarships will enable these children to achieve their dreams of being able to go to school and to live in a safe place while doing so.  Going to school will provide a pathway to future employment and economic opportunity.

Children in Tanzania are required to purchase uniforms and books, and to pay other fees, in order to attend school.  Due to extreme poverty, millions of Tanzanian children do not have the opportunity to go to school.  Children impacted by HIV/AIDS in this region are severely ostracized, which creates further obstacles in their quest to access education.  Point of Prevention (POP) is a small non-profit organization fighting against HIV/AIDS in Sub-Saharan Africa through collaboration, education and support of those impacted by the epidemic.

What We Need & What You Get

We have identified five children who are in desperate need of your support.  With your help, they will be able to get an education.  With an education, they will have the opportunity to life themselves and their families out of poverty.

For approximately $25, we are able to provide a child with a school uniform, books and fees for the child's first month of school.  If you pledge at this level, you will receive a picture of the child you have sponsored in his or her new school uniform.

For approximately $100 per month, we are able to ensure that each child not only attends school, but has a safe place to live and receives daily meals while doing so.  If you pledge at this level, you will receive a picture of the child you have sponsored in his or her new school uniform, and an update on their first month in school.

For $1200, we are able to ensure that each child attends school, has a safe place to live and receives daily meals for an entire year.  If you pledge at this level, you will receive a picture of the child you have sponsored in his or her new school uniform, and monthly updates on their progress in school. 

The Impact

For all children, education is the key to a better life.  For a child whose life has been impacted by HIV/AIDS in Tanzania, education may provide the only opportunity for future employment and economic security.  

 

“Education is the most powerful weapon which you can use to change the world.”  

― Nelson Mandela

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not able to contribute personally, please consider liking us on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/PointOfPrevention, visiting our website at http://pointofprevention.org/ telling your friends and family about the work that we are doing and the support that these children need.

story:
What is the School of Biblical Foundations (SBF)?

The School of Biblical Foundations is a twelve-week course at Youth With a Mission designed to equip students with the practical skills needed for personal Bible study. This course concentrates primarily on personal study and practical application rather than on an in-depth study of every book of the Bible. The goal of the SBF is to have each graduate trained to study the Word on their own and to develop study disciplines that will last a lifetime.

This school is unique as we will be traveling to Egypt, Jordan, Israel and Greece for on-site study and teaching. We will be traveling from August 9th, 2012 - September 8th, 2012. During our trip we will visit some of the different Biblical sites in each country as well as have historical teaching and background study on some books of the Bible.

For more info on our school please visit: http://www.ywamdenver.org/training/school-of-bi...

What Do We Need?

We need $6,000. This is the first time we've run this school and the travel costs and site visits are more than we originally budgeted. This amount is above and beyond what the students have already paid for their school and trip. With your contribution you will make it possible for us to visit more Biblical sites. We will be able to see the Bible come alive before our very eyes.

Who Needs the Money?

There are eleven students and two staff in the SBF that will be traveling to each country.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please get the word out and share our compaign with the people you know. Use the Indiegogo share tools found on our site to share it with your friends!

 

Please keep in mind that donations are not tax-deductible.

story:
Aanii, Bonjour, Hello. My name is Alexandra Hayes and I'm currently a student at Laurentian University in Northern Ontario.  I decided to put myself on here as a "cause to support" because I'm down on my luck and could use any help I can get. I've been told by many elders that being strong means knowing when to ask for help. I'm asking now.  I want to one day be a teacher on a reserve in Canada.  I'm terrified because I won't be able to afford school and rent next year.University prices have been rising like crazy lately and rent prices for students have been following them up.

My goal is to raise enough money to help me afford my education, a roof over my head, and nourishment.

I'm so incredibly passionate about Native Studies. I'm already teaching everything I learnt in my first year to all my friends and trying to get them excited as well.

Teaching is important.  I want to have the best education (which Laurentian offers for Native Studies).

The feeling that I have now... Feeling as if my dream of sharing my passion and helping others find their own passions and rights to fight for is honestly the worst feeling I have ever experienced.

I don't know if joining this website was the right thing for me to do... But I'm hoping against hope that it is.
I hope one day I will be able to give back more to the world than I received.
 
Miigwetch.  Merci.  Thank you so much.

story:
Our passion for and commitment to mentoring lies in the holistic development of the youthful mind, in order to train up highly successful and productive citizens. Our approach captures the mind and incorporates the spirit by enriching comprehensive knowledge, developing leadership, instilling moral values, embracing technology, and encouraging positive academic performance. The “life” skills gained by the youth will promote cycles of positive living that will enhance many communities through service.

PXWM LLC is passionate about spiritual and academic success.  Our Youth live lives that are devoid of wholesome fun and activities.  In many surrounding communities, there does not exist one place where students can get homework help, tutoring, mentoring, take part in workshops, sports, and community service.  Imagine a place where your child is not only safe, but is also learning and developing.  This place is where kids would want to go and not be forced or required to go.  PXWM LLC seeks to form solid partnerships with parents, local, state, and national officials, and the youth.  Together, we can change the landscape of disparaging statistics and raise the level of academic success.

Our children deserve a level playing field that is catered towards addressing their specific needs. Join us is being able to have a facility, technology, transportation, and land to make this a completed reality.  When we tell our kids to dream big, here is an area where we can put our sentiments into action!

 

Our needs are immediate!  The bulk of the contributions will be used to lease office space in the Prince George's County community.

We will need:

1. 10 fully operational computers with software

2.  1 SmartBoard and Projector

3.  3 television monitors

4.  Tables, desks, and chairs

5.  Office supplies (paper, notebooks, pens, pencils, eraser, markers, etc.)

6.  Volunteers to get the word out.  Connections with sponsors.

7.  Books (textbooks & daily reading titles)

8.  15 Passenger Van

9.  3 Video Game Consoles, games and accessories

10.  Youth, youth, and more youth!!!


The vision is to create a great environment for both fun and learning.  God has provided the vision and therefore He will increase the provisions.  With your help, we will be able to create a utopia that will grow and be a staple in our communities near and far.

 

Imagine less punishments, less crime, lower dropout rates, increased testing scores, more activities, more support, higher graduation rates, etc.  Promising these things is futile, but we have to start making a difference.  When more individuals, partnerships, and companies start working together to find solutions, then we can truly lessen the negative impact on our communities and increase the positive impact.  Will you join me in making a difference and encouraging others to do the same?  We can foster more that just hope because we will be putting necessary and required action behind our words of promise.

 

Ways that you can help right now:

1. Monetary donations

2. Time commitment

3. Spreading the word

4. Logistics and Planning

5. Equipment donations

6. Sponsorships

7. Prayer

8. Encouragement

There are many tools on this site to aid on the movement.  Thank you very much and God bless you, All!
