story:
Short Summary

We need money to build an iPad-based, cloud-powered platform to increase the reach and impact of the dynamic Invisible Capital Mapping Experience™ for solopreneurs, social entrepreneurs, activists, community organizers, enterprise leaders, NGO management teams and newly self-employed laid off workers.

I wrote the book Invisible Capital: How Unseen Forces Shape Entrepreneurial Opportunity to shed light on the array of hidden assets successful entrepreneurs leverage to their advantage.

I wanted to share these insights to help all those millions of Americans achieve their own American Dream while advocating for ways to do so that sustains communities versus preying on them.

A little about me. I've . . .

   • Worked on Capitol Hill and the White House Conference on Small Business;

   • Run a nationally acclaimed urban business incubator;

   • Been a serial entrepreneur since college.

Also, I'm . . .

  • The Social Entrepreneur in Residence at Temple University Fox School of
     Business' Innovative and Entrepreneurship Institute;

   • A fellow in Sustainable Design fellow at Philadelphia University's College of
      Architecture and Built Environment;

   • A former visiting researcher at Princeton University's Woodrow Wilson School for
      Public and International Affairs 

   • A frequent commentator and writer on issues of social and economic justice.
  
   • Actively mentoring college entrepreneurs from low-wealth communities.

Those who contribute to this cause will get a range of Invisible Capital-related offerings, including at higher giving levels:
 
   • Autographed copies of my book
   • Pole position for testing the IC-ME™ iPad app
   • Private individual or group ICME™ workshop with e-coaching

What We Need & What You Get

Here's the breakdown for what we need, why, and where it's going:

   • We need roughly $15,000 to pay for software development undergirding the new
      cloud-based Invisible Capital Mapping Experience™ platform.

   • This custom CRM-based platform will allow us to guide, track and support
      individuals and teams that have taken our workshops and need help leveraging
      their newly revealed invisible capital to build their entrepreneurial capacity.

   •  We also are overhauling the design, layout and materials for our workshops.

   • We have already conducted workshops in 4 states and 5 universities within 6
      months of launching the Invisible Capital Mapping Experience™.

   • Testimonials for and evites to past workshops are often posted here and our
      workshop promo can be viewed here.
 
   • If our financial goal isn't met by October 25th (my great-uncle Mike's 99th
     birthday!), we will still be able to use the funds we have raised by that time and
     will seek to raise additional funds through other avenues.

The Impact

By seamlessly infusing technology into these workshops, we will be able to better serve participants by extracting and analyzing more information they provide us through their active involvement in these sessions. We seek to not only help participants understand, identify and map their unique invisible capital, but allow them to influence how their map evolves over time with our technologically-mediated guidance and support.

With your help, the latest and greatest version of the Invisible Capital Mapping Experience™ workshop will not only continue to be a "hi-touch" experience, but a hi-tech one as well!

This mobile platform will help participants . . .
 
   • Remain true to their own goals;
   • Leverage information from their InvisiCap Maps to more
      strategically and effectively develop action plans for success; and,
   • Receive guidance, build knowledge and networks based on the customized reports
      and updates they receive after the workshops.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some folks just can’t give financial support at this time. We understand that, but there are other ways of helping the cause:

   • Spread the word about this campaign via email and social media;
   • Recommend me as a speaker, panelist or radio/TV show guest;
   • Contact us about scheduling an IC-ME™ workshop for yourself, your team, or
      organization members today @ 888-490-7770 or indiegogo@chrisrabb.com!
  
Please be sure to use the Indiegogo SHARE tools!

story:
Röviden, tömören:

 

Zilai János vagyok, a magyar amerikafutball-válogatott tagja. 19 éves koromra már 5 szezon rutint gyűjtöttem a felnőtt bajnokságból. 2016-ban összevágtam egy videót a legjobb megmozdulásaimról és elküldtem amerikai egyetemi edzőknek. Jónéhányan válaszoltak és a többség szerint megütöm az ottani szintet. Azt viszont nem tudják, hogy a mi bajnokságunk milyen színvonalat képvisel, így a további lépések előtt szeretnének a saját szemükkel is látni. A nyári táborokban lehetőségem nyílna megmutatni a korombeli amerikai fiúk ellen is, hogy felveszem a versenyt bárkivel. Rengeteg helyre hívtak, de hiába, mivel nincs pénzem elutazni. Az itt összejövő segítséget arra használnám fel, hogy kiutazzak és részt vegyek annyi ilyen egynapos táborban, amennyi csak belefér egy bő hét alatt.

 

A pontos terv:

Az a tervem, hogy kiutazok az USA keleti partjára valahová, ahová olcsó a repülőjegy, hiszen ott sűrűn vannak a csapatok. Elmegyek egy táborba, majd miután végeztem buszra pattanok és indulok a következőbe. Minden nap lesz új lehetőség. Az egyetemek tavasszal hozzák nyilvánosságra a pontos dátumokat, az alapján belövöm, hogy milyen útvonal lehetek a leghatékonyabb, hogy minél több hely beleférjen.

Nem akarok sokat költeni, így a szállásoláson is spórolni fogok. A fő cél, hogy összejöjjön annyi pénz, amennyi az utazásokat finanszírozza. Ha nem sikerül, akkor félreteszem, és egy évvel később újra nekifutok.

 

A hatás:

Ösztöndíjas sportolóként nem csak a világ legerősebb amatőr ligájában tudnék fejlődni, hanem szemeszterenként több ezer dollárt nyernék az amerikai futball miatti ingyenes oktatással.

Ezen túl öregbíthetném a honi (és európai) amerikai futball hírnevét, hiszen évente mindössze egy maroknyi fiú tud magának helyet szerezni Európából indulva az NCAA-ben.

Tavaly nyáron a német Zavier Scott 3085 dollárt kalapozott össze egy hasonló projekttel és néhány hónapra rá már a UConn Huskies játékosának mondhatta magát.

 

Buktatók és kihívások:

A legnagyobb kihívás a menetrend pontos kidolgozása egyik helyszínről a másikra utazva. Szerencsére hónapok vannak rá, hogy mindent eltervezzek.

Ha a 2017-es év dátumaiból indulok ki, például egy ilyen útvonal megoldható lett volna:

Elon        Péntek   június 16.  $50  North Carolina  Division I
Liberty     Szombat június 17.  $60  Virginia        Division I
JMU         Vasárnap  június 18.  $80  Virginia        Division I FCS 
Virginia   Hétfő  június 19.  $60  Virginia        Division I FBS 
Towson      Kedd  június 20.  $40  Maryland        Division I FCS 

Érkezés, távozás pedig a washingtoni reptérről. A nagyobb csapatok táboraiban (mint például a Virginia) kisebb egyetemek képviselői is nagy számban vannak jelen, így 5 helyszínen sem csak 5 csapatnak adnám elő magam.

Egyéb segítségi lehetőségek:

Ha anyagilag nem is, másképp is lehet támogatni.

  • A projekt hírének erjesztése nagyon sokat számít!
  • Amennyiben valaki Amerikában (bármely helyszínen tud segíteni útmutatással, szállással, utaztatással), azzal is sokkal előrébb lennék!

Köszönök mindent előre is!
story_txt:
Röviden, tömören:
 
Zilai János vagyok, a magyar amerikafutball-válogatott tagja. 19 éves koromra már 5 szezon rutint gyűjtöttem a felnőtt bajnokságból. 2016-ban összevágtam egy videót a legjobb megmozdulásaimról és elküldtem amerikai egyetemi edzőknek. Jónéhányan válaszoltak és a többség szerint megütöm az ottani szintet. Azt viszont nem tudják, hogy a mi bajnokságunk milyen színvonalat képvisel, így a további lépések előtt szeretnének a saját szemükkel is látni. A nyári táborokban lehetőségem nyílna megmutatni a korombeli amerikai fiúk ellen is, hogy felveszem a versenyt bárkivel. Rengeteg helyre hívtak, de hiába, mivel nincs pénzem elutazni. Az itt összejövő segítséget arra használnám fel, hogy kiutazzak és részt vegyek annyi ilyen egynapos táborban, amennyi csak belefér egy bő hét alatt.
 

A pontos terv:
Az a tervem, hogy kiutazok az USA keleti partjára valahová, ahová olcsó a repülőjegy, hiszen ott sűrűn vannak a csapatok. Elmegyek egy táborba, majd miután végeztem buszra pattanok és indulok a következőbe. Minden nap lesz új lehetőség. Az egyetemek tavasszal hozzák nyilvánosságra a pontos dátumokat, az alapján belövöm, hogy milyen útvonal lehetek a leghatékonyabb, hogy minél több hely beleférjen.
Nem akarok sokat költeni, így a szállásoláson is spórolni fogok. A fő cél, hogy összejöjjön annyi pénz, amennyi az utazásokat finanszírozza. Ha nem sikerül, akkor félreteszem, és egy évvel később újra nekifutok.
 

A hatás:
Ösztöndíjas sportolóként nem csak a világ legerősebb amatőr ligájában tudnék fejlődni, hanem szemeszterenként több ezer dollárt nyernék az amerikai futball miatti ingyenes oktatással.

Érkezés, távozás pedig a washingtoni reptérről. A nagyobb csapatok táboraiban (mint például a Virginia) kisebb egyetemek képviselői is nagy számban vannak jelen, így 5 helyszínen sem csak 5 csapatnak adnám elő magam.

A projekt hírének erjesztése nagyon sokat számít!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Lim Leanghorng. I am a teacher at Kent Ridge International School. I have been teaching privileged and underprivileged children and teenagers for three years. Every year is my great year but this year is the greatest year because I teach students who are like-minded. And they always seeks for/create opportunity to make positive change in their society. And this project is an example. 

While having privilege have access to great books and other source of knowledge, we, my students and I, feel uncomfortable to see other children having no way to get books to read not to mention about a comfortable reading environment because they believe that reading is a foundation of education and bright future. We are, therefore, running Books Light Future fundraising campaign to raise fund to create a library for 188 primary school students who are all energetic and enthusiastic readers yet have no means to access to books and comfortable reading space which is called LIBRARY.  

If you believe in the power of education, more specifically books, to change life, please make a contribution to our BOOK LIGHT FUTURE project.

Project Description 

Our vision statement

We work to create a library in which each and every child at Por Pei Krom Primary School can explore and fulfill his/her full potential through reading.

What we do

We do this through:

  • Creating a welcoming and inspiring reading space for students
  • Purchasing age- and level-appropriate books which are recognized by MOEYS
  • Involving teachers and school leaders in the project
  • Developing and designing reading programme for all students at the school
  • Engaging reading experience sharing between KIS students and students at the primary school so that they inspire each other to read.  

Our planned outcomes

The followings are the planned outcomes of the project:

  • A library will be created for students. The library will open for other students who are from nearby school to read as well.
  • Library hour will be added in school schedule at Por Pei Krom Primary School
  • Access to books will no longer a barrier for student-readers at Por Pei Krom Primary School
  • A regular reading experience sharing between KIS students and students at Por Pei Krom

Sustainability

The library will be managed by school leaders and a librarian.  Moreover, the fact that library hour will be added into students’ schedule truly encourages struggling readers to read because there will be a librarian and a teacher to help them in reading and choosing right books for them during library hour. Furthermore, the reading experience sharing session between KIS students and students at the primary school enables each of them to inspire each other to read. Once the library is functioned, the students will be encouraged to read and explore the world around through books. Once they are passionate reading and exploring new knowledge, they are more likely to successfully pursue their higher education, and hence they become independent and life-long learners. When these children grow up, they would be encouraged to support library and reading project for their wider community because they are all passionate readers.

What We Need & What You Get

We aim to raise 700$ to our project to buy 200 reading books and library materials such as bookshelves, tables and chairs. If we can get more budget, we will buy more books for the library. 

You will get a thank you email with the picture of library and children for any amount of donation. In addition, 

- Your name will be printed on 5 reading books for donation of 10$-20$ 

- Your name will be printed on the library wall for the donation of more than 20$

Money cannot buy knowledge, but it can buy books and create a library where readers can explore and obtain knowledge based on their interest and passion. 

Other Ways You Can Help

 Sharing our campaign to your friends on social media and forwarding it to people who might be interested in contributing in our project will be highly appreciated, and it is another way to support our project and make difference.

story:
With CRITI.CO we are creating a sustainability e-learning network. For the learners, CRITI.CO offers exciting, interactive and applicable online-courses addressing various aspects of sustainability. For individuals and organizations, CRITI.CO brings the possibility to share expertise and to generate an alternative income.

CRITI.CO is made for individuals, NGOs, entrepreneurs, students, architects, urbanists; it is for  creatives, scientists, for the curious, innovative and active citizens, who want to engage in a sustainable change in their own realities. The courses will combine theoretical input, interactive communication tools and - where applicable - hands-on assignments. The information is shared via diverse and engaging formats, such as video lectures, expert interviews, quizzes, discussions or podcasts. One course will cover a specific topic and usually last for 4-6 weeks with a workload of 2-6 hours per week.

Buy now our discounted vouchers for one or more of these and future courses!

You'll be asked after the campaign ends for which course you want to enrol.

We have even more courses coming up:

Natural Materials in Architecture - Redina Mazelli, Martina Bocci, Paolo Erriquez (Accademia Nel Cantiere)

Playful Cities Gamicipation - Karsten Michael Drohsel (STUDIO IN//stabil)

Context and Tools for Sustainable Practice - Stephanie E. Raible (Social Entrepreneurship Faculty)

Urban Grounded Practices - Miodrag Kuč (ZKU Berlin)

Building with Straw - Stefano Soldati (La Boa)

Regeneration Hackers - Giuseppe Scandone (QG Enviro)

Sustainable Cultural Heritage - Maro Magoula and Evangelia Pelentridou (Peripatos)

And more courses are coming addressing the social role of an architect, sustainable deconstruction, sustainable urban food production, permaculture, circular economy, bamboo construction, rammed earth techniques, green roof systems, participation with children...

 

Critical Concrete has been committed to alternative approaches to environmentally friendly architectural practices and a fair and inclusive city for 5 years now. The aim of our non-profit-organization is to collectively refurbish socially-relevant spaces through educational programmes, including summer school programmes, big workshops on real projects and small courses in our neighbourhood production centre.

We realized that our work and projects had a major impact on the people involved and initiated the critical rethinking of common processes and models. Without doubt, we will continue our local work, but the pandemic has shown us the potential of online formats as a necessary tool to promote alternative approaches to a large and interested community. To make relevant existing knowledge and practices easily and globally accessible, we decided to activate our network of individuals and small organizations working in the various fields of social and sustainable development and to set up our own online-learning platform - CRITI.CO was born.

Large online-learning platforms usually ask collaborating mentors for high partnership fees and do not offer any specialized support to set up the course. Following this, only institutions with the necessary resources can communicate their perspectives via those platforms. At CRITI.CO, we want to pursue a different approach. We intentionally want to gather aspiring individuals and organizations working in any field of sustainable practice to share their expertise. To not make the lack of time and money the reason this knowledge cannot be shared, we offer a fair revenue share of the courses’ income and actively support the developing, shooting, editing and promoting processes of each course. This way we want to create a resilient network of sustainable knowledge, which unites individual experiences into one large hub and make it easily accessible for everybody.

Exclusive course content, such as video lectures, interviews, podcasts and more, is hosted on our e-learning platform, Criti.co. Every course balances theoretical learning with practical assignments that will be unique to your surroundings. You can learn how to instigate a social project in your neighbourhood or analyse the earth properties on your doorstep. Each learner brings their own knowledge and experiences into an exchange with fellow learners. The platform creates a community of engaged co-learners who can discuss topics through forums and group assignments.

In live sessions you can actively engage with your tutors, benefitting from their expertise in the course and beyond. Each learner will also receive a certificate of achievement to kickstart their next steps in their chosen sustainable field. Importantly, we want Criti.co to be a community of like minded individuals supporting each other through peer reviews and collaboration.

story:
Elixir is an AI that forecasts the open, high, low, and close of the Nasdaq-100 (via QQQ). This campaign is to finance 1 month of morning-runs - which are same-day forecasts of the QQQ.

This campaign is primarily for a Morning Trading Group that was recruited in Twitter. But newcomers are welcome. Read more:

https://twitter.com/predictionmonk/status/11581...

Elixir has already performed over 1 year of public evening-runs (next-day forecasts) on social media. (See my Twitter page.)

 

And just who am I? My name is Gustavo and I post as @predictionmonk on Twitter.

Around 2014, I embarked on a project to build a narrow-AI (Artificial Intelligence) named Elixir.

The goal? To predict the Nasdaq-100, perhaps the most popular technology-heavy index in global finance.

Today, this goal is no longer a dream. For over 1 year, I have posted Elixir's performance on a freemium model: to dozens of my own clients in my Patreon page, and to about 40K followers on my Twitter page - see it below:

https://twitter.com/predictionmonk

 

And just how reliable is Elixir? Below is commentary by one of our earliest followers:

https://twitter.com/MoMoBagholder/status/115673...

And yet, Elixir has not applied her full potential - she can do same-day forecasts.

 

Currently, Elixir performs evening-runs for next-day forecasts. These process data up to market close (4pm ET) on a given day - and produces a fairly reliable forecast for the next day.

But morning-runs are more current. They absorb data up to market open (0930am ET), including overnight action - to deliver a *same-day* forecast.

 

What is the difference in performance?

Well, evening-runs have probabilities of success in the mid-50s to mid-70s (typically).

Morning-runs, on the other hand, have probabilities regularly in the mid-60s to upper-80s (erring on the conservative side).

 

Intrigued? I discuss more details in the FAQs below:

story:
Who We Are

We're a group of seven high school girls who are part of Destination Imagination, a creative problem solving program.  For the past two years, we have participated in the community service challenge. This entails picking a community need, however large or small it may be, and doing whatever you can to make a difference. This year we're teaming up with She's The First, and raising enough money to support a girl in India through four years of secondary school ($1,600 per year).  Education enables women to do powerful and great things and without this basic need, our world isn't complete.  Women make up half of the world's brainpower and we need to harness all of our creativity and knowledge in order to better the world. Your donation to our cause can help us make the world a better place- one girl at a time.  


Our Mission

Not only do we want to raise money, but also raise awareness. A lot of people, including ourselves, don't realize how lucky we are when it comes to receiving a quality education. This is an opportunity to not only help other girls, but to also learn about their culture. That is why, along with this campaign we will be organizing multiple fundraisers in 2015. These fundraisers include a movie night at our school, at which we will show a movie highlighting the necessity of a rise in girls education in developing countries. We are also planning a Holi Hai, or spring awakening, color festival, to bring the culture of India to our town and to help reach our goal of $6,500. All funds raised will go directly to the secondary education of a girl in India  at the Shanti Bhavan school, where they instill the idea that "a better world isn't just and idea, but a real possibility".  


About the Shanti Bhavan School

Shanti Bhavan is a school located in rural India. "[Their] mission is to adequately develop the most vulnerable and disadvantaged children of India’s “lowest caste” by providing them world class education and instilling globally shared values to enable them to aspire to careers and professions of their choice." 


Past Accomplishments

In 2012, we supported a woman in Tanzania who had been given the opportunity to receive an education from a program called AWEF (African Women's Education Fund), and become a teacher.  We raised over $800 which we sent to her in an effort to help provide school supplies for her classroom. We wanted to show that when women are given an education, they can do great things. In 2013, we worked with a program called "DIL" (Developments In Literacy). We raised around $1,200 to support 400 girls in Pakistan, and provide them with school supplies for a year.


Any donation small or large makes an impact. If you are unable to donate, helping to spread the word by sharing our campaign on Facebook, or passing it on to friends and family is a great way to take one small step and make a big difference.


Organizations:

She's The First- http://www.shesthefirst.org

Shanti Bhavan School- http://www.shantibhavanonline.org/our-mission/o...

African Women's Education Fund- https://www.facebook.com/pages/African-Womens-Education-Fund/472313262834378

Developments In Literacy- http://www.dil.org/


Social Media:

Twitter- https://twitter.com/oursmallstep

Instagram- http://instagram.com/oursmallstep

This is an opportunity to not only help other girls, but to also learn about their culture. That is why, along with this campaign we will be organizing multiple fundraisers in 2015. These fundraisers include a movie night at our school, at which we will show a movie highlighting the necessity of a rise in girls education in developing countries. We are also planning a Holi Hai, or spring awakening, color festival, to bring the culture of India to our town and to help reach our goal of $6,500. All funds raised will go directly to the secondary education of a girl in India  at the Shanti Bhavan school, where they instill the idea that "a better world isn't just and idea, but a real possibility".  About the Shanti Bhavan SchoolShanti Bhavan is a school located in rural India. "[Their] mission is to adequately develop the most vulnerable and disadvantaged children of India’s “lowest caste” by providing them world class education and instilling globally shared values to enable them to aspire to careers and professions of their choice." Past AccomplishmentsIn 2012, we supported a woman in Tanzania who had been given the opportunity to receive an education from a program called AWEF (African Women's Education Fund), and become a teacher.  We raised over $800 which we sent to her in an effort to help provide school supplies for her classroom. We wanted to show that when women are given an education, they can do great things. In 2013, we worked with a program called "DIL" (Developments In Literacy). We raised around $1,200 to support 400 girls in Pakistan, and provide them with school supplies for a year.Any donation small or large makes an impact. If you are unable to donate, helping to spread the word by sharing our campaign on Facebook, or passing it on to friends and family is a great way to take one small step and make a big difference.Organizations:She's The First- http://www.shesthefirst.orgShanti Bhavan School- http://www.shantibhavanonline.org/our-mission/o...African Women's Education Fund- https://www.facebook.com/pages/African-Womens-Education-Fund/472313262834378Developments In Literacy- http://www.dil.org/Social Media:Twitter- https://twitter.com/oursmallstepInstagram- http://instagram.com/oursmallstep

story:
Hi. We are three Middle School students in 7th grade. We are trying to raise money for our school so that our field trips are as affordable as they are fun and awesome. Our trips are not all outside of school. One of the things we are raising money for is our Drama Immersion Week where an amazing drama teacher comes in and we come up with plays that later we perform. We will also go to Kitt Peak, an observatory, to observe the stars through telescopes. Another one of our trips is High Ropes Course, where the Middle School practices and strengthens the community. If we tried to list all the mind-blowing activities we do, it would take up this whole page. All of the trips and special activities we do adds up to about 250 dollars per student.


           All of the money raised will go to our school to pay for these special trips. Without these fundraisers, the teachers and school would have to pay for everything out of their budget.  You can get involved even if you only donate 5 dollars (which, if you DO donate 5 dollars, you can get a container of 4 delicious cookies or 2 pictures of photography).  We are offering perks such as decorated headphones and earbuds, containers of cookies, and boxes of homemade greeting cards. Donate now!

story:
The Kindness Drive is a partnership between Nivea Castaneda along with her students in the Department of Communication Studies at the University of Denver and Colfax Community Network (CCN).  CCN is a 501(c)(3) non-profit community-based organization whose mission is to “advocate for and work on behalf of families and children residing in low-income transient housing (primarily residential motels) along Colfax Avenue. By providing information, services, and programs, we strengthen and improve family and community life.”

 

As part of a service-learning project, my Small Group Communication class and I have decided that knowledge without action is simply not enough. Therefore, we are committed to learning small group communication theories as well as applying our knowledge to advocate for children and families experiencing homelessness in Denver communities. 

To gain practical small group communication experience, students have been divided in four groups wherein each group is responsible for running a drive to collect necessary items for our community partner:

  • Brand new Underwear and socks (for any gender and age)
  • Non perishable food items
  • Diapers (for any age)
  • Toiletries (toothpaste, deodorant, shampoo, soap, etc).

 

Many of our friends, families, and allies live out of town and so we are providing a way for them (and others who find this easier than dropping off donations at the University of Denver) to contribute by donating monetarily. All proceeds will be used to buy items listed above.

 

We thank you for finding it in your hearts for your generous contribution and more importantly for being part of this experience with us! 

-Nivea Castaneda and Small Group Communication Class-

story:
What is CACTUS?

CACTUS is a non-profit Ukrainian NGO that promotes civil activism and responsibility among youths by providing them with the knowledge, tools and support necessary for making a positive social change. With almost 10 years of work behind our back, the NGO aims to expand a network of enthusiastic and motivated people ready to make their contribution to the development of Ukraine.

How does it work?

In addition to the year-round educational program, CACTUS holds an annual summer 10-day forum for 60 Ukrainian teenagers aged 13-18 coming from all over the country. Since we strive to help them identify the ways to contribute to their communities and give the tools needed for it, the CACTUS Forum has the following goals:

  • to develop communication and leadership skills. All the participants are to attend a Team Building session every day. In this way they study the best communication and coworking strategies as well as learn to identify and use their strengths so as to achieve the common team's goal in the long run;
  • to develop critical thinking and research skills. All the participants are to attend a Project Management session every day. Here the participants go over every single step of project creation: starting with identifying problems and their causes all the way up to budget and action plan; all the project ideas are then presented on the 10th day of the Forum;
  • to develop flexibility and creativity. Electives classes in Art (e.g. creative writing, photography) and Science (e.g. programming, model thinking) are provided in order to make it possible for the teenagers to think outside the box;
  • to bring up such topics as diversity, inclusion, and gender equality. CACTUS does not discriminate people on the grounds of sex, sexual orientation, race or ethnicity, physical abilities. That is why a Diversity Session - meetings with people ready to share their personal stories of dealing with the above mentioned issues - is held in order to promote diversity and inclusion;
  • to share volunteering, educational, and professional opportunities. CACTUS will invite speakers from such spheres as technology, media, human rights, education, and urban space, all of whom are eager to provide the participants with guidelines as to where they can seek development while still being school and university students;
  • to create a network of young leaders with a clear vision of possible changes in their communities; CACTUS provides a perfect environment for establishing valuable contacts with potential sponsors, mentors, and future team members for the community projects.

The biggest outcome of the CACTUS Forum will be the very first community service projects created and implemented by teenagers. With the participants coming from all over Ukraine, the estimated number of people affected by the projects will be as high as 1000.

CACTUS has been making changes in the Ukrainian community for almost 10 years. That is why holding the 10th anniversary Forum will be the direct proof of the impact it has done and a unique opportunity for at least 60 more Ukrainian youths to become leaders in their home communities.

Why do we do it?

We believe that even though it is impossible to tackle all the world issues at once, each of us can still think globally and act locally. CACTUS gives the necessary skills and tools to first analyze and then address the educational, ecological, and social issues Ukraine is facing today in the most effective way. 

When and where?

This year the CACTUS Forum will take place in the city of Ternopil (Western Ukraine) on July 20-29.

  1. July 17-19 - training for volunteers;
  2. July 20-29 - the Forum;
  3. July 28 - the 10th CACTUS Forum anniversary for the alumni of all the previous years;
  4. July 30 - evaluation of the Forum.

Why do we need funding?

CACTUS is growing bigger every year, expanding its staff team and developing a better teaching quality. The NGO has been functioning for 9 years thanks to small grants, in-kind donations, and local fundraising, being supported by people who are truly dedicated to the CACTUS mission - making a change. However, the funds the NGO possesses right now are not enough to hold the 10th anniversary Forum and implement the whole Forum curriculum.

That is why CACTUS needs additional funding for:

  • accommodation. 

60 participants - $4/day - $40/10 days - $2,400 in total;

25 staff members (Ukrainian and international volunteers/trainers) - $4/day - $40/10 days - $1,000 in total;

20 guest speakers - $4/day - $80 in total.

  • meals.

​60 participants - $5/day - $50/10 days - $3,000 in total;

25 staff members (Ukrainian and international volunteers/trainers) - $5/day - $50/10 days - $1,250 in total;

20 guest speakers - $5/day - $100 in total.

  • other expenditures (e.g. transport, venue rental, media equipment, stationery, printouts).

All the costs add up to $8,000. However, we set a goal of $7,000 since we will cover the remaining $1,000 with the help of local fundraising and our partner organizations that can provide partial monetary (Rotary Club) and material (Morshinska, local IT companies) support.

​Where will the funds go if we don't reach our entire goal? CACTUS will fundraise the remaining sum locally (e.g. contacting local partner organizations and sponsors, organizing charitable events, selling CACTUS merchandise) and will use all the available funds (from the Indiegogo donations and local fundraising) for the Forum expenditures. 

What can you get for contributing to CACTUS?

We appreciate your contribution to CACTUS, and that is why besides successful community projects implemented by our participants, we offer the following items that help us promote CACTUS both directly and indirectly:

  • report on the funds use for all backers;
  • CACTUS stickers for $10+ contribution;
  • CACTUS bag for $25+ contribution;
  • CACTUS notebook for $50+ contribution;
  • CACTUS T-shirt for $100+ contribution;
  • CACTUS sweatshirt for $300+ contribution.

What about challenges?

It is not easy to bring together 60 teenagers in summer and encourage them to work, but it is even harder to ensure the sustainability and lasting impact of the Forum after the event itself. That is why in order to make these 10 days count, a mentor is assigned to each project group according to the topic at hand. A mentor is not only a teacher, but also a wise friend who supports the participants during the whole period of project implementation. In this way we can keep in touch with all the Forum participants when they go home, giving them constructive feedback and making sure they are working on their projects.

Why is it important?

CACTUS is all about people and growth. Over the 10 days spent at the Forum the teenagers discover new facets of their personality as well as numerous issues relevant for Ukraine and the world, such as environment, inclusion, education, and human rights. Getting up-to-date information about these topics, participants go on to address them in their projects. Moreover, by the end of the Forum they have complete profiles of their projects: goals and objectives, budget, action and sustainability plans. Once the Forum is over, there is but one step left - make the project a reality.

CACTUS brings not the destination but the starting point to the lives of the people engaged. Not only do the participants become leaders in their communities, but they also enter leading Ukrainian and international universities, build successful careers and keep on supporting CACTUS. 

Thus, over the 9 years of CACTUS work

  • 11,000 people have participated in CACTUS activities;
  • 130 community projects have been implemented;
  • 600 volunteers have contributed to CACTUS (among them volunteers from 5 continents);
  • 1,009 teenagers benefited from CACTUS in 2017.

 

Some examples of successful projects?

 

!НАВАЖСЯ! 

(literally: !I DARE YOU!)

One of a number of projects successfully implemented by the participants of the CACTUS Forum 2017 is "!НАВАЖСЯ!" (literally: "!I DARE YOU!"). Olena Kyslovska (16 y.o.) and Polina Chesnokova (14 y.o.) tackled the topic of inclusion in Ukraine. The girls worked with a group of students from a specialized school for children with special needs in Kyiv for 2 months. Over this time Olena and Polina have held 6 seminars, 2 workshops, 1 social event and 1 meeting with a guest speaker from the field. The girls covered such topics as leadership, team work, dealing with fear and anxiety, educational opportunities, and, most importantly, showed the children with special needs that the Ukrainian society is inclusion-friendly and there are a lot of opportunities for them to get involved! 

Olena and Polina have won a Diamond Challenge for High School Entrepreneurs award and are planning to expand their project.

The project FB page: https://www.facebook.com/navazhsya/

Un-Bottom Waste Bin

Kateryna Malkina (16 y.o.) from Mariupol has created an ecological project dealing with an innovative way of plastic utilization by one of larvae species. Her project consists of 2 directions: scientific and social. Kateryna is working on the project in her school lab, examining the behavior of larvae in different environments over a specific period of time. She has also held a meeting with students at one of local schools where she spoke about her project as well as about the environmental challenges and our role in them in the context of Ukraine and the world. 

Kateryna has won a number of scientific contests in such countries as Ukraine, the Netherlands, the USA, Brazil, presenting her project on the international level.

Have we missed anything?

The only thing CACTUS lacks right now is YOUR contribution. Think about it - you can skip having a cup of coffee today and cover a $5-meal for one CACTUS participant!

Are there other ways to help?

There are for sure. You can:

  • apply for a CACTUS trainer's position and join the international staff members team for the CACTUS Forum 2018;
  • share the CACTUS campaign via social media and encourage your friends to support us;
  • let us know about organizations interested in this kind of projects.

Still have some questions?

Contact and find out more about CACTUS at:

http://www.cactus.ngo/

https://www.facebook.com/cactusua/

https://www.instagram.com/cactus.ua

https://www.youtube.com/cactusua

https://t.me/cactusua

https://issuu.com/cactusua/docs/cactus_annual_r...

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

We did it! Thanks to your inspiring generosity, we're going to make the dream of college come true for these brave, ambitious Afghan girls! 
Thank you for believing in them, and in us. We're so excited to break ground on the school, and documentary filmmaker Beth Murphy will be there to film it. 
Now, we're excited to announce a STRETCH GOAL! 

While the campaign to raise enough money to build and launch the college itself has ended, we hope that -- with the momentum of this success -- we can raise enough for one critically important addition to the school: a computer lab. 
Access to technology is so important for these young women -- they need it to develop essential skills that will help them get jobs, build careers and connect with the world. 
With another $25,000 (for a total of $140,000), we can buy and install 20 new computers, 2 printers, and all the necessary desks and chairs.  
Share the campaign after you've contributed. Let people know how you are making a difference today!


Transform the Lives of Afghan Girls

We are Principle Pictures, and we learned about the need for this college while filming the feature documentary “What Tomorrow Brings” (in post-production). The film tells the story of the very first girls’ K-12 school in Deh’Subz, Afghanistan, founded by the visionary Afghan American educator (and Rotarian) Razia Jan and her foundation, Razia's Ray of Hope.

Already, the girls in this community are experiencing enormous success in grades K-12. Since we began filming in 2009, we’ve witnessed the remarkable changes made possible by education .

- Illiterate fathers who were leery about sending their daughters into the classroom now express pride that their little girls can help them read letters—even in English. 

- The leading men in the community—the village elders—who once refused to look Razia in the eyes, now praise her efforts and support the school’s growth.


- Girls who once were silent about forced engagements and early marriages are now speaking up and finding ways to negotiate more time in school.

Just imagine what would be possible with a college education, a job and an income!

Razia wants to build on the incredible success of the high school she founded by creating the first college for rural girls in Afghanistan. The funds from this campaign will go directly to Razia's foundation to build the school. 

This project solves a seemingly intractable problem in Afghanistan - the lack of higher education opportunities available to girls in rural communities. And it does it in a way that makes sense for Afghanistan. This is not a western answer to an Afghan problem. It is an Afghan answer to an Afghan problem.

How Do We Know It Can Be Done?


Because Razia has already done it! The K-12 school she opened in 2008 has an attendance rate of 93%, a retention rate of 96%, and has dramatically increased enrollment year after year (today serving more than 480 students).

And Razia has won the support of the men the community, who help ensure that the school is protected.

By the Afghan Ministry of Education’s metrics for administration, curricula, and facilities, the school is the top private school in the district. A representative from the Ministry is on record describing the school as “perfect.”


Here's What the School Will Do:

Students will graduate in two years with marketable, much-needed skills and the ability to work in schools, businesses, government, and health care—careers that are compatible with being a married, observant Afghan woman.

The new facility will include a medical clinic where midwifery students will train alongside doctors and midwives. This medical facility will have an enormous impact on a severely medically underserved area with no district hospital.

Exactly What Would Your Dollars Provide?

When you back this project, you be paying for the purchase of the property, construction of the school, recruiting the teachers, buying the desks, and ultimately, for making a college education possible for the girls in this village. You are funding the future of Afghan women.

Just $115,000 makes that possible! Should we exceed our goal, things get even more exciting. 

More than 75% of the girls in this village live below the poverty line as defined by the United Nations (subsisting on less than $1US per day), and our goal is to support them and make their dream of education a reality.

Spread the Word!

Even if you can’t contribute financially, you can make a big impact. Spreading the word to your friends and family makes you a light in these girls’ lives.

Thank you!

story:
What We Need & What You Get

We need $100,000 to pay for constitutional scholars, economists and advisory council members to organize and participate in a speaking tour in 10 key states to debate opponents and educate policy makers, academics and the grassroots about the Compact for America initiative. All donations would be made to Compact for America, Inc., which is a 501(c)(4) non-profit charity.

Reason for Campaign

The average taxpayer owes $150,000 of the nearly $18 trillion national debt. The federal government's unlimited borrowing capacity has enabled politicians to buy votes with unsustainable federal programs, which have been recently estimated at over $205 trillion, putting the average taxpayer on the hook for more than $1.5 million in future taxes.

This is an impossible situation arising from a systemic problem-the ability to shift the costs of our political choices to future generations, which is enabled by the federal government's unlimited borrowing capacity.

A systemic crash is the only result of this systemic problem unless we act now and quickly. That's why Compact for America was organized.

Compact for America is marshaling what George Will has called an "innovative" effort to advance and ratify a powerful federal Balanced Budget Amendment from the states in as few as twelve months, with a target date of July 4, 2017, and a "do or die" date of April 12, 2021. The initiative involves educating policy makers, academia and the grassroots about the need to have 36 more states join, and simple majorities of Congress approve, the "Compact for a Balanced Budget"-a formal agreement that already exists between Georgia and Alaska to use the authority conferred on the states to amend the U.S. Constitution under its "Article V" provision.

The Compact for America effort has been endorsed by opinion leader George Will, judicial analyst and scholar Judge Andrew Napolitano, Fifth Circuit U.S. Court of Appeals senior judge Harold DeMoss, national radio personality Mike Church, senior fellow in constitutional studies and editor-in-chief of the Cato Supreme Court Review Ilya Shapiro of the Cato Institute and Dr. Kevin Gutzman, author of New York Times Best Seller James Madison and the Making of America.

Spearheaded by the work of constitutional scholar and litigator Nick Dranias, the Goldwater Institute, Heartland Institute, MacIver Institute, Pelican Institute, Georgia Public Policy Foundation and Alaska Policy Forum have been leading the education effort among nationally-known think tanks.

Most recently, the Federalist Society's prestigious "Engage" law journal published Dranias' legal analysis of the Compact for a Balanced Budget.

Every dollar counts. Educating your fellow citizens about the Compact for a Balanced Budget and persuading 36 more states and simple majorities of Congress  to join it will require millions of dollars to succeed-and save trillions of dollars for our kids when it does

Risks & Challenges

The Compact for America initiative is a huge and heavy lift, which will likely require both educational and lobbying resources in the millions of dollars. But with success in two states already, and sustained polling data showing the American people want to fix the national debt, it is a lift worth shouldering. What is the alternative?

This campaign is a small but important component of an overall strategic plan leveraging affiliated and allied entities across the country. The team leading and managing the Compact for America effort is unmatched by any other policy group.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you do not have the capacity to donate to this effort, or if you want to help beyond a donation, please join us at a huge "Liberty Amendment" symposium and dinner hosted by CFA and States United for a Balanced Budget at the Tucson Hilton El Conquistador on October 18!

You can also get involved in the effort by learning more, contacting your congressmen and state legislators, and getting your Compact for America gear.

Every dollar counts. Educating your fellow citizens about the Compact for a Balanced Budget and persuading 36 more states and simple majorities of Congress  to join it will require millions of dollars to succeed-and save trillions of dollars for our kids when it does


Risks & Challenges

  The Compact for America initiative is a huge and heavy lift, which will likely require both educational and lobbying resources in the millions of dollars. But with success in two states already, and sustained polling data showing the American people want to fix the national debt, it is a lift worth shouldering. What is the alternative?
This campaign is a small but important component of an overall strategic plan leveraging affiliated and allied entities across the country. The team leading and managing the Compact for America effort is unmatched by any other policy group.
  Other Ways You Can Help If you do not have the capacity to donate to this effort, or if you want to help beyond a donation, please join us at a huge "Liberty Amendment" symposium and dinner hosted by CFA and States United for a Balanced Budget at the Tucson Hilton El Conquistador on October 18!

You can also get involved in the effort by learning more, contacting your congressmen and state legislators, and getting your Compact for America gear.

story:
School officials are working hard to make sure children have a safe place to learn, but they need your help.

We are concerned parents who are starting a nonprofit organization to improve school security nationwide through advocacy, education, and the application of technology.

We are building a free public website where students, parents and school officials can learn and discuss ideas on how to make schools safer. 

As an organization, we are building better ways for students, parents and concerned citizens to report incidents to school officials.  We are also developing easier ways for schools to do security assessments and audits. 

The really cool thing about all this is that we are finding lots of people willing to volunteer their time.

With your help, we can give these volunteers a place to work, and a way to bring these important tools to the over 98,000 public schools that teach and protect our over 49,800,000 children. 

What We Need 

At this stage of our development, a big portion of the work we need is development of our website www.SchoolDangers.Org and the tools we want to get in the hands of students, parents and schools.  We can get most of this heavy lifting done by hosting a series of “Code for Good” Hackathon events.

Code for Good, works to solve social problems through software (JUST LIKE US!). Typically these are hackathon-type events, where developers, designers, and subject matter experts gather together for a day or two (or more) to focus on creating a software-based solution to a social problem.

While most of the work is done by volunteers, we estimate each event will cost around $5000  (We need to feed and water them and give them a place to collaborate!). 

If we raise: We can host a Code for Good event to:
$5,000 Build a professional website and newsletter to teach about School Safety and Security Issues.
$10,000 Extend the website so everyone can collaborate. (Public and Private Forums, white paper submissions, etc)
$15,000 Finish the first release of an affordable incident reporting system we have been working on so all schools can communicate better with students and parents. (We already started work on this!)
$20,000 Create an online school assessment and audit system to make it easier for schools to meet state requirements. Each state is different, so this is the engine that we will tweak on a state by state basis.
Over $20,000 Every state has different school safety and security laws. We estimate it is going to take $80,000 to hire the legal experts and consultants to research all these laws and develop a comprehensive state report card system.
Over $100,000 Anything over $100,000 will be used to further the organization's program and marketing to get the message out about these new resources!

story:
Hi!  My name is Anna and I am a teacher at Carver Prep, a charter school in New Orleans that educates students from traditionally underserved neighborhoods and communities. We opened in the fall of 2012 with a single ninth grade class, and currently serve a student body of 9th-11th grade students. Our scholars are 99% minorities, 93% free/reduced lunch, and nearly 20% special education students. 

In response to a huge rise in the number of native Spanish speaking students at our school, we urgently need to increase the number of Spanish speaking teachers at Carver Prep.  This project will send 6 of our teachers--representing a range of grade levels and content areas-- to Spanish language school in Honduras over winter break, with the ultimate goal of increasing both the cultural and language expertise of our teachers and ensuring that they are in the best position to prepare all of our students for college success. 

In the fall of 2014, our population of English Language Learner students significantly increased--reflecting a city-wide trend in a growing Spanish Language population, primarily from Honduras. While we served just 10 Spanish speaking students in 2013-2014, our population of scholars with limited English knowledge has grown to 53 in the 2014-2015 school year--an increase of over 500%.


School

2013

2014

Number

Percent of enrollment

Number

Percent of enrollment

G.W. Carver Prep

10

10%

53

20%

You can read more about it here:  http://www.nola.com/education/index.ssf/2014/08/central_american_immigrants_po.html

You can read a story featuring one of our ninth grade scholars here:

http://www.npr.org/2014/09/11/347392083/child-migrants-settle-uneasily-in-the-big-easy

You can listen to an NPR story that recently aired about Carver Prep's ELL population here:

http://www.npr.org/blogs/ed/2014/10/02/35143837...

As a direct result of this program, we will aim to reach the following goals as a school:

  • 75% four-year graduation rate school-wide; 95% five-year graduation rate.
  • An average of 2 years of reading growth for Spanish speaking scholars.

All 6 teachers who participate in Spanish Language School emerge as intermediate Spanish speakers at the conclusion of the program. 

You can read more about the school we plan on attending here:

http://ixbalanque.com/


Risks & Challenges

Learning a new language takes time and practice.  We are committed to using this opportunity to increase not only our language skills but our cultural knowledge of Latin America as well.  This will help us better connect to our scholars, promote awareness and understanding across our school, and ensure high quality educational outcomes for every student we serve.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are unable to contribute, please consider sharing our campaign with others who may be interested.  Thank you for taking the time to learn about this exciting shift in our school’s demographics and the work of our teachers to prepare all students for college!

story:
THE GOLDEN DOME!

www.golden-dome.org

Hi! And welcome to The Golden Dome Fundraiser!

WHO ARE WE?

The Golden Dome is a nomadic school dedicated to investigating intentional living and art making as it relates to cultivating ideas for sustaining and optimizing life on Earth. Each school session varies in theme while consistently centering around the study of the spiritual dimensions within the natural sciences and the expansion of these insights into physical art practice.

Our first program, "Performing the Fool's Planetary Rites", will take place at the end of July 2014 at a sustainable land art project in West Marin, CA. The program is dedicated to the study of the Tarot and it's relationship to performance. We will be enacting an initiation toward higher consciousness by performing the Fool's Journey through the Major Arcana. This program is organized by long time collaborators (tarot counselors, artists, musicians) Eliza Swann and Laura Zuspan. You can read more about us HERE. 

How does the Tarot bridge the gap between healing, art, and performance? How can our art contribute to cultural and psychic hygiene for the benefit of our planet? How can environment be investigated through the practice of art making in such a way that these questions cannot only be asked, but be lived as well?

The School!

Read about it HERE!

The 'School For Performing the Fool's Planetary Rites' takes place on a sustainable land art project that consists of a long house, a cabin, a stage, an outdoor shower, and a compostable toilet. Our two-week session there consists of workshops, collaborative art exercises, visits to performance and meditation centers, hikes, and lectures offered by visiting artists, curators, witches, and tarot practitioners. The session will culminate in a group performance at the "First Friday" art event in Oakland, CA on August 1st.

In the interest of making our school as accessible as possible we are charging only our base operation costs for meals, accommodation, and transportation for our participants - our staff is currently unpaid. The Golden Dome is seeking to raise funds to pay visiting faculty, and to offer scholarships to community members who can not afford to participate otherwise. Help us free the Dome!

Other Ways You Can Help!

Spread the word about the Golden Dome! 

Donate ice for our coolers! Drinking water! Lanterns! Quartz crystals! Trail Mix! Bells! Ribbons! Statues of Hindu Deities! Food for our pantry! Candles! Flutes! Tambourines! Lapis Lazuli! Bird Seed! Lend us camping gear!

story:
The Western Railway Preservation Society is a 501c3 non-profit organization located in Eastern Oregon. The society is actively restoring former Westside Lumber Co. caboose number 3 at our shop in McEwen, Oregon. To date we have raised $1,500.00 in donations towards the rebuild of this iconic piece of logging history. The total anticipated cost to restore the caboose to its as built appearance is approximately $4,000.00. We are in need of an additional $2.500.00 to purchase siding and other materials. Any funds raised will be utilized exclusively in the rebuild of this caboose. Using all volunteer labor the frame and undercarriage has been painstakingly rebuilt and is essentially complete. However, there is still a large amount of work required before this car can be restored to its former glory. Unlike so many other restoration projects, the caboose will be used for public education and enjoyment through regular display and operation on the Sumpter Valley Railroad.

All donations to the Western Railway Preservation Society are tax deductible.

story:
We Have Launched a Second Campaign to Save Cooper Union. View our new campaign here: http://igg.me/p/929623

Please note that any donations past the Phase 1 $150,000 goal will automatically be applied to Phase 2 of our fundraising (see below).

About The Legal Action

The Committee to Save Cooper Union is pursuing legal action as a last resort after Cooper Union’s Board of Trustees and administration proceeded with their plans to abolish a 150 year tradition of free tuition enshrined in the Charter of the school, refusing alternatives that would preserve free tuition.

A Working Group of faculty, students and alumni elected by their respective constituencies had developed a sustainable plan for preserving free tuition that was supported by the Faculty Union, the alumni association and students. The President and Board refused to accept this plan and chose to press on with their plan to charge tuition.


After carefully evaluating all of the legal options for both legal and cost-effectiveness, the Committee to Save Cooper Union decided that the best approach is to seek an injunction against charging tuition in New York Supreme Court. This option also allows us to petition the court for formation of “The Associates of Cooper Union” as required by the Cooper Union charter. The Associates would serve as a check on the Board of Trustees since the Associates' elected Council can remove Trustees by majority vote. This route also allows us to petition the court for an audit, as provided for in the charter, to help provide more detail on the fiscal mismanagement happening at Cooper Union.

The New Academic Building

One especially noteworthy fiscal issue is the Board and administration deciding to build an extravagant new academic building costing over $165 million before raising adequate funds for it. In addition, the Board and administration appear to have severely undervalued the Chrysler building when they renegotiated the lease with Tishman Speyer. There are also more recent examples of fiscal waste including spending $50,000 on celebrity speaker Fareed Zakaria, spending a total of $350,000 for Jamshed Bharucha’s inauguration celebration, excessive spending on private security, and spending about $1.5 million on consultants for supporting President Bharucha’s program of “reinvention” for Cooper Union.

Lack of fiscal discipline on the part of the Board is also demonstrated by their lack of follow-through on their Master Plan commitment to reduce operating expenses by 10% by 2011. This commitment to reduce operating expenses was also explicitly stated in the Board’s 2006 sworn cy pres petition to the New York Supreme Court filed in order to allow the Board to borrow against the Chrysler building revenue. Instead of being reduced, expenses steadily rose from $43.7 million in 2006 to $66.8 million in 2010 (if debt service and depreciation are excluded, the rise was from $39.4m to $49.8m.) Unlike the Board’s fiscal recklessness, the Working Group plan embodies the creative fiscal discipline that enabled Cooper Union to survive as a free tuition institution for over 150 years.

Funding goals

We are raising funds to defray the costs of a legal effort to prevent the destruction of a 150 year tradition of free tuition, require an audit and require the formation of the Associates of Cooper Union as a supervisory body. Thanks to the generous support of a number of donors we are able to bring this lawsuit, but raising additional funds will increase our chances of success. This fundraising will be split into a number of phases.

Phase 1: 45 Day Timeframe

This will help defray the initial costs of bringing the legal proceedings, including legal costs, filing fees, expert witnesses and public relations assistance.
Total needed to raise for Phase 1: $150,000

Phase 2: Approximately 45-90 Day Timeframe

Further legal proceedings may involve hearings, depositions, discovery and other legal costs.
Total needed to raise for Phase 2: $200,000

Additional phases could involve appellate work or other legal actions (such as petitioning the Board of Regents) to be determined by how the case unfolds.

As an Article 77 action, our attorney’s fees are potentially recoverable depending on the outcome, which could help defray our attorney’s fees but is not guaranteed.

If our goal of preserving a free tuition Cooper Union is achieved, any remaining funds will be donated back to Cooper Union. If the goal is not achieved, any remaining funds will be donated to some other worthy educational cause.

Notes on tax deductibility:

Committee to Save Cooper Union is a non-profit corporation and we expect to get 501c3 status for tax deductibility, in which case we could grant retroactive tax deductions. However, it could take months and we can't  guarantee it because in this area the IRS can sometimes be unpredictable. If you would be interested in making a contribution and potentially claiming a deduction retroactively, contact us (via www.savecooperunion.org ) and we can put you on a list for notification when our 501c3 application gets processed.

Notes on perks:

Poster size will be approximately 11" x 17"
Autographed print size will be approximately 12" x 18"
For T-shirts, we will inquire about preferred T-shirt sizes after the conclusion of the campaign.
Perk delivery expected to be within 4 weeks of conclusion of campaign (except for Ivory Tower DVD which will depend upon DVD release date).

story:
Dear Friends,

Warm greetings from Ukraine. My name is Svitlana Shchudlo. I am a Professior of Sociology at Ivan Franko Pedagogical University in Drohobych, Lviv region, Ukraine http://kpspddpu.ucoz.ua/index/shhudlo_s_a/0-22. I am asking you for help. I need to fundraise 500 EUR which will alllow me to go to the largest European Educational Research conference taking place in Budapest on September 7-11 this year. At the confernce I will be presenting a study ‘Pedagogy after Maidan’, which I have jointly conducted with my colleague from Cambridge University, Olena Fimyar.

  • Conference submission ID: 1620
  • Network 28. Sociologies of Education
  • Format of Presentation: Paper
  • Keywords: pedagogy, power dynamics, democratisation, Ukraine
  • Title: Pedagogy after Maidan: A regional case study of changing power dynamics between students and teachers in Lviv region, Ukraine
  • Authors: Svitlana Schudlo (Ivan Franko State Pedagogical University, Drohobych, Ukraine), Olena Fimyar (University of Cambridge, UK)

Ukraine is rarely represented in international research conferences. It is expensive for participants from Ukraine to go when travel and attendance cost equals your monthly salary. Despite this real hardship our country is making the first but very determined steps toward the integration into the European research space.  The events which unfolded in Ukraine last year affected all aspects of our lives. They did not leave anyone indiferent, either you are leaving in Ukraine or abroad. It is so important now to document people’s refelctions on the major event of the modern Ukrainian history.

In the ‘Pedagogy afer Maidan’ project we are looking at how the events in post-Maidan Ukraine have affected the teaching and communicaiton style in Ukrainian schools. The project gives voice to teachers and students and presents their reflection on the event that continues to shape their destinies. This project is not our only initiative. Together with my Ukrainian colleagues, Olena Fimyar and Iryna Kushnir, we are currently negotiating with the EERA council Ukraine’s candidate membership in this largest European Educational Research Association. We have a vision for development of education research in Ukraine. We are showing the inititive. We are building the links. Your support however small will help us achieve our goals sooner. Please consider cotrubuting towards the cause.

The budget I need to secure is:

  • Travel: 200 Eur [train Lviv-Budapest-Lviv]
  • Accommodation: 135 Eur
  • Conference fees: 165 Eur
  • Total: 500 Eur (approx 547 USD)

If you are interested in contributing to the project in any other form or getting involved with drafting documents needed to apply for Ukraine’s candidate membership at EERA, please do not hesitate to contact me or my colleagues.

Thank you for your time, thank you for your support and I look forward to seeing you in Budapest and welcoming you to Drohobych.

Sincerely and diakuyu,

Svitlana

 Format of Presentation: Paper
 Keywords: pedagogy, power dynamics, democratisation, Ukraine 

 Title: Pedagogy after Maidan: A regional case study of changing power 
dynamics between students and teachers in Lviv region, Ukraine
 
Authors: Svitlana Schudlo (Ivan Franko State Pedagogical University, 
Drohobych, Ukraine), Olena Fimyar (University of Cambridge, UK) 




Ukraine is rarely
represented in international research conferences. It is expensive for
participants from Ukraine to go when travel and attendance cost equals your monthly
salary. Despite this real hardship our country is making the first but very determined
steps toward the integration into the European research space.  The events which unfolded in Ukraine last
year affected all aspects of our lives. They did not leave anyone indiferent,
either you are leaving in Ukraine or abroad. It is so important now to document
people’s refelctions on the major event of the modern Ukrainian history. 
In the ‘Pedagogy afer
Maidan’ project we are looking at how the events in post-Maidan Ukraine have affected
the teaching and communicaiton style in Ukrainian schools. The project gives
voice to teachers and students and presents their reflection on the event that
continues to shape their destinies. This project is not our only initiative. Together
with my Ukrainian colleagues, Olena Fimyar and Iryna Kushnir, we are currently
negotiating with the EERA council Ukraine’s candidate membership in this
largest European Educational Research Association. We have a vision for
development of education research in Ukraine. We are showing the inititive. We
are building the links. Your support however small will help us achieve our goals
sooner. Please consider cotrubuting towards the cause. 
The budget I need to secure is: 


 Travel: 200 Eur [train Lviv-Budapest-Lviv]

 Accommodation: 135 Eur

 Conference fees: 165 Eur


 Total: 500 Eur (approx 547 USD)




If you are interested in
contributing to the project in any other form or getting involved with drafting documents needed
to apply for Ukraine’s candidate membership at EERA, please do not hesitate to contact
me or my colleagues. 
Thank you for your time,
thank you for your support and I look forward to seeing you in Budapest and
welcoming you to Drohobych. 
Sincerely and diakuyu, 
Svitlana

story:
Our Story

My name is Sabita Deshemaru. I am 32 years old, now living in Israel with my husband who is doing his residency in Hadassah Medical Organization Jerusalem. I was born in the city of Bhaktapur, located in the Kathmandu Valley in Nepal. 

There was a massive earthquake in Nepal damaging many parts of the country and specially in Kathamndu, Patan and Bhaktapur. Bhaktapur has faced large causality from the earthquake. From latest update, about 50% of old houses have been collapsed only in Bhaktapur. Hundreds of people died and thousands are injured. Nepal government has announced for international help/support. This is my personal effort to help people in need. We need your help to provide food, drinking water and medical assistance for those who have saved. There is much to help but less time we have. With god's will and god's help, we can feed and provide drinking water to them.

Our Goal

Therefore, we want to raise money for supplying food and drinking water. 

We are hoping to raise $30,000, which will cover food, water and tents for 100 people for a month. 

As needs are changing over time, it will be most effective to decide the beneficiary of the funds once the 30 days is finished. But to make it clear, we will choose the most affected community in Bhaktapur and will provide our relief in ground.

How You Can Help

Any amount you can contribute will be helpful, but even if you can’t donate, you can help us spread the word by sharing this site on Facebook and Twitter and emailing your family and friends.  The more people who know about this effort, the better chance we have of helping people in need in Kathmandu Nepal.

For more information or questions, please contact sabita.deshu@hotmail.com

Thank you so much for your support!

Sabita Deshemaru

story:
I have been an avid reader and writer since childhood.  Because of my parents' devotion to education, I was reading with ease by the time I entered Kindergarten (special thanks to my mother).

With the encouragement and support of my elementary school librarian, Ms. Feldshuh, I created my first pop-up, children's book entitled The Dog and the Mouse after a lesson on Aesop's Fables.  For this effort, I earned and received an Ezra Jack Keats award (see bronze coin I am holding in the photo of my mother and I).   Around the same time, Ms. Feldshuh suggested I write a letter to then-First Lady Barbara Bush about "How I cannot bear to be without books."  Imagine the look on my face when I received a response from Mrs. Bush on official White House stationary!

My love of literature never faded. Throughout my four years at Norman Thomas High School, I excelled in my English classes (particularly, Advanced Placement English) and passed the English Regents examination with flying colors -- special shout to Ms. Strudler, Ms. Peiser, Ms. Guido, and Mr. Ravage.  

As an undergraduate student at Lehman College, in pursuit of a bachelor's degree in English Literature, I tutored peers in writing (among other subjects) through the campus' SEEK Program and was a proud member of the Honors English Program.  I had amazing professors at Lehman College and was fortunate to have been taught by excellent faculty (especially those in the English Department) -- Dr. Grace Bullaro, Virginia Scott (may she rest in peace), Eve Zarin, Walter Blanco, Margot Mifflin, Sondra Perl, and Gerhard Joseph.  It was during this distinct period, my own coming of age, that I discovered and fell in love with Latino Literature.  As a result, my thesis for the Honors English program examined three literary works by Esmeralda Santiago, Julia Alvarez, and Christina García that discussed issues of acculturation and Americanization following migration from the Caribbean.  

As a young adult, I continued journaling and sharing personal experiences with a close circuit of friends.  These intimate experiences and interactions, coupled with all that I overcame in my youth, shaped my character and moral compass.  Sadly, through dark periods of depression in my 20s and early 30s, I often lost my identity and voice.  A regimen of exercise, therapy, and writing saved me when I needed it most and helped me regain confidence in my abilities.    

Fast forward to Spring 2012, as a participant in the National Hispana Leadership Institute's Advancing Latina Leaders in Non-Profits program, I approached Dra. Angélica Pérez-Litwin after a session she facilitated for my cohort and shared that I wanted to pursue writing but didn't have time…she stopped me in my tracks and boldly said: "That's an excuse…"  I don't quite remember the words that followed because I was taken aback by her directness and tone.  Don't get me wrong, I wasn't offended.  In fact, I appreciated her candor and took it to heart.  I decided to take her up on the challenge and resumed writing.  About a year later, Dra. Pérez-Litwin published my essay Confronting the Harsh Reality of Mental Illness on NewLatina.net, a progressive digital media platform she founded for "today’s Latina who wants more out of life."  The following year, Dr. Pérez-Litwin again empowered me by featuring another essay of mine entitled Shedding Depression to Vivir Mi Vida on her platform.  

My interaction with Dra. Pérez-Litwin and her indirect mentorship, as well as connection with fearless bloggers and writers through the Latina Leadership Network, inspired me to launch an "anonymous" blog (see www.caciqueinme.wordpress.com) in October 2013.  Although it thrived for five precious, short months, I decided to pause writing for a number of reasons…and refocus my purpose...as well as establish writing goals.  During this period, I submitted a piece entitled Preparando para las Navidades en la Casa de Abuela as a special contributor to LaRespuesta Media, a provocative online media community cultivating points of connection among all Boricua people as well as honoring and recognizing the distinctiveness of the Puerto Rican Diaspora.  In early 2014, I attended a pre-cursor seminar to the Writing Our Lives workshop with Vanessa Mártir at Hunter College and later shared my deeply personal and painful story with LaRespuesta Media about seeing the light in life after a suicide attempt through a piece entitled Light and Love After Darkness.

Additionally, I attended the Las Comadres Writers Conference at CUNY-Medgar Evers College in my native hometown of Brooklyn, NY, in the Fall of 2013 and again in Fall 2014 as well as completed a brief memoir-writing workshop at The Writer's Center in Bethesda, MD, shortly thereafter.  My writing has garnered mix reviews…stemming from "God bless you" to "Why do you have to write about our family?" to "I never knew you were in so much pain."  To me, writing is cathartic.  It allows me to connect with others who may have experienced similar circumstances…or not.  It makes me human.  It brings me joy.  Expressing myself through writing has been painful but has also brought me back to life.  I write to have a voice, give my family a voice, and to encourage my daughters to use their voices and realize their dreams.

Please support me and help me thrive at the VONA Voices Memoir Writing Workshop from June 28 through July 4, 2015, with Andrew X. Pham at the University of Miami.  The financial support requested ($1,150) will cover airfare and related workshop activities that will include but not be limited to a full week of classes, speakers, seminars, and public readings.  I thank you in advance for your thoughtful contribution but want you to know that your emotional support of this endeavor is not only appreciated…but priceless.

With gratitude,

Yesenia
