story:
Imagine a classroom of AP Computer Science students, excited and fresh-faced; maybe they've never written a line of code in their life, maybe they're super-guru-experts chomping at the bit to show up the teacher; every one seated at a desk, attention rapt, ready to hit the keyboard. Now imagine telling them they don't have keyboards. In fact, they don't have computers: not in the classroom, maybe not even at home. 15% of Americans don't, after all.
The reality is, this AP class will only be successful if it can provide for this need, but school budgets are thin, computer labs are overbooked, and even if they can provide the classroom environment -- with all the applications and tools implicit therein -- the students who cannot access a computer outside the classroom will likely not succeed.

Light as a...

For the past year, I have been developing a solution to one classroom's needs. I call it "feathers". With a feather, any computer can be transformed into an identical working environment for AP Computer Science students. Everything is completely self-contained, and completely homogeneous. When the student is done, they can turn off the computer and everything will be back the way it was before they started. A feather makes no permanent changes, and no permanent changes can be made to it -- turn it back on, and it's totally reset.
A feather can be a USB stick, a CD, or even distributed across a network. I can set up the feathers and adapt them to the requests of the teacher. Right now, the class is running 10 feathers every day on a set of old computers the school was simply going to throw out. That's the beauty: feathers are incredibly lightweight. They will run on outdated hardware without a hitch and guarantee the same student experience day in and day out. The teacher doesn't even have them hooked up to the internet (although he could.)

The Challenge

The feathers we have work great and will hopefully continue to do so. However, they only solve part of the problem. In order to do their homework, students need something outside of the classroom. Ideally, it would look something like what happens during class.
What I intend to do is take our feathers to the cloud. A server could provide a flock of feathers, accessible over the internet, to the students. Everyone would be on a level playing field. Students could use a feather from one computer and then switch to another, or multiple students could collaborate by working on a single feather. When it came time to turn in homework, they could do so from anywhere. If the teacher needed to distribute the assignment or provide some resource to the students, he could do so with ease.

What We Need

I am a volunteer. I have charged nothing for my services. However, it is not within my power to purchase a server for the teacher, and neither is it in his power to do so for himself. That's where you come in! Through Feathers for STEM Education I am trying to raise enough money to purchase computer equipment for his classroom -- namely, a server to host feathers. Every dollar raised by this campaign will help an AP Computer Science classroom at Lee M. Thurston High School in Redford, MI. Thurston is in a socioeconomically disadvantaged area.
The figure chosen was based on practical estimates of purchasing costs, as well as an evaluation of the cost of existing cloud solutions. For comparison, equivalent resources from Amazon's EC2 service would cost over $4000.
If I succeed, it will be a further opportunity for me to expand the power of feathers, refine the design, and ultimately make it available to other teachers and schools.

What I Want

Feathers are based wholly on free, open-source technology and I want them to stay that way. I fully intend to release information on what I have done with feathers alongside tools that will enable other people to follow in my footsteps, and I intend to release them for free. This fundraiser will go a very long way, with your help, towards this goal.
Thank you,
Noah Santer

p.s. If there are any perks you'd like to see, let me know!

story:
3:23 Academy, in St. Augustine, FL, is owned by Kim and Tim Pollock, both of whom graduated from local Flagler College as student-athletes. Kim and Tim are excited to serve the city of St. Augustine in a meaningful and impactful way.

Our mission is the following: To provide affordable youth programs that emphasize athletic participation, academic growth, and artistic expression in a safe environment that fosters well-rounded children.

3:23 Academy offers family-friendly services that help develop children of all ages. Unlike any other program in St. Augustine, 3:23 Academy works against the trend of overspecialization. Instead, we feel passionately about developing the whole child, which is why our unique program offers athletic, academic, and artistic classes.

What we provide:  individual tutoring, SAT Prep, basketball training, speed/agility classes, guitar/songwriting classes, art lessons, after-school care, toddler-Mom/Dad activities, Parents Night Outs, and other workshops. 

      What We Need & What You Get

      To get things moving, we need to raise $10,000.

      This money will outfit our space and cover all the start-up costs that go into a new business: signage for our store-front, liability insurance, a computer, a payroll program, advertising, athletic equipment--some of which is major, and official product and gear.

      In exchange for your partnership, we have lined up what we think are some pretty cool perks, from free lessons to free gear to customized pallet artwork to scholarships and more. 


      Do Work!

      As you may have already predicted, our name comes from Colossians 3:23, which reads, “Whatever you do, work at it with all your heart, as working for the Lord, not for men.” For a business promoting the academic, athletic, and artistic growth in young people, that verse seems rather appropriate!

      Education has always been important in our home. We hope to make it just as important to St. Augustine. By contributing to our company, you can help us and future students and ballers "do work" here in the city we love, St. Augustine, FL.


      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you cannot contribute financially, we understand. Do consider, however, helping in one of several other ways:  

      1.) Use our services! We offer a lot of great programs.

      2.) Refer us to someone you know.

      3.) Pass along our Indiegogo page.

      4.) Write a testimonial; this can be from any perspective--about us as a couple, as neighbors, friends; Kim as a parent or musician; Tim as a teacher or coach, etc. Send it to either one of us.

      5.) Follow us on the internet and social media:

             a.) Website: www.323academy.com

             b.) Facebook:  https://www.facebook.com/323Academy

            c.) Twitter: @323academy, https://twitter.com/323Academy

            d.) Instagram: @323academy

      6.) Donate an item or service. In no particular order, our needs include the following:

      • Two small soccer goals

      • Ball bags--athletic bags that hold several balls

      • A computer

      • Copier/copy paper

      • Bean bag chairs

      • Large Dry Erase Board

      • Kids’ musical instruments

      • CD Player

      • Guitar stand

      • Dry Erase Easel

      • Carpet squares or circles

      7.) Pray! Pray that we get the funds needed to carry this through and that we don’t lose sight of our ultimate goal--to do work that pleases Him, not us.

      Thank you!!!

story:
What is More Than "NO"?

We are comprised of actors, comedians, directors, writers, producers and other artists in the entertainment industry who would like to utilize our talents to change our world.  

Although many would separate comedy and activism, we believe that the best way to discuss a tough subject, is with a light-heart.  Therefore, our first goal is to create educational videos that are insightful, shareable, (dare-we-say) comedic that address sexual-assault in an approachable manner.

We believe an open dialogue about rape, sexual violence, and consent needs to be a common occurrence in order to eradicate it from our society.  We are striving to encourage and facilitate a discussion amongst our peers, educators and the youth of America.  


What do we need?

Although $12,000 might seem like a lot of money, it is actually quite low for the amount of work we're putting in.  We are working with professional film and television writers to create low-budget, yet effective scenarios that can be shot quickly and with minimal equipment.  Here's our approximate sample budget:
1) Cast and Crew - $5,000
The most important thing is hiring experts for each position onset: Director, Director of Photography, Light Tech, Sound Tech, Make-up Artist, Stylist, Actors, Graphic Design,  Production Assistants
2) Equipment - $3,000
We need access to professional equipment to best create each PSA: Digital camera,  lighting, sound. 
3) Post Production - $2,000
Editing can make or break any project.  We need a professional film editor for color correction, sound correction, ADR, etc. 
4) Craft Services - $1,000
Everybody has got to eat!  We want to make sure we take care of those putting effort into this important project by serving enough healthy food and drink options at each shoot.
5) Service Fee - $500
And, of course, there's always the IndieGoGo service fee :)
Pre-production would begin in February of 2015 with filming taking place March-May of 2015 and editing in May and June.


The Impact of our Work

The impact of our work has already been seen, especially by our founder, Madeline Harris.  Within the first week we released our first PSA, many people privately shared their stories of survival with Madeline.  Each survivor had never before come forward about their assault, and some didn't even realize they had been assaulted, until they watched the PSA.

This has happened every time we release a new PSA.  We get to talk with other survivors, hear their stories, and help them heal.

We've also started important dialogues with parents and guardians of younger adults and children.  Many of whom have begun to grasp the importance of teaching consent to their sons and daughters as part of their sexual education.

We are currently in the process of obtaining our 501(c)(3) nonprofit status.  Going forward, these PSA's will be inserted into educational packages that we are creating to take to high schools and colleges across the country so we can continue this important dialogue in hopes to prevent future assaults.


Risks & Challenges

We are doing this on a bare-bones budget.  Most film projects take thousands more to produce, but we feel we have the resources and experience to create these short PSA's for far less than most.

WHY?!  Because we've practiced!  We've already created 3 PSA's with almost nothing.  

We know that with a little help, we can get the message out quickly and effectively.  We just need a little boost!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you honestly can't spare a dime, there's other ways to help!  

  1. Send our campaign video via email!
  2. Post it to Facebook!
  3. Tweet about it!
  4. Write about it in your blog!
  5. Invite us to speak on your podcast!
Any and everything that gets the word out, helps further our vision.  So thank you, thank you, THANK YOU!
story_txt:
What is More Than "NO"?

We are comprised of actors, comedians, directors, writers, producers and
other artists in the entertainment industry who would like to utilize our
talents to change our world.  
Although many would separate comedy and activism, we believe that the
best way to discuss a tough subject, is with a light-heart.  Therefore,
our first goal is to create educational videos that are insightful, shareable,
(dare-we-say) comedic that address sexual-assault in an approachable manner.
We believe an open dialogue about rape, sexual violence, and
consent needs to be a common occurrence in order to eradicate it from
our society.  We are striving to
encourage and facilitate a discussion amongst our peers, educators and the
youth of America.  
   
What do we need?
Although $12,000 might seem like a lot of money, it is actually quite low for the amount of work we're putting in.  We are working with professional film and television writers to create low-budget, yet effective scenarios that can be shot quickly and with minimal equipment.  Here's our approximate sample budget:
1) Cast and Crew - $5,000
The most important thing is hiring experts for each position onset: Director, Director of Photography, Light Tech, Sound Tech, Make-up Artist, Stylist, Actors, Graphic Design,  Production Assistants

2) Equipment - $3,000

We need access to professional equipment to best create each PSA: Digital camera,  lighting, sound. 
3) Post Production - $2,000
Editing can make or break any project.  We need a professional film editor for color correction, sound correction, ADR, etc. 
4) Craft Services - $1,000
Everybody has got to eat!  We want to make sure we take care of those putting effort into this important project by serving enough healthy food and drink options at each shoot.
5) Service Fee - $500

And, of course, there's always the IndieGoGo service fee :)

The impact of our work has already been seen, especially by our founder, Madeline Harris.  Within the first week we released our first PSA, many people privately shared their stories of survival with Madeline.  Each survivor had never before come forward about their assault, and some didn't even realize they had been assaulted, until they watched the PSA.

WHY?!  Because we've practiced!  We've already created 3 PSA's with almost nothing.  
We know that with a little help, we can get the message out quickly and effectively.  We just need a little boost!
 
  
Other Ways You Can Help If you honestly can't spare a dime, there's other ways to help!  


Send our campaign video via email!
Post it to Facebook!
Tweet about it!
Write about it in your blog!
Invite us to speak on your podcast!

Any and everything that gets the word out, helps further our vision.  So thank you, thank you, THANK YOU!

story:
Why Yoga?

As a healer by nature and an educator in practice, I profoundly believe in the power of mindful speech, thought and action to radically change our world. This February 2015, I have the opportunity to travel to Bali, Indonesia, to complete an in-depth 500 hour professional yoga teacher training program called Shakti Initation. Alongside a group of twenty-three other women and two master female yoga teachers, I will spend five weeks deepening my skills as a leader, educator and yoga teacher in order to emerge with a skill set equipped to transform our world for hope, healing and positive transformation.

This advanced training program forms the next crucial step in my development as a teacher. Your contribution is not only an investment in my life journey, but palpable, direct support to the countless number of lives that I will engage with and bring light, hope and healing to as a result of this training. As an experienced leader, successful entrepreneur, and passionately engaged citizen I am committed to bring the depth and richness of this experience back to my community, locally in Western Massachusetts and internationally.

What We Need & What You Get

The cost of the program is $4,800, which does not include international flights or travel insurance. My intention is to raise $5,000, the full program tuiton cost plus $200 additional to contribute toward my flight costs.

    The Impact

    I cannot stress enough the difference your contribution will make. 

    My intention upon graduating from this program at the end of March, 2015 is to continue to work with adolescent girls in leadership development and female youth empowerment. I have worked with high school girls for over four years as a classroom educator, mentor and yoga teacher, and feel passionately about helping female youth grow up to feel empowered, capable, creative and beautiful. I intend to work in and outside of local school systems in the northeast as a professional yoga teacher upon my return.

    Did you know? -- I am an experienced, seasoned world-traveler. When I was 20 years old at Amherst College, I founded an international non-profit education initiative in rural Costa Rica, Beyond el Campo, that has brought over 2,000 books, strategic programing, and sustainable community development to a small farming community. My love of people, passion for justice and direct engagement with the world around me propels me forward to new ventures and I am thrilled to not only complete this teacher training, but for all of the meaningful work I will be able to engage with upon graduating.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Can't contribute today? That's OK-- Spread the word! Tell your fellow yogi friends, teachers and healing practitioners to support me in my pursuit!

story:
The Graphic Design Class of 2015 at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign is enlisting your financial support in—you guessed it, helping us get jobs.

“Ugh, art majors,” you scoff. “What are you supposed to do with that?”

Well, good design is, in fact, what makes the world go round. We don’t just design cool logos, awesome posters, or fabulous websites—we problem solve, work our butts off, and bring great ideas to life. Say you’re going to start your own non-profit organization. Chances are you’re actually going to want people to take you seriously, and that's not going to happen if you’re using Comic Sans and a half-assed logo. Design has the power to potentially make or break how your company is perceived by others. We’re inherently the key to your success, so come graduation, it will be our time to shine out there in the real world.

Please lend a hand in making our success possible by donating to our 2015 Portfolio Review, which will be taking place in Chicago at the end of the semester. We will be inviting design professionals from the Chicago design community to come view our portfolios and give us advice that will be critical in starting our own careers. We need to rent an appropriate venue, set up tables and chairs, and (of course) feed ourselves so we stay energized for what will be an exciting day.  Help us in bringing this event to life so we can help change the world by doing what we do best.

UPDATE: Thank you all for your support so far! Along with the proceeds from our very successful GD POP UP SHOP, we are only a few hundred dollars away from the overall fundraising goal students have pursued in previous years! However, some of our expenses (including our venue rental) have increased this year, and so our stretch goal for this Indiegogo fundraiser is $4000. Can you help us reach this? We truly appreciate your generosity!

story:
Musalaha’s Israeli-Palestinian Children’s Summer Camp is designed to provide a framework for Israeli and Palestinian children to meet together in a fun and friendly atmosphere. Here they have the opportunity to build relationships with children from the other side, whom they would otherwise not have the chance to meet and learn to counter many of the stereotypes they have learned.

Our children’s summer camp allows for campers to learn about the reconciliation process as they build relationships other side. This is done thorugh sitting together at meal times, playing water games, engaging in activities and studying the Bible together. They walk away from these camps learning new phrases and songs in Hebrew and Arabic, share cabins, become agents of change even at a young age and leave having made new friends. We also invite Sudanese refugee children to participate as the children learn to be around other groups of people who are living in both Israeli and Palestinian societies.

If children, at a young age, learn to love and break down the barriers of hate we will be able to raise up a new generation that seeks to transform society through love, peace and biblical principles of reconciliation.  

These children represent the future of this land, and if we do not invest in them now, and help them understand their common humanity as individuals made in the image of God, we will have missed a wonderful opportunity to impact their perceptions and decision making processes early on. Within a few years, many of these young people will be serving in the military, attending university and joining the work force. The ones who will be that change in their communities.

Following their experience at camp, these children are able to return home, equipped as messengers of peace and love and grow into agents of change within their own communities.

story:
This old church building as you can see has been cleared out ready for work to commence. A Library in this small village will be a very welcome centre that will not only serve the children from Akara primary school but the entire community and county. There is no library in the county and a resource like this will benefit so many children. Third picture is a primary four classroom again as you can see a lot of work needs to be done.

Teaching children how to read and the importance of understanding the English language cannot be stressed enough. The children in this community need this centre running and it will support the teachers too. Our goal is to get children reading and writing in English from a very young age so that they are able to compete in their exams and communicate well with others in the language.

We are collecting reading and reference books as well in preparation for this new Library. Head teachers from eight surrounding schools have already requested the foundation if children from their schools can also use the Library once it’s complete. The entire community are backing our efforts as they realise the importance of enhancing education for the children.

Please help us make this a reality for the children of Akara primary school and for all the children who attend school in the county.


Pamella A Oryema

Founder/Director – THE OKWIR FOUNDATION

story:
Please launch our futures!

"When I go to Space Camp, for real, I will be ready for anything!"- student

What did you dream of becoming when you were 10 years old? What changed the trajectory of your life as a learner? All dreams start as a seed and with support and education blossom into a reality. You can help make the dreams of our students a reality. Join us in believing in their dreams and their ability to reach their dreams. We KNOW that going to Space Camp will provide our students just what they need to continue to achieve anything they want in life. Regardless of the dreams they hold, the experiences provided at Space Camp- teamwork, challenge, education-- will support them.

"I love science and if I go to Space Camp I’ll learn new things see and experience new things and go through challenges every day. Since I want to be a scientist this will be really cool." -student

As teachers to an amazing group of 24 5th graders in Washington, DC, we have a combination of over 50 years of experience working with some of our nations most eager learners. Our students strive for excellence, work for their dreams and pursue them without fear. In all of our years, we have not taken a group on a large scale trip such as Space Camp. However, after Vanessa Ford ( STEM teacher) attended the Honeywell Educator @ Space Academy in June of this year, she was changed. She came back knowing that she, along with all of us, had to make this experience a reality for our 5th grade class. 

"It will be great to have these experience with my friends before middle school." -student

Our 5th graders have been together as a community of learners for over 7 years!  (We start preschool at age 3 here in DC!) As they each head to various middle schools, we want to provide them with an experience that solidifies their bond to each other while they are inspired to branch out in their middle school years.  

"Going to Space Camp would important to me because it would be so inspiring and it would as close a kid can get plus it would be the first field trip that we actually travel that far. I just get so excited!" -student

Our students are VERY eager to fundraise-- car washes, popsicle sales, knitting hats, playing violin at local farmer's markets-- but while those acts will bond them as they work towards the goal, it won't fully fund the trip. This is where we need you or your organization!

It is costly to safely take 24 students 1,500 miles! The total cost listed on this campaign is less than the total cost of the trip ( the students must and should fundraise themselves for this too) but this would be a large bulk of the costs.

We encourage you to get to know our students through our image gallery and watch their video (coming soon)! You will be inspired by them as we are every day and know you will want to support our efforts.

What We Need & What You Get

Rarely can one quantify impact on a child's life... but in this case we can!  Space Camp is a true dream for our students and $800 fully sponsors a student for this amazing experience! $800  covers travel, food, lodging and the experience of a life-time! We have many giving levels with associated perks for you! From personalized thank-you notes, videos and pictures to Skype sessions with our class thanking for you making their dreams a reality, we are ready to do what it takes to thank you for your giving! 

Should we not reach our goal, our dreams will not be dashed. Our students will be working tirelessly each week to fundraise it will just mean more popsicle sales, car-washes and knitted hats. Our goal is to raise these funds by December 31, 2014 so we can celebrate and plan the remainder of the year fundraising for space suits to go with our trip!

All donations will be placed through the Maury Elementary PTA which is a certified 5013c non-profit.

The Impact

"I want to go to space camp because I want to learn more about space and it will a little training because I might become an astronaut and I want to do more experiments." -student

Your  impact on the lives of our students will go on for years to come.  This trip will make them feel special, confident in their learning and abilities and show them they truly can do anything! While I have not launched an IndieGogo campaign before, I have proven track record of procuring donations and putting them immediately to use-- as do my colleagues working to make this a reality for our students. Just look at my blog (http://maurythinktank.blogspot.com ) or co-planner Art teacher Lauren Bomba's blog ( www.studiomaury.wordpress.com) and you'll see the ways we use materials donated to us and how we thank them! We value al of our supporters!

Risks & Challenges

Is it possible that we will not raise the amount needed to take our students to Space Camp? I suppose it could be... but we are determined to ensure we make this happen for our students. If we have not fully funded the trip by December 31, 2014, we will begin Phase II which will involve a letter writing campaign, doubling student fundraisers and holding more events for community members to contribute. We are not a group that gives up easily!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to help financially, please know we will accept all kinds of other support. Do you know someone who makes great T-Shirts and could give us a discount? Do you have a friend, colleague or local business in your area who loves Space and wants to make a DC student's dream come true? If the answer is yes to this, or any other idea you have, please share! Your support just by sharing will be invaluable.

We will not do this alone and as donors you will be there with us. You will hear from us, see how we are doing, experience camp through a video and truly make a difference! If you have any questions or concerns before donating, please do not hesitate to contact Vanessa Ford at vanessa.ford@dc.gov.

story:
My Story

My name is Ava and I'm a Junior studying Athletic Training and Spanish at Chapman University. I have the wonderful opportunity to study what I love abroad in the spring of 2015. The Univeridad de Granada and Chapman have an exchange program to help students learn about our unique profession of choice in other cultures. The unfortunate part is that studying abroad costs a lot of money, and a grant that Chapman usually receives to help students like me cover their expenses was not renewed this year. So I need your help!

Your Help

The University is helping a little with the cost, but it will not be enough. I am hoping for at least $2,500 to pay for airfare, room and board. I also have rewards for anyone who is willing to donate! You can see more about those in the sidebar.

The Impact

During my time in Granada I will be able to further my Spanish language skills and my sports medicine knowledge. The more funding I have the greater my ability to immerse myself fully in the culture.

Other Ways To Help

If you can't help out financially and still want to support me, I would greatly appreciate any advice for students abroad, or any Spanish study tips! Either way, thanks for reading through this. I truly appreciate it.


This is something I have been looking forward to for a long time and I would heartbroken if I was unable to go.

Thank you very much!

profession of choice in other cultures. The unfortunate part is that 
studying abroad costs a lot of money, and a grant that Chapman usually 
receives to help students like me cover their expenses was not renewed 
this year. So I need your help!
Your Help 

The
 University is helping a little with the cost, but it will not be 
enough. I am hoping for at least $2,500 to pay for airfare, room and board. I 
also have rewards for anyone who is willing to donate! You can see more 
about those in the sidebar.The Impact

During
 my time in Granada I will be able to further my Spanish language skills
 and my sports medicine knowledge. The more funding I have the greater 
my ability to immerse myself fully in the culture. 
  Other Ways To Help 
If
 you can't help out financially and still want to support me, I would 
greatly appreciate any advice for students abroad, or any Spanish study 
tips! Either way, thanks for reading through this. I truly appreciate 
it. This is something I have been looking forward to for a long time and I would heartbroken if I was unable to go. Thank you very much!

story:
Short Summary

SkillKindle SA is a concept in development stages in South Africa, having already been successful in India, and is one of the ways in which MD of Connect for Purpose aims to improve the skills of South Africans,  thereby advancing South Africa and helping achieve the dreams of late President of the Republic of South Africa (Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela) "Education is the most powerful weapon which you can use to change the world."  

  • I am a Management Consultant by expertise (having spent 9.5 years in 3 of the top Global Management Consulting firms), but a Spiritual woman in all things that I aspire to achieve. I have lived all my life in South Africa, having been brought up and educated in Durban, Kwazulu Natal, and worked in Johannesburg, Gauteng. I have prided myself in being educated, but also in being able to analyse a situation and make rational decisions. I am passionate about people, food, travel and God. 
  • I strive to live in the present time, which translates into me doing something NOW that will move South Africa towards being an ethically operated country that is for the people, by the people. I left the corporate consulting world as I want to make a change at the individual level, where these individuals create unique offerings that will also drive South Africa forward and create employment. I believe this is only possible through Education. SkillKindle SA is one form of technology that will assist to drive the dream that I share with many South Africans. I have seen it operational in both the United States (the model has evolved given the maturity of the internet in the United States) and in India, where Learners and Teachers alike have seen considerable progress in the development of skills. 
  • By contributing to SkillKindle SA, you will do more than make my dream a reality! There are millions of South Africans who seek skills development in South Africa. Finding a Teacher who has a vested interest in their development (career and personal), and one whose class is accessible to the Learner, is not easy. There are many Teachers who have a skill to provide, but do not have the means to market their offering. Through SkillKindle SA, your contribution will increase transparency of the Teacher's performance and  accessibility to millions of potential Learners with no limit on age, as well as create an efficient market place for Teachers to present their offering and create employment.

What We Need & What You Get

Through a detailed business case, I have assessed that SkillKindle SA requires a minimum of $40,000.00 contribution to meet some of the goals for the first phase implementation (over and above my $10,000.00 contribution).

  • This covers part of the initial design, development and implementation, but additional support is required for  ongoing maintenance of the website and database, employment of individuals who will verify the authenticity of the training programmes, find Teachers in areas outside of large cities and provide support for Learners and Teachers, contact centres to support the Learners and Teachers, and most importantly, marketing the offering across South Africa.
  • I would not be able to Thank You enough for helping to make this dream a reality. I believe you will contribute because you too believe in the power of education. What better way to be rewarded than to: Have a Teacher be able to list their course for free; Sponsor a learner to attend a class.
  • Each and every Dollar contributed will be beneficial and will contribute to making this a success. Each Dollar will be accounted for as it is received and as payments are made. I will keep all Contributors informed throughout the process, and you will see the rise in Learners who have developed a skill as SkillKindle SA grows.

The Impact

How will your contribution make an impact:

  • In 2011, 20% of South Africans were living in extreme poverty, and 45% in moderate poverty. SkillKindle SA aims to improve this statistic by increasing the capability of South Africans, and expose the people of South Africa to skills they can use to earn a living
  • Every $1 earned contributes to bringing a platform to South Africans that provides people with a skill to deliver a platform to reach learners around them; It also providers learners greater transparency on the training providers
  • With increased transparency, you will help contribute towards improved technical ability of South Africans, and thereby contribute towards the growth of a country and enablement of people to move above the poverty line

Risks & Challenges

Reaching all South Africans given the lack of access to technology and risk averseness of skills providers will prove difficult.  Thankfully, the State of the Nation address in June 2014 declared that access to internet services will improve.

  • As a first step for SkillKindle SA, the platform will be introduced in urban areas to test the solution, and increase awareness.
  • With a working solution in place, I will then work closely with skills developers in South Africa who have had exposure to developing learners in Rural and peri-Urban areas, to develop strategies to increase skills development in this area, including mentoring and coaching potential skills developers in these areas
  • In expanding this solution, alternate methods of information dissemination will be looked into e.g. SMS communication, mobile payment systems, interaction in schools, etc.
  • Thankfully, the State of the Nation address in June 2014 declared that access to internet services will improve, which will improve access to find the trainers.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are as passionate about SkillKindle SA as I am, then please pass on the word

  • If you know people in South Africa, ask them to get involved in introducing skills providers (Trainers). They can email the provider's details to Verushka@skillkindle.com
  • If you believe people would want to contribute resources beyond what we are asking and be involved post the initial Go Live, please pass on these details to them.
  • The top 3 fans that successfully refer people to the campaign, and result in the largest amount of funds raised through the campaign, will receive a voucher for use on SkillKindle SA (R750, R500, R250 respectively).
  • IndieGogo has materials you could use to share the details of the SkillKindle SA Campaign, so please utilise these to make sure the possible contributors reach the correct audience and that I can keep track of your referrals.

Thank you for taking the time to read about SkillKindle SA! I hope to take this journey because of people like you who care as much as I do about education!

They can email the provider's details to Verushka@skillkindle.com If you believe people would want to contribute resources beyond what we are asking and be involved post the initial Go Live, please pass on these details to them.

story:
Many of us know about the national importance of Selma, Alabama in our history but fewer of us know about the black entrepreneurial spirit that blossomed after the Civil Rights Act. McRae-Gaines Learning Center was founded in Selma, Alabama in 1978 under the umbrella of the Black Belt Human Resources and Development Center as their contribution to the care and education of minority children in Selma. Their founding directors wrote “A Pathway to College” which is still used as the basis for McRae-Gaines’ curriculum. Since that time McRae-Gaines Learning Center has influenced the success of its graduates as they go on to attend Selma public and private schools by giving them an early start on the fundamentals so important to school readiness. 

By the 1980s, McRae Learning Center became a popular preparatory school for African-American families in Selma and expanded its program to serve children through the eighth grade. Even today alumni talk about the strong community spirit at the school, the individual attention they received from all of their teachers, and the confidence they had in their academic preparation when they entered high school in the Selma City School System. The school’s contribution to confident and prepared students as they continued their education is measurable and significant.  Graduates from McRae-Gaines have completed their studies at colleges and universities throughout the United States. These students serve their communities today as teachers, lawyers, doctors, engineers, architects, community developers, government officials and in many other professions.

Due to the economic downturn in the Black Belt of Alabama over the past 15 years, McRae-Gaines Learning Center has returned to its founding mandate as a certified provider of child-care and pre-school programming for the State of Alabama Department of Human Resources. The school also partners with the Wallace Community College Selma to provide single and low-income parents with affordable child care while enrolled in classes at the college.  In addition, McRae-Gaines houses the award-winning OSR program for 4-year old kindergarten students and continues educating our children through the Second Grade. Since the late 1990s many of our parents affiliated with the school lack the benefit of a higher education or training and face fierce competition for the few jobs available in Dallas County. The unemployment rate in Dallas County is 13.7% and the underemployment rate is 29.8%. About 43.5% of the population is below the Federal poverty line, including 46.5% of children under the age of 18. 

As a duly elected Board of Directors and with resources in Selma and the Black Belt stretched thin and tapped out we have made the decision that we must go outside of Selma to raise critical support for McRae-Gaines Learning Center – in particular for our heroic teachers and staff. 

We want to see McRae-Gaines continue to educate “the least to the greatest…” in Selma and Dallas County.  We feel a deep sense of obligation to guarantee that legacy and are committed to reconnecting the Learning Center with benefactors who can help us stabilize the school’s financial situation and who can contribute significantly to the school’s ability to carry out its mission for the foreseeable future.

In order to do that we need to improve the conditions under which the school operates today.  We need to raise the following essential funds in this order of priority:

  1. Establish a Teacher’s Support Fund, $25,000
  2. Repair the roof damage caused by Hurricane Isaac, $50,000
  3. 10 Scholarships for 10 of our students, $50,000 ($5,000 per/ student per/year), 

The focus of this appeal is to establish a Teacher’s Support Fund with a campaign goal of $20,000. We can always come back to round it out - and we hope that you will continue to follow us!

Children are our most precious resource and we cannot let the accident of their birth place keep them from reaching their full potential.  Living in Selma as adults is no excuse for us to allow our children to be deprived of the very best education and the broadest possible opportunities. We want the same success and the same opportunities for McRae-Gaines students as we were able to provide our own children.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Mark and I work with Little Village Lawndale Public High school on the southwest side of Chicago. My program teaches young men values such as self-determination, positive anger expression, accountability, integrity, respect for womanhood, and visionary goal setting. One of the ways we teach and instill these values is through the power of sports, specifically rugby and boxing. Currently I have a group of around 20 students. The community we're located in is impoverished and has a very large gang culture and many of my students are affected by those influences. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • Any money raised will go to the sports program in the way of equipment, uniforms, transportation costs, educational and value building activities. 
  • I haven't quite decided how to thank funders yet, I'll speak to some of my students see if they can think of anything or maybe would like to make something personalized for anybody willing to help. 
  • If we don't reach our entire goal, our funds can be used on a myriad of things. The sports aspect is just one aspect of the whole program and the rest of the program can use funds to help the youth in other ways. 

The Impact

  • The program I work for has hard numbers that prove it helps reduce violent crime as well as boosts school attendance and graduation rates. Your money will help strengthen a program that already is proven to be effective. 
  • Many of the youth we face are missing important family figures and social constructs and our program is one of the few places they feel like they belong, or can be emotionally vulnerable and share their struggles and needs. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word to anybody and everybody, especially if there is someone in your life with a passion for youth and youth development. 
  • If anyone out there has some Rugby or Boxing experience and would like to come to help out with a practice, that would be appreciated as well.

    Thank you so much,
    -Mark

story:
Our fall robotics competition is called BEST, which is a competition that gives us six weeks to build a highly functioning robot. It will also require us to build a booth exhibit, make our own practice field, and participate in a variety of smaller projects.

New Vista Robotics is unfunded, and while our main robot materials are donated, we must raise money to pay for all tools, additional materials, food, and travel to local and regional events. Each year we raise money by selling donuts and working parking at CU games, but still come up short of what is needed to run the club. The club was invited to BEST Regionals in 2015 and raised $3000 on IndieGogo to make the trip. Not only do we need to raise that amount again, but we are in need of some equipment (table saw, chop saw, drill bits, saw blades, tap and die set, drill wireless, build materials, plywood, etc.). We haven’t purchased any new equipment in 2 years. We’ll also take all opportunities to raise money at school, but we need your help. If you can, please donate money, gift cards, or equipment. We appreciate your consideration. For more information, contact the robotics mentor, Stephen Shepherd at stephen.shepherd@bvsd.org, or call 720-561-8700.

 

We will use sponsorship money as follows:

Trip to Regionals (transportation and lodging):           $2960

Tools and Equipment:                                                           $500

Sustenance:                                                                             $450

Banner and T-shirts:                                                              $140

story:
Critique of "Rest in Power: The Trayvon Martin Story"

UPDATE: Debunking "Rest in Power: Trayvon Martin Story" (8/18/18)

Hey folks,

Just FYI, we've now distributed the detailed critique/debunking of the first three episodes of Jay Z's propaganda documentary, "Rest in Power: The Trayvon Martin Story," in written PDF form (one report for each episode, current total about ~200 pages of typed content), video form and audio (MP3) form (roughly 3.5-4 hours of total content).

If you're already a contributor to our IndieGoGo to support this effort you'll have received emails from us with the necessary links to access/download this content. There are three more episodes to go, with Episode 4 airing on Monday, August 27, so figure final content will be about double what we've done so far.If you're NOT yet a contributor, you might just want to consider becoming one, because we've set a new "stretch goal" that if we reach will result in Attorney Don West himself sitting for an in-depth, in-person interview/discussion with yours truly about the case. Don's personally committed to this, if we hit our new stretch goal. (I've also spoken with George Zimmerman about doing something similar, details to follow.)

So, if you haven't yet become a contributor, or if you have but you have friends or family or social media contacts whom you haven't yet convinced to become contributors, now would be the time! It's just one click to support this effort!

http://www.lawofselfdefense.com/trayvon

--Andrew

Campaign Update: NEW STRETCH GOAL: Get DON WEST on board!

I talked with Don West today, who as you know was one of George Zimmerman's lawyers at his trial, and he's very much aware of this initiative, and is open to participating.  What we've tentatively explored is the two of us meeting up at a mutually convenient location, and essentially filming both of us discussing the trial in person--we could even do it as a live webinar, perhaps, so folks can ask questions in real time.

To make it worth the effort, however, we'd need to be able to cover the travel cost of us meeting up, filming and producing the video of the meeting, and so forth, plus I'd like to be able to offer Don a really exceptional single malt Scotch in appreciation for his contribution.

Accordingly, I'm setting another stretch goal, given that we're already not far from hitting our first stretch goal of $10,000--we're currently just under $7,000.  

If we hit $15,000 before the last episode of this "crockumentary," I'll commit to convincing Don to meet up, have an extensive real-time discussion of the Zimmerman trial from each of our unique perspectives, and make that available at least as a live event and and an online stream.  That content would be made available for free to all contributors at the $30 level or above, and contributors below $30 would just need to bump up to $30 to be included. 

So, that's the new goal, folks:  $15,000.  

Campaign Update: STRETCH GOAL ANNOUNCED!

Wow, folks, we hit our initial goal of $1,000 in funding in less than two hours from launch of this campaign!  So, now we are announcing a stretch goal:  $10,000. If we hit our stretch goal of funding we'll also produce a DVD version of our video critique/review to make available as a permanent product for folks to own.  That DVD will be provided for FREE to the $30+ tier folks, for an additional $10 to the $20+ tier folks, and an additional $20 to the $10 tier folks (in all cases plus S&H, usually $7.95).  Arrangements for payment and shipping will be made to each donor individually after this funding effort has concluded, assuming our stretch goal has been reached.  (Obviously, there's no obligation to order the DVD if you're not interested in owning it.)

Few events have been as shrouded in propaganda, myths, and outright lies, as has the death of Trayvon Martin and the subsequent trial and acquittal of George Zimmerman, who justified his killing of Martin as an act of lawful self-defense.  

Because of my expertise and interest in self-defense law, I made the effort to watch every moment of the trial, including all the pre-trial hearings, as well as to review the entire body of evidence in this case, and I wrote about the trial extensively at the time. 

As a result, I bring a uniquely informed perspective to the truth of the death of Trayvon Martin, and the level of legal expertise necessary to shine a light on all that is false propaganda, myth, and lies around this case.

"Rest in Power: The Trayvon Martin Story" is a six-episode documentary that begins airing on Monday, July 30, 2018, that purports to tell the "true story" of Martin's death and surrounding events.  Perhaps it will, indeed, tell the true story, but given that I've virtually never heard the story told in a truthful way, I expect the documentary to be ripe for a professional, well-informed legal critique.

What We Need & What You Get

Given my already heavy workload, however, I can't reasonably commit the time effort necessary to view and critique the six-episode documentary unless there is substantive public interest in such a critique.  Accordingly, I've chosen to gauge the level of interest by raising funds to monetize my critique of the documentary.

  • We've achieved our minimal goal of $1,000, so this review/critique is a definite "GO"

  • We ask each donation be a minimum of $10

  • We will offer discrete "perks" at donations of $10+, $20+, $30+

  • We also offer a STRETCH "perk" of DVD of video review/critique

$10 or More

Those who donate $10 or more will receive access to a webinar featuring a video recording of me critiquing each episode, shortly after each episode airs. This will also be provided as a downloadable MP3 file, for those who prefer a podcast type delivery.

$20 or More

Those who donate $20 or more will receive the already mentioned webinar/MP3 review of each episode, PLUS also a written expert review of each episode, delivered in PDF form shortly after each episode airs.

$40 or More

Those who donate $40 or more will receive access to the webinar/MP3 review and PDF reports after each episode, PLUS as well as a printed-and-bound version of the written reviews, with a personalized autograph by me, Attorney Andrew F. Branca, delivered shortly after the final episode of the documentary.

$50 or More

Those who donate $50 or more will receive all of the lesser perks, PLUS an hardcover copy of our best-selling book, "The Law of Self Defense, 3rd Edition," autographed by me to the contributor personally (usually $35 + S&H, by itself).

$100 or More

Those who donate $100 or more will all the deliverables of the lesser perks, PLUS a copy of the Law of Self Defense LEVEL 1 State-specific Supplement DVD of their choice (usually $100 + S&H, by itself, by itself).

$200 or More

Those who donate $200 or more will receive all the deliverables of the lesser perks, PLUS a Law of Self Defense LEVEL 1 Core Class 4-DVD set of instruction (usually $200 + S&H, by itself).

$500 or More

Those who donate $500 or more will receive all the deliverables of the lesser perks, PLUS a one-hour private consultation with Attorney Andrew F. Branca (normal consultation is minimum of $450/hour, and generally a 10-hour minimum).  (NOTE: Consultation will be educational in context; Andrew does not provide legal advice via consultation; may be held in reserve by contributor for a future date, at their discretion.)

NEW! STRETCH FUNDING GOAL!

If we hit our stretch goal of funding of $10,000 we'll also produce a DVD version of our video critique/review to make available as a permanent product for folks to own.  That DVD will be provided for FREE to the $30+ tier folks, for an additional $10 to the $20+ tier folks, and an additional $20 to the $10 tier folks (in all cases plus S&H, usually $7.95). 

The Impact

This campaign is intended to be of interest to folks who care about truth, the law in real-world application, and about self-defense and the consequences (both positive and negative) that follow from having used force in self-defense.

Risks & Challenges

There is effectively no risk to funding this campaign.  If the minimum $1,000 is not raised, all money will refunded. If we exceed $1,000, I personally commit to conducting the review/critique and producing the promised "prizes."  In the unlikely event that I fail to meet that commitment, all money will be refunded.

Other Ways You Can Help

Besides making a contribution the best way you can help to share word of this fund raising effort on your social media accounts, on any internet gun forums you may participate on, and with like minded friends & family.

Thank you for your support!

--Andrew

Attorney Andrew F. Branca

Law of Self Defense LLC

http://www.lawofselfdefense.com/patreon
story_txt:
Critique of "Rest in Power: The Trayvon Martin Story"
UPDATE: Debunking "Rest in Power: Trayvon Martin Story" (8/18/18)
Hey folks,
Just FYI, we've now distributed the detailed critique/debunking of the first three episodes of Jay Z's propaganda documentary, "Rest in Power: The Trayvon Martin Story," in written PDF form (one report for each episode, current total about ~200 pages of typed content), video form and audio (MP3) form (roughly 3.5-4 hours of total content).
If you're already a contributor to our IndieGoGo to support this effort you'll have received emails from us with the necessary links to access/download this content. There are three more episodes to go, with Episode 4 airing on Monday, August 27, so figure final content will be about double what we've done so far.If you're NOT yet a contributor, you might just want to consider becoming one, because we've set a new "stretch goal" that if we reach will result in Attorney Don West himself sitting for an in-depth, in-person interview/discussion with yours truly about the case. Don's personally committed to this, if we hit our new stretch goal. (I've also spoken with George Zimmerman about doing something similar, details to follow.)
So, if you haven't yet become a contributor, or if you have but you have friends or family or social media contacts whom you haven't yet convinced to become contributors, now would be the time! It's just one click to support this effort!
http://www.lawofselfdefense.com/trayvon
--Andrew
Campaign Update: NEW STRETCH GOAL: Get DON WEST on board!
I talked with Don West today, who as you know was one of George Zimmerman's lawyers at his trial, and he's very much aware of this initiative, and is open to participating.  What we've tentatively explored is the two of us meeting up at a mutually convenient location, and essentially filming both of us discussing the trial in person--we could even do it as a live webinar, perhaps, so folks can ask questions in real time.
To make it worth the effort, however, we'd need to be able to cover the travel cost of us meeting up, filming and producing the video of the meeting, and so forth, plus I'd like to be able to offer Don a really exceptional single malt Scotch in appreciation for his contribution.
Accordingly, I'm setting another stretch goal, given that we're already not far from hitting our first stretch goal of $10,000--we're currently just under $7,000.  
If we hit $15,000 before the last episode of this "crockumentary," I'll commit to convincing Don to meet up, have an extensive real-time discussion of the Zimmerman trial from each of our unique perspectives, and make that available at least as a live event and and an online stream.  That content would be made available for free to all contributors at the $30 level or above, and contributors below $30 would just need to bump up to $30 to be included. 
So, that's the new goal, folks:  $15,000.  
Campaign Update: STRETCH GOAL ANNOUNCED!
Wow, folks, we hit our initial goal of $1,000 in funding in less than two hours from launch of this campaign!  So, now we are announcing a stretch goal:  $10,000. If we hit our stretch goal of funding we'll also produce a DVD version of our video critique/review to make available as a permanent product for folks to own.  That DVD will be provided for FREE to the $30+ tier folks, for an additional $10 to the $20+ tier folks, and an additional $20 to the $10 tier folks (in all cases plus S&H, usually $7.95).  Arrangements for payment and shipping will be made to each donor individually after this funding effort has concluded, assuming our stretch goal has been reached.  (Obviously, there's no obligation to order the DVD if you're not interested in owning it.)
Few events have been as shrouded in propaganda, myths, and outright lies, as has the death of Trayvon Martin and the subsequent trial and acquittal of George Zimmerman, who justified his killing of Martin as an act of lawful self-defense.  
Because of my expertise and interest in self-defense law, I made the effort to watch every moment of the trial, including all the pre-trial hearings, as well as to review the entire body of evidence in this case, and I wrote about the trial extensively at the time. 
As a result, I bring a uniquely informed perspective to the truth of the death of Trayvon Martin, and the level of legal expertise necessary to shine a light on all that is false propaganda, myth, and lies around this case.
"Rest in Power: The Trayvon Martin Story" is a six-episode documentary that begins airing on Monday, July 30, 2018, that purports to tell the "true story" of Martin's death and surrounding events.  Perhaps it will, indeed, tell the true story, but given that I've virtually never heard the story told in a truthful way, I expect the documentary to be ripe for a professional, well-informed legal critique.

What We Need & What You Get
Given my already heavy workload, however, I can't reasonably commit the time effort necessary to view and critique the six-episode documentary unless there is substantive public interest in such a critique.  Accordingly, I've chosen to gauge the level of interest by raising funds to monetize my critique of the documentary.

We've achieved our minimal goal of $1,000, so this review/critique is a definite "GO"
We ask each donation be a minimum of $10
We will offer discrete "perks" at donations of $10+, $20+, $30+
We also offer a STRETCH "perk" of DVD of video review/critique

Those who donate $10 or more will receive access to a webinar featuring a video recording of me critiquing each episode, shortly after each episode airs. This will also be provided as a downloadable MP3 file, for those who prefer a podcast type delivery.

story:
El trabajo que voy a presentar a Barcelona-LASA 2018, es acerca del feminismo desde una metodología vivencial en una corporalidad trans y en el contexto guatemalteco permeado por el racismo y la discriminación.

Antes de que tomes una decisión quiero contarte acerca de mi experiencia en este campo, hace varios años me dedico a la promoción y defensa de los Derechos Humanos a través del activismo y del trabajo académico en Guatemala. Actualmente soy investigadora y tallerista corporal en el Centro de Investigación Transpersonal Q’anil en donde imparto talleres corporales con una mezcla de metodologías. Estos talleres tienen dos fases, la primera es hablar de la interseccionalidad de las opresiones y las violencias, para después pasarlo a un plano corporal-vivencial, con el fin de transformar las relaciones de maltrato hacia la sanación y el buen vivir. El trabajo que hago si bien implica un impacto a nivel personal y con ello transformaciones sociales, es un trabajo que no me genera suficientes recursos económicos para poder pagar un viaje a Europa, por eso hago un llamado a tu solidaridad, para poder presentar mi trabajo, el cual significa no sólo analizar la realidad social sino transformarla un poco.

Con tu donativo quiero reunir mil dólares, para poder pagar mi pasaje de avión entre Guatemala-Barcelona, ida y vuelta. Según la cantidad que dones te haré llegar una carta de agradecimiento personalizada o una copia de mi ponencia, según sea el caso.

Si tú no puedes hacer una aportación económica, ayúdame a difundir esta campaña para que llegue a más gente.

Desde ya agradezco profundamente tu apoyo para la divulgación de propuestas de conocimiento transfeminista como esta, que se están generando desde Guatemala.

story:
Short Summary

Hello. My Name is Timothy Elliot Lalowski. I am a 3rd year Architectural and Civil Engineering Student with a minor in Architecture at the Illinois Institute of Technology. This year, I became inspired to explore the field of Health as a supplementary area of study, and reached out to many organizations around the world looking for opportunities to receive in-field research.

I eventually teamed up with David Carpenter, the leader of the World Health Organization Collaborative Center in Environmental Health, the Institute of Health and the Environment at the University of Albany, as my mentor for my endeavors. Mr. David Carpenter (M.D.) has been overseeing my research and connecting me with professionals in the field around the world. However, UAlbany does not have funding to support any research or internships, so the burden of funding my endeavors has fallen on to me. 

Some of the research on this topic can be accomplished through reading textual information from publications contained in library archives and Scholarly Journal Articles Databases such as JSTOR, however, nothing compares to an in-field experience, where real, pressing issues can be witnessed firsthand. For this reason, I am hoping to travel abroad to developing areas of the world such as the slums of India and the villages of Kenya to research detrimental Health issues that face the people who live there. 

I would be conducting research alongside my peer at IIT in Chemical Engineering, Jefferson West, while volunteering with the Jane Adeny Memorial School. (This way, not only can I perform research, but I can also support the great ideals of this organization.) For more information on the Jane Adeny Memorial School, visit: http://www.janeadenymemorialschool.com/ 

For more information on David Carpenter and the Institute of Health and the Environment at the University of Alban, visit: http://www.albany.edu/ihe/ 

 

 

Accesible Solutions to waste management issues in kenya

I. SUMMARY/ABSTRACT

Kenya, like most developing regions of the world, suffers from a heightened risk of disease and infection from food and water supplies due to issues caused by the current waste management conditions. The objective of this project is to study aspects of common techniques for waste management and utilize the findings to propose an alternative solution to the issue.

The project is divided into five stages: identify extent of health hazards, identify current practices and past implementations, test current practices and past implementations for evaluation, design, and design testing. The first two stages are to be completed in the summer of 2013, the third stage is to be completed in the fall 2013-spring 2014 university year, and the final two stages are to be completed in the summer of 2014.

The researchers involved in the project are Timothy Lalowski and Jefferson West. Timothy Lalowski is a third year Architectural Engineering major at the Illinois Institute of Technology with additional studies in Civil Engineering and Architecture. Jefferson West is a third year Chemical Engineering major at the Illinois Institute of Technology with a minor in Business. Both students are in good academic standing.

The advising and evaluation roles of the project are to be undertaken by Dr. David O. Carpenter, director of the World Health Organization Collaborative Center for Environmental Health at the University of Albany Institute for Health and the Environment.

II. NEED STATEMENT

Rarely do developing regions receive aide which is accessible to the population at a point of time in the future. Equipment fails, buildings deteriorate, and systems are broken, without the resources necessary to repair or further develop what has been implemented. Often, time and money goes to waste, funding implementations that cannot be properly utilized due to the differing structure of society and variety of resources. This is caused by a misunderstanding of the needs and structure of the region. Developing regions need strategies of waste management based specifically on their cultural and regional needs, instead of implementing techniques developed for use in relief supplying countries.

A. Description of specific problem targeted

Waste management solutions in Kenya lack accessibility, and their implementation lacks reinforcement. As a result, the habitants of the region suffer from diseases and infections caused by the soil, air, water, and food contamination.

B. Previous actions to deal with this need

1.)    Community Composting Initiatives

2.)    Waste Collection NGOs and CBOs

3.)    Privatization of waste collection and disposal

4.)    Scavenging systems

5.)    Recycling Initiatives

6.)    Incineration Plants

7.)    Chemical Treatment Plants

8.)    National Environmental Management Authority (NEMA)

Few have provided a significant change in waste reduction or effective and safe disposal. The effective techniques are unable to keep up with the growing demands.

C. Supportive data/information verifying the need

Data Presented by the World Health Organization/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation attached, and can be found at the following URL: http://www.who.int/water_sanitation_health/monitoring/africasan.pdf

D. Approach and benefit

The approach of the project focuses on the accessibility of waste management solutions. Success of the project relies on the successful education and future accessibility of resources utilized in the proposed solutions.

III. PLAN OF OPERATION

A. Project design

Developing countries pose a uniquely high risk of disease from water and soil contamination. It is the objective of this project to first identify the extent of the health risk based on current conditions. Phases two and three aim to identify influences that either increase or decrease the level of health risk related to the current waste management conditions. The final two stages present an implementation to alleviate some of the risk associated with the current conditions of waste management in Nairobi, Kenya.

B. Project structure

Goals: The primary goal of the project is to develop and test waste management solutions based on the observations and tests of previous unsuccessful implementations.

Objectives:

 Phase I: Identify Extent of Issues in Waste Management

     1. Test levels of soil contamination (chemical)

     2. Test levels of water contamination (chemical and pathogenic)

     3.Test levels of air pollution

     4. Gage waste production rates

     5. Gage recycling rates of waste reduction

     6. Gage composting rate of waste reduction and benefits

     7. Gage waste treatment rate of waste reduction and efficiency

     8. Gage water treatment rate and efficiency

Phase II: Identify Implementation Success and Failures

     1. Identify current waste management practices and past implementations

     2. Observe current waste management practices and past implementations

     3. Evaluate success and failure of current waste management practices and past implementations

     4. Isolate aspects of current waste management practices and past implementations

Phase III: Implementation Testing for Evaluation

  1. Design testing procedure of isolated aspects of current waste management practices and past implementations
  2. Perform testing procedure of isolated aspects of current waste management practices and past implementations
  3. Repeat testing procedure of isolated aspects of current waste management practices and past implementations
  4. Evaluate tests on successes and failures of current waste management practices and past implementations

Phase IV: Design

  1. Organize and evaluate conclusions
  2. Form hypotheses based on evaluations of component testing
  3. Design solutions to demonstrate hypotheses

Phase V: Design Testing

  1. Design experimentation on solution designs
  2. Perform experimentation on solution designs
  3. Repeat experimentation on solution designs
  4. Evaluate solution designs
  5. Revise solution designs
  6. Repeat

 Activities:

Anticipated Testing Procedures:

-          Soil Contamination Testing

-          Water Contamination Testing

-          Soil Compaction Testing

-          Soil Flow Rate Testing

-          Water Treatment Testing

-          Effectiveness of Programs Evaluations

-          Contaminant Filtering Techniques

-          Composting Techniques

-          Collection Techniques

-          Air Pollution Testing

Observation Procedures:

-           Daily Log keeping

-          Interviews, with candidates and inquiries to be selected at a later date

-          Referral to research publications

-          Audio and Video data recording

-          Waste Tracking

Analysis Procedures:

-          Correlation Testing

-          Graphing and Charting

-          Referral to Engineering standards

-          Referral to research publications

Design Procedure:

-          Evaluation of Analysis

-          Drafting

-          Design

-          Testing

-          Evaluation of Design Testing

-          Revision of Design

-          Testing

IV. MANAGEMENT PLAN

All research, design, and testing is to be completed by Timothy Lalowski and Jefferson West. The breakdown of specific roles is as follows:

 

Timothy Lalowski: Project oversight, scheduling, project organization, daily records keeping, academic research, interview coordination, audio and video log management, soil testing, pathogen studies, structural design, and hydrology design.

Jefferson West: Project advisement, report transcription, budget oversight, equipment retention, chemical testing, interview conduction, chemical design, disease protection, and toxin management.

 

V. EVALUATION PLAN

 

A. Process (formative) evaluation

Process description is to be submitted to Dr. David O. Carpenter for evaluation in the following format:

1.)    Questions and topics prepared for interviews to be submitted in typed format

2.)    Testing Procedures to be submitted in standard lab write-up format

3.)    Stages of Design to be submitted in Gaant Chart format

4.)    Overall log of project activity to be submitted in Gaant and written format

 

B. Product (summative) evaluation

Project summary is to be submitted to Dr. David O. Carpenter for evaluation in the following format:

1.)    Individual data collection sessions to be submitted typed from daily journals.

2.)    Interview data to be submitted as audio or visual file and typed format

3.)    Test data to be submitted in organized graphs and charts within standard lab write-up format for each individual test

4.)    Final summative product to be submitted it typed APA format with summary of activity

 

VI. COMMITMENT AND CAPACITY

 

A. In-kind match

Available personal funds: $5,000 in the form of bonds originally intended for educational purposes

Time Availability: 2 years

B. Capacity

Timothy Lalowski is a third year Architectural Engineering Major at the Illinois Institute of Technology with additional studies in Civil Engineering and Architecture. Jefferson West is a third year Chemical Engineering Major at the Illinois Institute of Technology and a minor in Business. All programs are ABET accredited at a 4 year university. Both Students are in good academic standing at the University. Both students have the capacity of time commitment to the project should funding requirements be met. Resumes Appended.

VII. BUDGET AND NARRATIVE

 

A. Budget (Appended in Gallery)

Total Requested: $6,941

In-Kind: $2,755

Total Cost: $9,696

 

B. Budget Narrative

Travel: Travel expenses include airfare to on-sight study location as well as shuttle between Nairobi, Kisumu, and Muhoroni. These three locations serve as three separate study areas.

Equipment: Standard soil, hydrology, and chemical lab equipment is necessary for the testing of conditions and implementations.

Supplies: Supplies necessary for the project involve recording media to log the entirety of the trip and adhere to Engineering standards of experiment procedure and provide a fully transparent representation of the project and its operations.

Other: Additional Expenses include equipment shipping, food, and board. Food and board are provided by the Jane Adeny Memorial School. Equipment shipping is defined as additional shipping costs necessary for international shipping to Muhoroni, Kenya.

Other Ways You Can Help

- Getting the word out! Every voice can tell thousands, and together we can fix the issues.

- Research Information: get educated on the subject, and educate others.

- I am constantly looking for connections to professionals in the field that can point me in the direction of pertinent information and the answers I am looking for.

- Have an open discussion. (I can be reached at tlalo34@gmail.com)
