Developing countries pose a uniquely high risk of disease from water and soil contamination. It is the objective of this project to first identify the extent of the health risk based on current conditions. Phases two and three aim to identify influences that either increase or decrease the level of health risk related to the current waste management conditions. The final two stages present an implementation to alleviate some of the risk associated with the current conditions of waste management in Nairobi, Kenya.
B. Project structure
Goals: The primary goal of the project is to develop and test waste management solutions based on the observations and tests of previous unsuccessful implementations.
Objectives:
 Phase I: Identify Extent of Issues in Waste Management
     1. Test levels of soil contamination (chemical)
     2. Test levels of water contamination (chemical and pathogenic)
     3.Test levels of air pollution
     4. Gage waste production rates
     5. Gage recycling rates of waste reduction
     6. Gage composting rate of waste reduction and benefits
     7. Gage waste treatment rate of waste reduction and efficiency
     8. Gage water treatment rate and efficiency
Phase II: Identify Implementation Success and Failures
     1. Identify current waste management practices and past implementations
     2. Observe current waste management practices and past implementations
     3. Evaluate success and failure of current waste management practices and past implementations
     4. Isolate aspects of current waste management practices and past implementations
Phase III: Implementation Testing for Evaluation

Design testing procedure of isolated aspects of current waste management practices and past implementations
Perform testing procedure of isolated aspects of current waste management practices and past implementations
Repeat testing procedure of isolated aspects of current waste management practices and past implementations
Evaluate tests on successes and failures of current waste management practices and past implementations
Phase IV: Design

Organize and evaluate conclusions
Form hypotheses based on evaluations of component testing
Design solutions to demonstrate hypotheses
Phase V: Design Testing

Design experimentation on solution designs
Perform experimentation on solution designs
Repeat experimentation on solution designs
Evaluate solution designs
Revise solution designs
Repeat
 Activities:
Anticipated Testing Procedures:
-          Soil Contamination Testing
-          Water Contamination Testing
-          Soil Compaction Testing
-          Soil Flow Rate Testing
-          Water Treatment Testing
-          Effectiveness of Programs Evaluations
-          Contaminant Filtering Techniques
-          Composting Techniques
-          Collection Techniques
-          Air Pollution Testing
Observation Procedures:
-           Daily Log keeping
-          Interviews, with candidates and inquiries to be selected at a later date
-          Referral to research publications
-          Audio and Video data recording
-          Waste Tracking
Analysis Procedures:
-          Correlation Testing
-          Graphing and Charting
-          Referral to Engineering standards
-          Referral to research publications
Design Procedure:
-          Evaluation of Analysis
-          Drafting
-          Design
-          Testing
-          Evaluation of Design Testing
-          Revision of Design
-          Testing
IV. MANAGEMENT PLAN
All research, design, and testing is to be completed by Timothy Lalowski and Jefferson West. The breakdown of specific roles is as follows:
 
Timothy Lalowski: Project oversight, scheduling, project organization, daily records keeping, academic research, interview coordination, audio and video log management, soil testing, pathogen studies, structural design, and hydrology design.
Jefferson West: Project advisement, report transcription, budget oversight, equipment retention, chemical testing, interview conduction, chemical design, disease protection, and toxin management.
 
V. EVALUATION PLAN
 
A. Process (formative) evaluation
Process description is to be submitted to Dr. David O. Carpenter for evaluation in the following format:
1.)    Questions and topics prepared for interviews to be submitted in typed format
2.)    Testing Procedures to be submitted in standard lab write-up format
3.)    Stages of Design to be submitted in Gaant Chart format
4.)    Overall log of project activity to be submitted in Gaant and written format
 
B. Product (summative) evaluation
Project summary is to be submitted to Dr. David O. Carpenter for evaluation in the following format:
1.)    Individual data collection sessions to be submitted typed from daily journals.
2.)    Interview data to be submitted as audio or visual file and typed format
3.)    Test data to be submitted in organized graphs and charts within standard lab write-up format for each individual test
4.)    Final summative product to be submitted it typed APA format with summary of activity
 
VI. COMMITMENT AND CAPACITY
 
A. In-kind match
Available personal funds: $5,000 in the form of bonds originally intended for educational purposes
Time Availability: 2 years
B. Capacity
Timothy Lalowski is a third year Architectural Engineering Major at the Illinois Institute of Technology with additional studies in Civil Engineering and Architecture. Jefferson West is a third year Chemical Engineering Major at the Illinois Institute of Technology and a minor in Business. All programs are ABET accredited at a 4 year university. Both Students are in good academic standing at the University. Both students have the capacity of time commitment to the project should funding requirements be met. Resumes Appended.
VII. BUDGET AND NARRATIVE
 
A. Budget (Appended in Gallery)
Total Requested: $6,941
In-Kind: $2,755
Total Cost: $9,696
 
B. Budget Narrative
Travel: Travel expenses include airfare to on-sight study location as well as shuttle between Nairobi, Kisumu, and Muhoroni. These three locations serve as three separate study areas.
Equipment: Standard soil, hydrology, and chemical lab equipment is necessary for the testing of conditions and implementations.
Supplies: Supplies necessary for the project involve recording media to log the entirety of the trip and adhere to Engineering standards of experiment procedure and provide a fully transparent representation of the project and its operations.
Other: Additional Expenses include equipment shipping, food, and board. Food and board are provided by the Jane Adeny Memorial School. Equipment shipping is defined as additional shipping costs necessary for international shipping to Muhoroni, Kenya.
Other Ways You Can Help
- Getting the word out! Every voice can tell thousands, and together we can fix the issues.
- Research Information: get educated on the subject, and educate others.
- I am constantly looking for connections to professionals in the field that can point me in the direction of pertinent information and the answers I am looking for.
- Have an open discussion. (I can be reached at tlalo34@gmail.com)

story:
Greetings Everyone,

I am excited to share that this summer I am traveling to Haiti to help build a vocational center and engage in a cultural exchange in the mountain village of Duchity, Haiti with Volunteers for Peace. I leave for the trip on June 16 and return July 3. Click here for more information about the program. We will partner with a local organization to build a vocational center to help uplift the rural community that has struggled in recent years.

The program is managed in Haiti by a native of Duchity, Despagne Felix, who several years ago was forced to leave his family and the village to find training and work in Port-au-Prince. After finding both in the city, he was able to come back to Duchity and made it his goal to build a vocational center where locals can get the skills and training they need to find work in their community, instead of having to leave everything and everyone behind.

I am drawn to this goal because it is managed by a local person who understands the needs and struggles of the community. In addition, the program is helping to build the center, but the responsibility for teaching and entering the vocational programs is still on the local people themselves, which gives people a real sense of self-reliance.

I'm passionate about uplifting communities worldwide and felt that this was a great opportunity to do what I can to help a small community better themselves. Haiti is a very poor country, and there is such a contrast between the vast wealth and the mass of poverty in the Western Hemisphere, and rural Haiti struggles with poverty even more.

The total cost for this trip is $1900 which includes program cost, building supplies, lodging, food, transportation within Haiti (Duchity is nearly a 7 hour drive from Port-au-Prince), and airfare. While I am traveling to Haiti alone, I hope to bring your support with me. Can you donate $20, $50 or $100 to cover the trip costs?

If you can't spare any money, you can still help by passing this on to anyone who you think my be interested in donating to this worthy cause.

I sincerely thank all of you, and feel incredibly fortunate for this opportunity.

All the best,

Michael P. Murphy

story:
Please help us Save Children's Lives in India.

Every child deserves a chance to live. 1.34 million children die every year before they reach their fifth birthday in India, often from common, preventable and treatable illnesses like pneumonia, diarrhea and infections.

That is where we can help. At the American Heart Association, we know how to help healthcare providers identify illnesses in children that can quickly progress. It is our obligation - and our honor - to share that science and training so more lives can be saved. We’ve launched a very simple but important campaign, Saving Children’s Lives. Alongside the United Nations, the World Health Organization and others, we are determined to decrease under five mortality.

Thank you to our generous sponsor, Impelsys!
 

Helping Save Children's Lives is just a click away

We need your support to train local community and hospital healthcare providers in India to stop easily preventable deaths.

We will train 180 local healthcare providers in the specialized skills needed to assess and address illnesses in babies and children. They will immediately be equipped to provide improved care and start training other healthcare providers to increase impact.

By the end of three years, we aim to expand from the initial 180 healthcare providers to as many as 1,155 with the ability to save children’s lives. By that time we believe the program will be self-sustaining.

With the support of various levels of government in India we believe Saving Children’s Lives can expand throughout the country and serve as a model for other regions – and other countries.

You Can Change the world

Your contribution can help save children’s lives. Pure and simple. By supporting the pediatric emergency care skills training for for healthcare providers in India, we can all take a stand against these unnecessary deaths and literally change the futures of entire families and communities. Together, we will enable new possibilities for the next generation of children in India.

Please help AHA make sure that children have all the help they need to live longer, healthier lives.

There Are So Many Ways You Can Help

Making a contribution is just one of the many ways that you can help.

  • Ask family, friends and colleagues to join the campaign.
  • Share it on social media with the Indiegogo tools on this page.
  • "Follow" the campaign (by clicking on the heart icon under the main video) to    receive campaign updates
  • Spread the word and help save children’s lives today.

Pick your perk.

Every giving level has a different perk, like a beautiful picture postcard by our award winning photographer Misha Masek.

Whatever amount you give, you'll be reminded of the children whose lives you're saving in India.

Thank you for your support!

story:
My name is Nasir Cook, I am 12 years old, I am in the 8th grade, and I live in Brooklyn, New York.  In junior high school I have been a good student academically but never I was never pushed really hard to be a great student in class.  I am also a budding fencer who is learning Epée at The Peter Westbrook Foundation. My dream is to become a gold medalist in fencing and a research doctor who will find a cure for cancer. Too many members of my family and community have suffered the effects of this ravenous disease.  The wounds this disease leaves are not only on the people battling the disease but also the ones that get left behind. I believe a doctor's job is to heal and if I can help cure cancer then maybe I can help prevent and heal some of the wounds cancer has left on us.

Being a part of the community has made a huge impact on me and I want to further my education to do bigger and better things.  To do this I need to attend a school that will push me beyond my comfort zone. I have been accepted to my first choice school, Basis Independent Brooklyn. Even though I have been awarded a partial scholarship, I still need to raise $20,000 to attend this school year.

Overcoming barriers is a skill I had to learn early in my life. Growing up in a single parent household in Brooklyn, I learned early on how to be resourceful by being able to get what is needed.  I learned that the world was unfair, but instead of crying and being upset with life, I kept my thoughts positive and looked at the skills I was learning in these experiences. I learned how to be responsible and also I learned how to stay strong when dealing with adversities. But more than anything, I believed that I shouldn’t let these negative situations distract me from wanting more for myself. Going to Basis Independent Brooklyn means that I will obtain an education that will continue to develop my mind and allow my in turn to transform the lives in my community, not just locally but globally as well.

Right now my mother and I are doing everything we can to get financial aid, yet it’s very difficult because my mother is currently unemployed due to being laid off from a job she worked for the past 7 years while out on disability.  Friends, today I humbly ask you to dream with me.

Cesar Chavez’s words resonate with my life goals of community work --- “We cannot seek achievement for ourselves and forget about progress and prosperity for our community... Our ambitions must be broad enough to include the aspirations and needs of others, for their sakes and for our own.” I believe in the power we have as a community and hope that you can help me reach my dream of becoming a great student today and one of the physicians that help cure cancer tomorrow.

story:
Alpine Montessori School

We are a small, non-profit school located in Alpine, Texas. Alpine Montessori was birthed 25 years ago by parents who wanted something more for their children and has been kept alive by parental and volunteer love and sweat.

What makes us different from other schools?

  • The child comes first in all things
  • Independent thought is nurtured
  • People over profits, we work to find a way to help all interested people enroll
  • Focus on community (locally and globally)

At Alpine Montessori, our children show us how they need to learn and we find ways to help them meet their goals. Students who leave our school find themselves academically ahead of their peers, but even better — they are better able to make independent decisions.

What We Need 

Being a non-profit organization doesn't change our needs for materials and supplies. Parents and friends of the school donate time and materials frequently to help keep us going. We try to keep our tuition as low as possible, in order to do this we need to utilize fundraisers to help us supplement our purchasing needs. 

Things we would love to do with your donations:

  • Purchase new materials for our primary and elementary programs
  • Plan bigger, better field trips to help foster curiosity
  • Improve our playground equipment
  • Finish our greenhouse
  • Build a woodworking shop
  • And oh so much more!

Why Should You Help Us?

Our school is the only secular private non-profit school in our county (the largest county in Texas). We serve a small but far flung population. Due to our demographics, our fundraising abilities are more limited than they are for those in larger areas. Our school is fueled by the sweat equity of all of the partners and parents now and who have come before, but sweat doesn't always pay the bills. We want to do more than keep our doors open. We want to grow, expand and flourish as we nurture young hearts and minds.

An investment in Alpine Montessori is an investment in Alpine, in Brewster County, in the future of young children in rural locations. Our school provides jobs and training to residents along with compassionate education for our students.

As a Montessori school, we are uniquely suited to help serve students who are gifted AND students who may have special needs. We believe in finding the strengths within each child and using those to help them overcome any hurdles they find before them. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!
  • Volunteer at our school.
  • Donate materials (art materials, building materials, landscape materials)

We couldn't be here if it weren't for you and others like you. Thank you for all that you do for us, for the children and for the community we cherish so deeply.

story:
NVCMideast continues to deepen and expand our passion of supporting transformation of violence and pain by offering Nonviolent Communication  training to Israelis, Palestinians and Internationals, in area "C" of the West Bank, accessible without permits to Israelis, to Palestinians from the West Bank, and to Internationals.

Two weeks ago we had our closing circle for the fourth 9 day NVC training in this part of the Mideast,  bringing together up to 100 Israelis, Palestinians and Internationals at EcoME Center near the Dear Sea and the desert, living  a culture of Nonviolent Communication in the Mideast.

from March 12-14, 4 NVC women trainers - Palestinian, Israeli and American -will facilitate the next Women's Leadership and Empowerment Training and Retreat at EcoMe.

Projects include Training NVC Trainers in the Mideast, opening the. Women's  Leadership and Empowerment Institute,  weekly practice groups,  weekend and longer trainings and retreats for organizations, schools, teens, men, women, religious and secular Jews, Moslems and Christians, leaders, educators and activists, as well as ongoing joint regional projects within Israel and the West Bank.


Between February 19 and  March 1,  with support from friends all over the globe, up to 100 Israelis, Palestinians and international friends gathered together in Beit Jala and near the Dead Sea for 9 days of living, learning, sharing and connecting with each other. This is the continuation and expansion of five years of NVC  (Nonviolent Communication)  trainings and projects in the Mideast. For many people from this region, this was the first time they have sat with each other, shared their truth, heard each other's pain and dreams, and engaged in a collective transformational training . For others, this was as continuation of their training in living, applying and learning to share Nonviolent Communication in Israel and Palestine.

This training, and all of our projects, aim to empower and support the needs of each community in the Mideast by offering the experience of using NVC to break through into new territories of communication, connection and change.

Our trainings are led and supported by an international team of NVC Trainers who have substantial experience leading trainings in the Mideast, Africa, Asia and the west, local organizations such as EcoMe, Holy Land Trust, and by dozens of Israeli, Palestinian and international volunteers.

We are also excited about our growing programs  with women, in schools , and with  teens and families, that empower us to learn and practice Nonviolent Communication together, changing the world together.

We are asking for your support to complete our fundraising for this 9 day training retreat, our flagship program.  Everything we do lays the basis for continuing and deepening our next trainings. This is a grassroots, independent project, with no backing from donor institutions.  In a region where political and cultural separation are the norm,  EcoME, our  host and partner, is unique in its mission to welcome and  shelter gatherings of Palestinans and Israelis in a  safe and welcoming location freely accessible to people living both  inside the West Bank and Israel. 

Our Current Needs

This indiegogo campaign is crucial to our sustainability and continuation . Monies raised will go directly to cover 

- scholarships ( we granted scholarships to almost all of the participants from the Mideast)

- our awesome team of local Arabic and Hebrew translators who are crucial to creating a community filled with learning, connection and participation. Every activity is translated into three languages and we have roving translators to facilitate in-depth one-on-one and small group connection

- EcoMe, our wonderful host organization

-our team of dedicated international trainers and assistants who are working tirelessly year round to make this event a significant contribution to the well being, peace, understanding and healing of people in the Mideast and the world

We are seeking your help!  The aim of this campaign is to increase our network of friends and supporters and to raise at least $15,000 so we can continue to provide scholarships for everyone from the Mideast who needs one to attend. 



What you get?

The joy and meaning from connection, contribution and participation in our growing movement, a certificate that you can personalize as a gift to your loved ones, friends and family members, and beautiful gift of your choice.


Who we are

This project is a collective effort of a team of international trainers in Nonviolent Communication, www.cnvc.org, trainers focusing on the Mideast, NVCMideast, dozens of local supporters and organizations and the EcoMe Center for Peace and Ecology , http://rebuildingalliance.org/ecome-center/. Our training team this year includes Irmtraud Kauschat  Germany,  Duke Duchscherer  (United States and Canada) Roberta Wall, J.D.  (United States),Hagit Lifshitz, M.A. (Israel),  Yoram Mosenzon  (Israel, Netherland), Nafez Assaily  (Guest Trainer, Hebron), Marc Weiner  (United States). 

Other projects that grew out of this course

This course enables true and meaningful partnerships to arise, and already there are a number of amazing projects, including:

- Yoga teacher training in the West Bank for Palestinian and Israeli men

-9'day International Intensive  NVC training and  Convergent Facilitation leadership trainings in Beit Jalla  for Israeli and Palestinian leaders and organizations 

- ongoing training and teaching NVC in,the West Bank by new Palestinian Trainer

-ongoing NVC practice groups in Israel by new Israeli trainers

-ongoing NVC in schools in the West Bank and Israel 

-development  of NVC Family Camps in Israel and the West Bank beginning in 2015

-Trainings within religious communities

- Palestinian-Israeli Womens Empowerment Weekends

- Palestinian -Israeli Mens Weekends

- Palestinian-Israeli Teen programs

-Sister city and country projects between Brazil and the Mideast and Switzerland and the West Bank




What is Nonviolent Communication?

Nonviolent Communication (NVC) is a way to build connections powerfully, compassionately,authentically, and with clarity. It builds capacity to express ourselves in language that doesn’t involve blame or attack and shows us how to listen to the underlying values or needs which are important to people even when they express themselves in difficult or hostile ways. NVC then builds on the new connections and understanding that arise to explore solutions and strategies that address everyone’s needs. Nonviolent Communication is being used in conflicts and settings worldwide by communities, institutions and organizations, activists, leaders, parents, educators, doctors, social workers, managers and others This program will bring together in the Mideast all sectors of people living in the region, as well to improve their work and home life and bring about the changes they want to see in the world.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word! Think of people you know who are longing to see positive action in support of transformation in the region, people who want to value the lives of everyone in this tortured piece of land. Tell them about the opportunity to participate - both as learners at the event, and as partners and co-sponsors in making this possible. Speak about this at your synagogue, church, or mosque, share it on your Facebook page and elsewhere.

Thank you already for your heart and support. Remember, in these kinds of campaigns, no amount is too large or too small.

We would love to hear from you. Please email us: MideastNVC@gmail.com


We feel  thankful for and encouraged by your support !

Irmtraud Kauschat  (Germany) irmtraudkauschat@yahoo.de

Duke Duchscherer  (United States and Canada) duked303@gmail.com

Roberta Wall, J.D.  (United States) www.steps2peace.com

Hagit Lifshitz, M.A. (Israel) www.mifgash.org.il  

Yoram Mosenzon  (Israel, Netherland) www.connecting2life.net

Nafez Assaily  (Guest Trainer, Hebron): www.lownp.com


And all of our Assistants, volunteers and participants!
story_txt: NVCMideast continues to deepen and expand our passion of supporting transformation of violence and pain by offering Nonviolent Communication  training to Israelis, Palestinians and Internationals, in area "C" of the West Bank, accessible without permits to Israelis, to Palestinians from the West Bank, and to Internationals. Two weeks ago we had our closing circle for the fourth 9 day NVC training in this part of the Mideast,  bringing together up to 100 Israelis, Palestinians and Internationals at EcoME Center near the Dear Sea and the desert, living  a culture of Nonviolent Communication in the Mideast.from March 12-14, 4 NVC women trainers - Palestinian, Israeli and American -will facilitate the next Women's Leadership and Empowerment Training and Retreat at EcoMe. Projects include Training NVC Trainers in the Mideast, opening the. Women's  Leadership and Empowerment Institute,  weekly practice groups,  weekend and longer trainings and retreats for organizations, schools, teens, men, women, religious and secular Jews, Moslems and Christians, leaders, educators and activists, as well as ongoing joint regional projects within Israel and the West Bank.Between February 19 and  March 1,  with support from friends all over the globe, up to 100 Israelis, Palestinians and international friends gathered together in Beit Jala and near the Dead Sea for 9 days of living, learning, sharing and connecting with each other. This is the continuation and expansion of five years of NVC  (Nonviolent Communication)  trainings and projects in the Mideast. For many people from this region, this was the first time they have sat with each other, shared their truth, heard each other's pain and dreams, and engaged in a collective transformational training . For others, this was as continuation of their training in living, applying and learning to share Nonviolent Communication in Israel and Palestine.This training, and all of our projects, aim to empower and support the needs of each community in the Mideast by offering the experience of using NVC to break through into new territories of communication, connection and change.Our trainings are led and supported by an international team of NVC Trainers who have substantial experience leading trainings in the Mideast, Africa, Asia and the west, local organizations such as EcoMe, Holy Land Trust, and by dozens of Israeli, Palestinian and international volunteers.We are also excited about our growing programs  with women, in schools , and with  teens and families, that empower us to learn and practice Nonviolent Communication together, changing the world together.We are asking for your support to complete our fundraising for this 9 day training retreat, our flagship program.  Everything we do lays the basis for continuing and deepening our next trainings. This is a grassroots, independent project, with no backing from donor institutions.  In a region where political and cultural separation are the norm,  EcoME, our  host and partner, is unique in its mission to welcome and  shelter gatherings of Palestinans and Israelis in a  safe and welcoming location freely accessible to people living both  inside the West Bank and Israel. Our Current NeedsThis indiegogo campaign is crucial to our sustainability and continuation . Monies raised will go directly to cover - scholarships ( we granted scholarships to almost all of the participants from the Mideast)- our awesome team of local Arabic and Hebrew translators who are crucial to creating a community filled with learning, connection and participation. Every activity is translated into three languages and we have roving translators to facilitate in-depth one-on-one and small group connection- EcoMe, our wonderful host organization-our team of dedicated international trainers and assistants who are working tirelessly year round to make this event a significant contribution to the well being, peace, understanding and healing of people in the Mideast and the worldWe are seeking your help!  The aim of this campaign is to increase our network of friends and supporters and to raise at least $15,000 so we can continue to provide scholarships for everyone from the Mideast who needs one to attend. What you get?The joy and meaning from connection, contribution and participation in our growing movement, a certificate that you can personalize as a gift to your loved ones, friends and family members, and beautiful gift of your choice. Who we areThis project is a collective effort of a team of international trainers in Nonviolent Communication, www.cnvc.org, trainers focusing on the Mideast, NVCMideast, dozens of local supporters and organizations and the EcoMe Center for Peace and Ecology , http://rebuildingalliance.org/ecome-center/. Our training team this year includes Irmtraud Kauschat  Germany,  Duke Duchscherer  (United States and Canada) Roberta Wall, J.D.  (United States),Hagit Lifshitz, M.A. (Israel),  Yoram Mosenzon  (Israel, Netherland), Nafez Assaily  (Guest Trainer, Hebron), Marc Weiner  (United States). Other projects that grew out of this course This course enables true and meaningful partnerships to arise, and already there are a number of amazing projects, including:- Yoga teacher training in the West Bank for Palestinian and Israeli men-9'day International Intensive  NVC training and  Convergent Facilitation leadership trainings in Beit Jalla  for Israeli and Palestinian leaders and organizations - ongoing training and teaching NVC in,the West Bank by new Palestinian Trainer-ongoing NVC practice groups in Israel by new Israeli trainers-ongoing NVC in schools in the West Bank and Israel -development  of NVC Family Camps in Israel and the West Bank beginning in 2015-Trainings within religious communities - Palestinian-Israeli Womens Empowerment Weekends- Palestinian -Israeli Mens Weekends- Palestinian-Israeli Teen programs-Sister city and country projects between Brazil and the Mideast and Switzerland and the West BankWhat is Nonviolent Communication? Nonviolent Communication (NVC) is a way to build connections powerfully, compassionately,authentically, and with clarity. It builds capacity to express ourselves in language that doesn’t involve blame or attack and shows us how to listen to the underlying values or needs which are important to people even when they express themselves in difficult or hostile ways. NVC then builds on the new connections and understanding that arise to explore solutions and strategies that address everyone’s needs. Nonviolent Communication is being used in conflicts and settings worldwide by communities, institutions and organizations, activists, leaders, parents, educators, doctors, social workers, managers and others This program will bring together in the Mideast all sectors of people living in the region, as well to improve their work and home life and bring about the changes they want to see in the world.Other Ways You Can HelpPlease spread the word! Think of people you know who are longing to see positive action in support of transformation in the region, people who want to value the lives of everyone in this tortured piece of land. Tell them about the opportunity to participate - both as learners at the event, and as partners and co-sponsors in making this possible. Speak about this at your synagogue, church, or mosque, share it on your Facebook page and elsewhere.Thank you already for your heart and support. Remember, in these kinds of campaigns, no amount is too large or too small.We would love to hear from you. Please email us: MideastNVC@gmail.comWe feel  thankful for and encouraged by your support !Irmtraud Kauschat  (Germany) irmtraudkauschat@yahoo.deDuke Duchscherer  (United States and Canada) duked303@gmail.comRoberta Wall, J.D.  (United States) www.steps2peace.comHagit Lifshitz, M.A. (Israel) www.mifgash.org.il  Yoram Mosenzon  (Israel, Netherland) www.connecting2life.netNafez Assaily  (Guest Trainer, Hebron): www.lownp.comAnd all of our Assistants, volunteers and participants!

story:
Would you say I have a plethora of piñatas?

#laspinatasatx

Help us put together Austin’s first-ever Piñata Picnic on Saturday, November 14th, 2015! In collaboration with Big Medium and the East Austin Studio Tour, we are inviting Austinites, old and new, to come out to Edward Rendon Sr. Park where they can destroy piñatas to their hearts’ content while they relax and picnic on the waterfront in Austin’s East Side.

We ❤ Piñatas

Between October 17th and November 22nd, visitors will find a small herd of massive piñata burros grazing in Edward Rendon Sr. Park on Town Lake. They are part of our Las Piñatas art installation, a commission by City Of Austin Arts in Public Places Program and an official stop on part of the the East Austin Studio Tour (EAST).


When a pair of transplanted property developers unjustly demolished local piñata store Jumpolin in early 2015, a fire was lit under the East Austin community to reset the course of the city's growth.

Austin’s growth is a reality. But for Austin’s growth story to be considered a success, we believe the city must respect its past as much as it anticipates its own future. The Las Piñatas art installation is designed to preserve the memory of Jumpolin so that Austinites, both new and old, will discover a shared 

responsibility in shaping the city’s expansion. 

You are a part of Austin's growth story, a story that begins with the local quirks and traditions that make this city great. Together, we will celebrate the humble piñata as a symbol of Austin's vibrant East Side community.


The plan, and why we want your help


On Saturday, November 14th the Las Piñatas site will be a gathering spot for Austinites to come out to picnic and break piñatas on the beautiful waterfront of Edward Rendon Sr. Park. (more details on our FB page)

BECOME A PIÑATA PATRON! Help us buy as many piñatas as possible to hand out to children and families to break during the Piñata Picnic in a celebration of Austin's vibrant East Side. Your contribution will have a direct impact on the community, as we will source all piñatas from Jumpolin and other local businesses in the neighborhood. 


All donations will be used to buy piñatas and the materials we need for this event. Should we end up with leftover piñatas from the event, they will be donated to neighborhood schools and community groups. A portion of all proceeds will also benefit Latino in Architecture's Summer UTSoA Program Scholarship.


Our sponsors and partners

We want to thank our sponsors and partners that made Las Piñatas possible.

Who we are

The Las Piñatas project is spearheaded by architect David Goujon. It is supported by a group of volunteers, friends and families passionate about Austin's heritage. If you are interested in helping out in any way, please write to us at LasPinatasATX@gmail.com

A very special thanks to

Monica and Sergio Lejarazu, Matt Boelsche, Reva Goujon, Jorge Vega, Anna Bradley, Sara Ortiz, The Franks Family, Rohin Bhalla, TechShop Austin, Lowe's Round Rock, Structures Engineering, David Rodriguez Sr., Rosa A. Goujon, NoackLittle Architecture and Interiors, Austin Mutual Agency and AIA Austin.

story:
Together we can help children less fortunate this Christmas


About Us

We are a group of independent documentary makers based in Cebu, Philippines.

Our most recent work has focused on animal welfare projects such as illegal horsefighting,inhumane conditions in factory farms and a project on the worlds smallest primate. You can see our work here.

Our campaign

This Xmas we want to help the local community of street kids in whatever way we can.  Our expectations are pretty realistic but we hope we can buy them the basic neccessities like footwear, clothes ,a health kit or arrange a health check up depending on the level of support.

Every donation (minus paypal and indiegogo charges) will go directly to the street children. We will personally cover all logistical and administration costs involved in making sure ALL your donation goes directly to the children who need it.

We will also film the fulfilment process for greater transparency so you know how your money is spent and where it goes to.

Please  share this campaign with your friends and family on facebook and other social media sites and if you can pledge a couple of dollars then thats great.
 
Many thanks for taking the time to read about our campaign. Hopefully this year we can help make these kids holidays a happier one.
 
Richard and Graham
 
Undercover

story:
Why England?

Since i was a wee lass, I wanted to move to England. Through years of work, careers, school (oh god so much school), I finally have the chance to go and pursue my dreams: To teach in London (or nearby) , England. With my Bachelor of Education in hand, I have been awarded a teaching position in England, however, I need to figure out how I can financially make the initial move from Canada.

Where Does All The Money Go?

Every dollar donated will go towards my expenses for the initial move to England. Such as:

  • The flight to England
  • First and Last Month's Rent
  • Basic Furniture / Needs

 

Why Beg For Money?

I originally wanted to wait a year or two to save up enough money to move myself without any worries, but I recently discovered that England's immigration laws are extremely difficult to work with unless you are in your 20s. Since I am closing in on my 30s, I cannot risk this opportunity to achieve what I set out to do 15 years ago.

Any and all the people who donate to my dream chasing will always be dear to my heart. And through the years I will regail people with tales of those who have believed in helping dreams come true.

LGBTQ and Diversity

As a member of the LGBTQ community and being from a mixed race and mixed culture, I understand the issues and challenges that are faced. Changes in the world and acceptance sometimes are not enough to create a healthly environment for students who are constantly being marginalized or bullied based on thier race or sexuality. I have always believed that I have a duty to help and be able to provide advice or be a role model for students who need guidence... not only from someone who is an ally, but from someone who is a member.

Philosophy of Education

Your donation will not only help me, but will intrinsically make an impact on every student I teach. Below is my philosophy of education, something I hold dear to my heart and will always believe in.

Teaching isn't simply a transfer of knowledge from one person to another; it is an opportunity to change lives and help mould futures. Education has changed drastically over the past few decades, changing from a knowledge based approach to a critical thinking approach. With online access to a plethora of information, we are no longer filling minds with raw information, but rather showing students how to interpret, understand, and critically analyze information and how to find relevant knowledge. I strongly feel that our students are now on the cusp of a new era of learning and teachers need to embrace the new digital society to be able to give students an education that they can relate to. Using technology, social media and other types of relevant media, I will strengthen my lessons by making them relevant and interactive with students – keeping them engaged and enthusiastic about learning.

 

Teachers are role models whether or not they intend to be and the way teachers look at life and career is important. A smile, sharing a good joke with the students, or even just taking ten minutes in the morning with a class to talk informally to see how their weekend went, can create a more approachable teacher without breaking professionalism. Like any other job, one of the most important qualities to have in a leader is approachability—that if anyone is having difficulties they will be able to talk to you and be able to work out a solution.


Teaching is more than just fulfilling the curriculum; it is getting to know students, and helping them when they need guidance. Teaching is being able to show students who want to give up to keep going and to give students a place to feel welcome when they feel like they don’t belong. School should be fun and engaging and they should not be subject to a torturous like environment. School should be like a second home where they can have fun, collaborate and socialize with one another while investigating new information. Students should be free to be creative with their lessons and never feel the fear of being judged if they try something new, or attempt a solution to a question. A great teacher once said, “Take chances, make mistakes, and get messy!”

story:
Every Child Should Have a Chance

My name is Rosemary White and I am the ED of an inclusive preschool program here in Toronto. Bond Child and Family Development. (formerly Bond Street Nursery School) This wonderful nursery school was founded in 1937 to help children and families whose lives were ravaged by the Great Depression and then by the war. Families without enough food or clothing and certainly, no toys. Sadly, in 2013, there continues to be poverty and great need in our community and Bond continues to find housing, clothing, food and toys for many children.

25% of the children in our program have special needs. One in every 88 children in Canada is diagnosed with Autism. Our school supports many children with autism. Children needing help with speech and language skills and physical development are here too.

 As the mother of a child with special needs, De George Syndrome, I am passionate about inclusion. I fought many battles to have my daughter be a part of the normal world in schools, camps, and in life. My daughter passed away and now my fight continues for other children.

 We have been asked many times to include children who are unable to walk because of medical fragility. We have not had the equipment or staffing to support children safely. That is about to change. With your donation, we can buy some very useful things. Every child should be able to participate in every part of our program but sometimes they need a little extra help.

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising two thousand dollars to buy two things: a special back support tricycle and a small support chair to help a three year-old girl with Cerebral Palsy and a four year-old boy recovering from brain cancer. Neither can walk…yet.

We have a very large beautiful outdoor playground and garden where kids ride their bikes on a meandering path through the trees and around the garden. There are child-sized picnic tables and benches. The new trike and chair will allow the two children (and who knows how many more later), to do what all the other children are doing.

 Your support will be applauded and acknowledged on our website and in our newsletters. You will know, especially if you have friends or family with special needs, that your dollars have been put to very good use.

If you do not use Pay Pal and want a receipt for tax purposes, send a cheque to:

BCFD, 51 Bond St. Toronto ON, Canada M5B 1X1  include your full name and address.  

Or go to our website: www.http://bondchildandfamilydevelopment.ca and click on Canada Helps

If you have already donated through Pay Pal, and would like a receipt, send me your address at bsns@bellnet.ca

Even if we only raise a few hundred dollars, it will be enough to buy the chair so a child could sit up to the craft or snack table without falling.

 The Impact

Children that come to Bond get a terrific start. By ages 4 and 5 they are ready for kindergarten. Each, to the best of his or her ability has learned English, made friends, and can count, recognize colours, sing, dance and play. Oh, and take turns. That is so important.

Our program is a United Way member agency with a proven track record of success in our community. We have helped thousands of children throughout the years. Our home visiting and intervention programs, our school bus – all United Way funded. Our bursary program is supported by donors, people who know we will do what we can to help as many children as possible.

Our staff has won awards for Best Inclusive Practices, Best Community Program and Best Advocates for Children.

 Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot give, why not help get the word out to others about our campaign.

Indiegogo has easy to use share tools!

story:
Monica, a friend of mine, wants to go to Our Lady Seat of Wisdom Academy (http://seatofwisdom.org/) this fall. Unfortunately this school does not take student loans, so Monica is trying to raise the money on her own.

I have been friends with Monica for over four years and I've seen what a beautiful, generous young woman she is. She always has a smile on her face and a kind word for someone. I'm hoping to raise half the total for her. As her youth leader and as her friend I have seen her grow in her faith over the last few year and I would love for her to have this opportunity to further that growth at a Catholic institution. 

Right now Monica is working full time while finishing up Grade 12 to fund her tuition and ticket to Ontario, where the school is located. 

The total costs, as taken from the School's website are as follows:

TUITION 
$5,950 + $200 CAD Student Activity Fee (2012-2013)

ROOM AND BOARD
$5,000 CAD
 
So a total of $11,150 + the cost of a plane ticket to Ontario. 
 
In the campaign I'm hoping to raise 5,500, so about half of the overall cost. Even if this goal is not met, every little bit helps Monica! 

If you contribute....

  • You're helping a wonderful young woman grow in her Catholic faith. :)
  • I will pray for your personal intentions every day that Monica is at school. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share this campaign on Facebook! 
  • Ask your friends to donate- even if it's five dollars!
  • Email it! 
  • Print it out and attach it to a carrier pigeon! 

Thank you for your help! :)
story_txt:
Monica, a friend of mine, wants to go to Our Lady Seat of Wisdom Academy (http://seatofwisdom.org/) this fall. Unfortunately this school does not take student loans, so Monica is trying to raise the money on her own.
I have been friends with Monica for over four years and I've seen what a beautiful, generous young woman she is. She always has a smile on her face and a kind word for someone. I'm hoping to raise half the total for her. As her youth leader and as her friend I have seen her grow in her faith over the last few year and I would love for her to have this opportunity to further that growth at a Catholic institution. 

Right now Monica is working full time while finishing up Grade 12 to fund her tuition and ticket to Ontario, where the school is located. 
The total costs, as taken from the School's website are as follows:
TUITION $5,950 + $200 CAD Student Activity Fee (2012-2013)
ROOM AND BOARD
$5,000 CAD
 
So a total of $11,150 + the cost of a plane ticket to Ontario. 
 
In the campaign I'm hoping to raise 5,500, so about half of the overall cost. Even if this goal is not met, every little bit helps Monica! 


If you contribute....

You're helping a wonderful young woman grow in her Catholic faith. :)
I will pray for your personal intentions every day that Monica is at school. 



Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign on Facebook! 
Ask your friends to donate- even if it's five dollars!
Email it! 
Print it out and attach it to a carrier pigeon! 

Thank you for your help! :)

story:
Youth For Palestine - Netherlands

We are a group of young activists who seek to raise awareness concerning the injustices the Palestinians have been facing for many decades. We aim to show the truth the Zionist-controlled-media has been hiding, through publishing reports, photographs and videos. We also care to throw a light on the Palestinian culture and creative personalities, a beautiful part of Palestine that is systematically being hidden and erased.

Our activity does not end there; we have been organising protests and campaigns in the Netherlands in various occasions. We are willing to increase our efforts and to extend our presence to other countries in the world.

The bombing of the Gaza Strip.
Now we all know the events of last summer, in the Gaza strip especially. "Israel" kept bombing Gaza, supposedly looking for the murderers of the 3 teenagers that have been killed. 
Later on, when they admitted that Hamas or Palestine had nothing to do with it, they were still bombing the most dense part of the world, because they wanted to destroy the Hamas tunnels.
With all the bombing and destroying they did, they also tried to destroy the possibility for lots of children to somehow build a future through education. We can’t have that. 

The Project

Youth for Palestine is working on a project in Gaza which has its focus on reaching out to the orphans there, and helps providing them with school supplies. With this project we will be able to help about 10% of all the orphans in Gaza. Youth for Palestine has people in Gaza itself who will be making sure that the right supplies will be brought to the right place. We won’t stand by and do nothing when the future of these children is at risk. With everything that’s happened, a lot of school and facilities have been destroyed in Gaza. 

With your help and donations we can at least try to make sure the children don’t forsake their dreams and ambitions, and know that they’re not alone.
Despite of the fact that a lot of schools have been completely or partially destroyed, the children are still going to school, but they don’t have the right supplies for it. We want to provide those supplies, and to do that we need an amount of at least €3000,- 

Don’t forget; every penny counts!!

Education means hope to a better future, let’s try to give them that hope!

story:
Using 6,500 plastic bottles filled with inorganic trash, we’ll form walls with chicken wire and cement, ultimately constructing a classroom where the children will learn and expand their horizons. Our team will also create and carry out a hygiene workshop, spend time with special-needs children in San Martin and visit a women’s solidarity group in Tikonel.

I'm constanty striving to be the passionate, life changing servant leader God has made me to be. He has blessed me with the desire to help the youth of the world. Building a bottle school will help me bring joy and love to those lives! This is one of the best ways that I am able to partner my heart for children and my physical strengths to accomplish something great! Building this school will change lives, including my own, and I am excited to be a part of this impactful movement! 

I've been able to raise some of the money so far, but I still am falling short of my goal of $800. Words cannot express the gratitude I have for every single donation that is made. 

Please donate what you can and share with whomever, I appreciate you so much for taking the time to help me continue to serve others!

story:
Short Summary


Obfuscation is changing all of the readable names of classes, fields, properties and any other elements of C#. It is extremely powerful. But obfuscation tools are really expensive. And most of them won't work with Unity3D effectively.

I have a new Idea on how to tackle the problem. And it goes against all the rules for proprietary development. I want to allow the users to make their own modules for deciding what should and should not be obfuscated.

Any developer with the knowledge of how to program in C#, Javascript or even Boo should be able to make the choices on what they want obfuscated and what they don't want obfuscated. Their modules allow them to make the decision. But most importantly they will be able to differentiate between what is a Unity class, and what is not a Unity class. Handling these separately is key to good code security.


What We Need & What You Get


My little 13 inch macbook is not powerful enough to get the development done very well. And it is on its last legs. I need a new macintosh to move my development environment and code to. Aside from that it's not possible to support wife and daughter without a full time job and with a full time job you just dont get any free time to work on side projects. What I want to do is get some help from the indiegogo community to allow me to take six to eight months off work and devote to this project that I think will protect the intellectual property of hundreds of thousands of developers around the globe.

While I will be purchasing a new macintosh, this money will also help support me and my family as I become a one man development wrecking crew on this project. I know I can produce this, I want to produce this. I just need a little freedom from the daily grind.

If I get enough donations, I will look into hiring other like minded individuals with some incredible development skills (I already know a few) who can help me accomplish this task.


The Impact


Developers around the globe will enjoy an inexpensive and powerful solution to allow them to completely protect their projects with the power of the high priced versions, and the comfort-ability of knowing that their project is just as protected as they need it to be, As well as the freedom to customize that protection to suit their needs with freely available modules that I hope will spark a whole new community.

    Challenges


    Figuring out all of the obfuscation tricks that the professionals use will be the most complex task, as no person that has done it will talk about it, and no person that has a project that is working will let you in on any of their secrets. However, I am a self taught computer programmer since the age of 13. I started on Visual basic 5 control creation edition from microsoft. After that I worked on understanding all kinds of scripting languages such as VBScript and Javascript. I have also worked on open source server development using PHP and MySql. More importantly tho, I have held many positions in companies working on languages ranging from Java/C# to Objective C and even Oracle's PL/SQL or microsoft's T-SQL. I have worked on nearly all databases including but not limited to MySql, Oracle, MSSQL and even FoxPro. On one instance I used both Access and Excel as a data system for an internal website.

    The point is that I have always been able to either figure stuff out, or make stuff up. And that is why I know this is well within my reach. I was already able to rename class names, and I have been working on getting other features working as my money slowly dwindles. The project just needs to be expanded on and turned into a nice robust framework that would make all my mentors proud. And more importantly a nice simple system that will be easy for the regular developer to build on, as well as having a set of default project pieces that will allow non developers to use it with relative ease.

    Other Ways You Can Help


    If you believe in this project and don't have the money to donate. That is ok. Talk about it. Share the links on your facebook page. If we can get this going. We can take this portion of the market by storm. And I'm not out to get rich. I don't plan on bringing this out with a price tag that indy developers can't reach (i'll probably bring it out for next to nothing to start with, of not exactly nothing). I want this to be available to the masses. And I want to build a community around the project, I would like to make this into something to be remembered for.

    If I cannot reach my goal


    If for some reason I am unable to reach my goal, I will be using whatever is put up to keep me running as long as I can, and get this project out with all the features I can get working in it. I want to make this amazing, but if I cannot, I will make it at least tangible. 
    Thank you for your consideration and support.

Thank you for your consideration and support.

story:
Our educational enrichment program gives kids needed skills to lead healthy active lives, and a foundation from which to go on to be successful adults.

The goal of our Indigogo campaign is to raise the money we need to produce our new curriculum and distribute it to the 3,000 CYCLE Kids students in our program each year. 

Mission

The CYCLE Kids program inspires healthy lifestyle choices.  Kids are introduced to the joy of bicycling and educated about bike safety and nutrition.  We empower children to develop positive, safe and active lifelong habits, achieve academic success, and improve their social skills. 


About
CYCLE Kids is a national organization with 39 programs in eight states, reaching 3,000 children each year.  Since 2004, CYCLE Kids has engaged children in physical activity to address the health and emotional issues facing today's under-active often overweight, children.  Built on the belief that the vital, simple, and captivating skill of riding a bike changes lives, CYCLE Kids is dedicated to improving the health and well-being of children through a comprehensive curriculum that teaches not just the skill of cycling, but nutrition too.  The program fosters monitorship, builds community, and gives kids and families empowering skills and lessons that endure a lifetime.


What We Need 

The CYCLE Kids program is unique because a child's learning is both experiential and academic. During the program, each child receives a textbook to support concepts learned in their physical education class. 
This year, CYCLE Kids is revamping, and redesigning our curriculum. We have strengthened the nutritional concepts and added activities that emphasizes cooperative learning, using auditory, kinesthetic, and visual learning techniques. 
CYCLE Kids needs to raise $65,000 to complete our new curriculum. With the support of our partner, Kick Design, our new content is almost ready to go. We need your help to finish production and to distribute it to the schools.

Funds raised for this project will be used to complete the following:

  • Layout Design
  • Illustration
  • Printing
  • Training
  • Distribution

The Impact

In the CYCLE Kids program, students learn about nutrition, they learn how to ride a bike safely, they get exercise, and most importantly, they get that same feeling you had when you realized that Dad had already let go and you were riding on your own.

With research funded by the American Heart Association and conducted in collaboration with  the nutrition department at Boston University's Sargent College for Health and Rehabilitation Sciences, a program was developed that taps into the joy of the biking experience. Children achieve personal and social growth, desire higher levels of physical activity, and gain much needed nutrition knowledge.

  • Personal growth –  students feel safe and self-reliant, improving their self-confidence, self-esteem, and sense of well-being.
  • Social growth – kids have an opportunity to socialize with other children in a positive, social, and non-competitive physical activity.
  • Physical activity – By making bike-riding fun, social, and safe, CYCLE Kids gets children hooked on a healthy activity.
  • Nutrition knowledge –  CYCLE Kids graduates adopt new nutritional skills, including portion control, how to fuel your body for energy, and the importance of fruits and vegetables.

Take away? Kids start to bike to school, focus better on their academics, make new friends, and influence their families to change and adopt healthier habits.

The CYCLE Kids program fosters mentorships, builds community, and empowers kids.  The program brings hope and strength to communities: the hope for a brighter future for their children and the strength to unite and become agents of change.


Our Research

Where there is knowledge there is power.  Over the past 5 years, we have been educating ourselves on how to create the greatest impact through our program.

How? CYCLE Kids measures program impact with pre and post program assessments that determine a child's gain in knowledge in the areas of riding skills and enthusiasm, road safety, and nutrition.

Why? Results from these assessments show us how to reach further into the community and inspire children to adopt the skills from a CYCLE Kids class and integrate them into everyday life.

Next Steps: The new 2- year curriculum will

  • Strengthen children's existing knowledge of nutrition
  • Encourage parental involvement and inspire healthy eating for the whole family
  • Emphasize cooperative learning
  • Address all types of learning styles

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute, don’t worry, but please help us spread the word by sharing this page with all your friends & family, and through your social media platforms!

If you want to make a meaningful investment in the health of our children, we have an opportunity for you.  Help us produce and distribute the new CYCLE Kids curriculum that will give kids and their families empowering skills that endure a lifetime.

Address all types of learning styles
