story:
Thanks to everyone who attended our reception on June 16 to help us envision the potential for our new office and recording studio space! If you were not able to attend, or if you are one of our out-of-town supporters, please watch as Marc takes you on a lighthearted tour of the space. 


In our 22-year history The Marc Steiner Show has established a reputation for unpacking the complexity of issues and telling the human stories behind the headlines: showcasing diverse voices, moderating fair and in-depth discussions, and using the media platform to help build bridges and connect communities.

We are pleased to announce that we now are looking to build on and expand our legacy: For the first time ever, Center for Emerging Media – the non-profit production company that produces The Marc Steiner Show and other projects – is moving to our own headquarters, with room for our own recording studio.

While we will still broadcast live from our home station WEAA every morning, our new offices and recording studio will be a space for producing The Marc Steiner Show as well as a community space, where we can create new projects and help train the next generation of media makers.

Our Vision for the New Center for Emerging Media Offices:

  • A space where students, scholars, activists, and just regular folks can come to share their stories and create meaningful projects focusing on issues, perspectives and ideas often overlooked by mainstream media outlets.
  • A space where new voices can learn how to express themselves powerfully and effectively, mentored by veteran broadcaster, educator, and human rights activist Marc Steiner and our talented producers Mark Gunnery and Stefanie Mavronis. All of our production staff -- including Marc, Mark and Stefanie -- are already actively involved in training youth with an interest in storytelling and media. Imagine what we can do with our own office space and studio!

We need your support to make this vision a reality! 

We have secured new offices in the heart of the Charles Village neighborhood of Baltimore, but furnishing them and building out an audio-video recording studio will take money. We have a $35,000 budget to meet and have put together a number of great premiums for your donations. Every dollar is appreciated. And your donations are tax-deductible!

If you believe in our work but are in a place where donating any amount would create a hardship, you can help us by taking the time to pass on the information about this campaign to your friends, family, and colleagues … and urge them to support us! Thanks for all you do!

In case you are new to The Marc Steiner Show and Center for Emerging Media

Center for Emerging Media (CEM) is a non-profit media production company founded in 2000 by veteran Peabody Award-winning radio journalist, educator, and activist Marc Steiner, as a platform to produce special educational and journalistic media projects. Marc’s daily public interest talk show The Marc Steiner Show has been broadcasting over Baltimore’s public radio airwaves since 2003.  In 2008, CEM assumed complete production and fiscal and fundraising responsibility for The Marc Steiner Show.

CEM’s goals are to use all forms of media to produce high-quality, thought-provoking programming that informs its listeners on a wide range of topics, airs the voices of individuals not typically heard in mainstream media, and provides fair and balanced discussions of important issues.

And CEM has accomplished a lot over the years! In addition to The Marc Steiner Show, which airs two hours every weekday, we produced two powerful documentary pieces and have covered many key events in Baltimore and beyond:

  • For the 30th anniversary of the end of the Viet Nam War, our team traveled to that country to record and produce a 7-hour radio documentary called Shared Weight, featuring voices from all sides of that conflict. Shared Weight has played on public radio stations across the nation.
  • We produced the Peabody Award-winning series Just Words, which tells the stories of the working poor in their own voices.
  • Our Sound Bites series has aired one hour weekly for the past four years, and features stories, headlines, and panel discussions on issues of our food system and the environment.
  • Our This Day in History segments at the beginning of each Marc Steiner Show have received wide recognition for their spotlight on history from the perspective of working people, women, the LGBT community, and people of color.
  • In the events in Baltimore following the death of Freddie Gray, CEM staff members have been in the streets providing local “on the ground” coverage and telling the important stories of real lives and real people, largely missed by the national press.  Producers Mark Gunnery and Stefanie Mavronis produced a compelling 3-part video series, "Voices of the Freddie Gray Protests." 


How Big of a Risk are We Taking?

While any new venture is a risk, we have the benefit of over 22 years of success, plus our deep relationship with the Baltimore community, to sustain us. We believe it’s worth the risk and that, in fact, this move will enable CEM to become more independent and self-sustainable. In addition, once the recording studio is up and running, it has the potential to be income-generating.

What the World Says About CEM and The Marc Steiner Show:

Katrina van den Heuvel, Publisher, Editor & Part-Owner, The Nation:

"I always value how you bring history to bear – unknown, untold, underreported, humane history – on events of the day or just to bring it to people’s attention. Because I think we’re living at a moment where so much of what we listen to and read seems de-contextualized and de-historicized."

E. Ethelbert Miller, Award-winning Poet: 

"The Marc Steiner Show is not just another talk show. It's a place where people go for what I define as heavy-lifting conversations. It's amazing how Marc stays on top of timely issues, new books and trends. His program might as well be called Radio University. What I admire about Marc is his professionalism and amazing grace. A guest on his show always sounds like a neighbor talking across a fence, which is perhaps at the core of what makes the Marc Steiner Show important. Here is a radio program which encourages community. It opens the door and windows to dialogue and civic engagement. Listen to Marc Steiner and you'll understand that democracy requires us to put our shoulder to the wheel. Every show this man records is another victory for freedom and social justice."


Joe Ehrmann, Founder of Coach for America & Former Baltimore Colts Defensive Lineman:

"Marc you’re my hero. I just love what you do for this community, and I thank you for being such a tremendous change agent. Glad to call you friend." 
John Nichols in The Nation magazine's 2013 Progressive Honor Roll issue, where The Marc Steiner Show was named "Most Important Radio Show."
"No one who has listened to veteran activist Marc Steiner’s morning show on Morgan State University’s WEAA can figure out why this guy hasn’t gone national. Yet Steiner is so into his hometown of Baltimore that it’s hard to imagine him anywhere else. This is what public affairs radio should be: informed, nuanced, interested in a range of opinions, yet clear and unequivocal in its passion for democracy and social justice. Steiner is exceptionally well prepared for every interview, determined to foster dialogue and so respected that state and national political figures are frequent guests. What makes his show remarkable, however, is Steiner’s respect for his listeners. He knows they will engage with discussions about poverty in Baltimore and poverty in Palestine, about the American Legislative Exchange Council and the Trans-Pacific Partnership. And the Peabody Award–winning broadcaster’s 'Day in History' review explores the cultural and political landscape with thrilling depth and reach.”

Zeke Berzoff-Cohen, Co-Founder & Executive Director, The Intersection:

"Marc Steiner is a national treasure and a regional gem. Marc's award winning journalism brings insight, wisdom and a great diversity of voices into some of the most important and challenging conversations of our era. Marc lives out his values on the air and in the community.  As a board member for my non-profit The Intersection, Marc has had a transformative impact on the lives of several of our most at risk several children. We are incredibly fortunate to have Marc here in Baltimore and I am honored to call him a friend."
story_txt:
Thanks to everyone who attended our reception on June 16 to help us envision the potential for our new office and recording studio space! If you were not able to attend, or if you are one of our out-of-town supporters, please watch as Marc takes you on a lighthearted tour of the space. In our 22-year history The Marc Steiner Show has established a reputation for unpacking
the complexity of issues and telling the human stories behind the headlines: showcasing diverse voices, moderating
fair and in-depth discussions, and using the media platform to help build
bridges and connect communities.
We are pleased to announce that we now are looking to build
on and expand our legacy: For the first
time ever, Center for Emerging Media – the non-profit production company that
produces The Marc Steiner Show and
other projects – is moving to our own headquarters, with room for our own
recording studio. 
While we will still broadcast live from our home
station WEAA every morning, our new offices and recording studio will be a
space for producing The Marc Steiner Show as well as a community
space, where we can create new projects and help train the next generation of
media makers.
Our Vision for the New Center for
Emerging Media Offices:


A
space where students, scholars, activists, and just regular folks can come to
share their stories and create meaningful projects focusing on issues,
perspectives and ideas often overlooked by mainstream media outlets.


A
space where new voices can learn how to express themselves powerfully and
effectively, mentored by veteran broadcaster, educator, and human rights
activist Marc Steiner and our talented producers Mark Gunnery and Stefanie Mavronis. All of our production staff -- including Marc, Mark and Stefanie -- are already actively involved in training youth with an
interest in storytelling and media. Imagine what we can do with our own office space and studio!


We need your support
to make this vision a reality! 
We have secured new offices in the heart of the Charles Village neighborhood of
Baltimore, but furnishing them and building out an audio-video recording
studio will take money. We have a $35,000 budget to meet and have put together
a number of great premiums for your donations. Every dollar is appreciated. And
your donations are tax-deductible!
If you believe in our work but are in a place where donating
any amount would create a hardship, you can help us by taking the time to pass
on the information about this campaign to your friends, family, and colleagues
… and urge them to support us! Thanks for all you do!
In case you are new to The Marc Steiner Show and Center for
Emerging Media
Center
for Emerging Media (CEM) is a non-profit media production company founded in
2000 by veteran Peabody Award-winning radio journalist, educator, and activist Marc Steiner, as a platform to produce
special educational and journalistic media projects. Marc’s daily public
interest talk show The Marc Steiner Show
has been broadcasting over Baltimore’s public radio airwaves since 2003.  In 2008, CEM assumed complete production and fiscal
and fundraising responsibility for The
Marc Steiner Show. 
CEM’s
goals are to use all forms of media to produce high-quality, thought-provoking
programming that informs its listeners on a wide range of topics, airs the
voices of individuals not typically heard in mainstream media, and provides
fair and balanced discussions of important issues.
And CEM
has accomplished a lot over the years! In addition to The Marc Steiner Show, which airs two hours every weekday, we produced
two powerful documentary pieces and have covered many key events in Baltimore
and beyond:


For
the 30th anniversary of the end of the Viet Nam War, our team
traveled to that country to record and produce a 7-hour radio documentary
called Shared Weight, featuring
voices from all sides of that conflict. Shared
Weight has played on public radio stations across the nation.


We
produced the Peabody Award-winning series Just Words, which tells the stories of the working poor in their own voices.


Our Sound Bites series has aired one hour
weekly for the past four years, and features stories, headlines, and panel
discussions on issues of our food system and the environment.


Our This Day in History segments at the beginning
of each Marc Steiner Show have
received wide recognition for their spotlight on history from the perspective
of working people, women, the LGBT community, and people of color.


In
the events in Baltimore following the death of Freddie Gray, CEM staff members have
been in the streets providing local “on the ground” coverage and telling the important stories of real lives and real people, largely missed by the national press.  Producers Mark Gunnery and Stefanie Mavronis produced a compelling 3-part video series, "Voices of the Freddie Gray Protests." 


How Big
of a Risk are We Taking?
While any
new venture is a risk, we have the benefit of over 22 years of success, plus
our deep relationship with the Baltimore community, to sustain us. We believe
it’s worth the risk and that, in fact, this move will enable CEM to become more
independent and self-sustainable. In addition, once the recording studio is up
and running, it has the potential to be income-generating.What the
World Says About CEM and The Marc Steiner
Show:
Katrina van den Heuvel, Publisher, Editor & Part-Owner, The Nation:"I always value how you bring history to bear – unknown, untold, underreported, humane history – on events of the day or just to bring it to people’s attention. Because I think we’re living at a moment where so much of what we listen to and read seems de-contextualized and de-historicized."E. Ethelbert Miller, Award-winning Poet: "The Marc Steiner Show is not just another talk show. It's a place where people go for what I define as heavy-lifting conversations. It's amazing how Marc stays on top of timely issues, new books and trends. His program might as well be called Radio University. What I admire about Marc is his professionalism and amazing grace. A guest on his show always sounds like a neighbor talking across a fence, which is perhaps at the core of what makes the Marc Steiner Show important. Here is a radio program which encourages community. It opens the door and windows to dialogue and civic engagement. Listen to Marc Steiner and you'll understand that democracy requires us to put our shoulder to the wheel. Every show this man records is another victory for freedom and social justice."Joe Ehrmann, Founder of Coach for America & Former Baltimore Colts Defensive Lineman:"Marc you’re my hero. I just love what you do for this community, and I thank you for being such a tremendous change agent. Glad to call you friend." John Nichols in The Nation magazine's 2013 Progressive Honor Roll issue, where The Marc Steiner Show was named "Most Important Radio Show.""No one who has listened to veteran activist
Marc Steiner’s morning show on Morgan State University’s WEAA can figure out
why this guy hasn’t gone national. Yet Steiner is so into his hometown of
Baltimore that it’s hard to imagine him anywhere else. This is what public
affairs radio should be: informed, nuanced, interested in a range of opinions,
yet clear and unequivocal in its passion for democracy and social justice.
Steiner is exceptionally well prepared for every interview, determined to
foster dialogue and so respected that state and national political figures are
frequent guests. What makes his show remarkable, however, is Steiner’s respect
for his listeners. He knows they will engage with discussions about poverty in
Baltimore and poverty in Palestine, about the American Legislative Exchange
Council and the Trans-Pacific Partnership. And the Peabody Award–winning
broadcaster’s 'Day in History' review explores the cultural and political
landscape with thrilling depth and reach.”Zeke Berzoff-Cohen, Co-Founder & Executive Director, The Intersection:
"Marc Steiner is a national treasure and a
regional gem. Marc's award winning journalism brings insight, wisdom and a
great diversity of voices into some of the most important and challenging
conversations of our era. Marc lives out his values on the air and in the
community.  As a board member for my non-profit The Intersection, Marc has
had a transformative impact on the lives
of several of our most at risk several children. We are incredibly
fortunate to have Marc here in Baltimore and I am honored to call him a friend."

story:
Short Summary

Reserva Playa Tortuga (RPT) is a non-governmental, non-profit organization in Costa Rica. RPT aims to contribute to the fields of biological research and science based conservation management as well as fomenting a culture of environmental conservation in the areas influenced by the National Wetlands of the Térraba-Sierpe basin. It is a rather young reserve, launched in 2009, which initially focused on the conservation of endangered marine turtles on its beach, Playa Tortuga. During the past years the reserve has grown and elaborated its activities to include water quality testing, mammals and birds inventories, sustainable fishing promotion and otter research. Although research is of great importance to our reserve, we believe that it is equally important to translate our research findings, implementing them with real world projects within the communities around the Reserve. A synergy of research and conservation education is what we are aiming for.

RPT is currently developing a pilot environmental education program in the 6th Grande de Térraba circuit of the Osa Canton, which includes 18 schools and about 1100 students. The core of the program is to promote, teach and disseminate relevant biological conservation research information and good practices for the sustainable use of natural resources, as a responsibility of the Osa community. The program seeks to educate, activate and empower locals, regarding the environmental rights and responsibilities of the school children. The programs focus is on the level of the students, using a wholistic approach reaches out to include their families and the community at large. Based on the ‘teach the teacher’ concept, we also train the teachers to use the educational materials, concepts and pedagogical techniques, so they can gradually work more and more independently each academic year. To train these teachers we need to hire an environmental educator. Human resources are at this time the key-factor to make this program happen.

By supporting our project, you will be able to educate a whole community in Costa Rica, but at the same time, you will be creating new jobs for the local people.

For more information, please visit our webpage: http://reservaplayatortuga.org/pepaen/

 

Reserva Playa Tortuga (RPT) es una organización no gubernamental sin fines de lucro en Costa Rica. RPT pretende contribuir al campo de la investigación biológica y la gestión de la conservación basada en la ciencia, así como fomentar una cultura de conservación del medio ambiente en las zonas de influencia de los humedales nacionales de la cuenca del Térraba-Sierpe. Aunque la investigación es de gran importancia para nuestra reserva, creemos que es igualmente importante proyectar los resultados de la investigación dentro de las comunidades en torno a la Reserva. Una sinergia de la investigación y la educación para la conservación es lo que pretendemos.

Nuestro programa busca promover, enseñar y difundir la información sobre investigaciones conservación biológica relevante y buenas prácticas para el uso sostenible de los recursos naturales, como una responsabilidad de la comunidad de Osa. El programa busca educar, activar y potenciar a los locales, con respecto a los derechos y las responsabilidades ambientales de los niños en edad escolar. El enfoque de programas está en el nivel de los estudiantes, con un enfoque holístico llega a incluir a sus familias ya la comunidad en general. Basado en el concepto de "enseñar del profesor, también capacitamos a los maestros a utilizar los materiales educativos, los conceptos y las técnicas pedagógicas, por lo que poco a poco podamos trabajar más y más independiente cada año académico. Para formar a estos docentes y educandos tenemos que contratar a un educador ambiental. Los recursos humanos son en este momento la clave de factor para que este programa se haga realidad.

Mediante el apoyo a nuestro proyecto, usted será capaz de educar a toda una comunidad en Costa Rica, pero al mismo tiempo, se está creando de nuevos empleos de trabajo para la población local.

Para obtener más información, por favor visite nuestra página web: http://reservaplayatortuga.org/pepa

 

What We Need & What You Get

To hire a half-time environmental educator for one year in Costa Rica, we need $3500.

If we don’t reach our entire goal, the donated money will be used to hire someone anyway, but we will not be able to hire the educator half-time.

If our entire goal would be exceeded, we will use the extra money to invest in equipment for executing the educational modules, e.g. laptop, binoculars, stereoscope, insect nets… (see section ‘Other ways you can help’)

To thank you for your support, we offer you 4 perks: peace & love, a guided visit in Reserva Playa Tortuga, a 2-day visit at the reserve or a 5-day visit at the reserve.

The Impact

The program aims to promote, train and disseminate the actions for the sustainable use of natural resources and conservation through the development of an environmental education program in the schools of the Grande de Térraba circuit.

Additionally, we will develop educational material and outreach activities at the level of the household and the community, allowing children to express the acquired knowledge with emphasis on the relationship with the ecosystem and daily actions to promote the sustainable use of natural resources.

The impact of this project will be on three levels: 1) the children and teachers of schools of the Grande de Térraba circuit, 2) the households of all children involved, and 3) the involved community of the schools of the Grande de Térraba circuit.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you want to support the educational program by providing us with materials, there is a lot of stuff that we need to implement this program on a broader scale. This is the list of things that we need:

-          Laptop computer

-          Projector

-          Binoculars

-          Entomological kit (tweezers, veils, rule,…)

-          Scales

-          Magnifying glasses

-          Stereoscope

-          Insect nets

-          Costa Rica bird identification guides

-          Waterproof bag

If you are interested in sending us some of the abovementioned materials to get more information about the needed materials, please contact mjimenez@reservaplayatortuga.com

story:
Who Are We?

Georgia grew up on an organic farm in north North Dakota where she learned the value of hard work and the sacredness of life. Their family raises small grain, alfalfa for hay, and beef cattle they sell directly to local customers. She has wanted to work against trafficking and forced prostitution for quite some time, and throughout college had the chance to volunteer with a Minneapolis non-profit, Source MN, who was starting a transitional home for women coming out of that life. For 7 months after graduating college Georgia interned with Source and lived as a mentor in their transitional home model. She's been working toward opening a transitional home and school for young women, especially those under 18, that will be located on her family farm for some time, and college and interning were key steps in the process. She's also stepping into managing the farm and is substitute teaching around the farming schedule. While she's working toward the long term goal, she also wants to do something now to raise awareness and funding.

Jenn is a hiking and adventure guide in the Boundary Waters of northern Minnesota, a nursing assitant, rock climber, and outdoor enthusiast. She brings a host of expertise in camping and survival methods to this trip and a love for adventure. Jenn first realized the link between campers she led in Boundary Waters trips and transitional women coming out of prostitution and trafficking situations when her campers loved nature and didn't want to go back to their inner city lives at the end of the week. After several years of relationships and seeing patterns, she knew that these experiences were a fun relief for kids in bad home situations but she needed to do more to help keep young girls out of prostitution and trafficking. She got involved in Source's community outreach events and at the transitional home where she heard about this awareness bike trip. Being in love with adventure and expert on camping, Jenn saw this as a great way to get involved with awareness while doing what she loves.

We believe that every person, male or female, must be treated with the dignity and respect of being human. Slavery strips that away. With more slaves in the world now than at any other time in history, and the United States having more slaves than any other country, we need to end slavery and rescue women. 1 in 3 women are sexually abused by the time they turn 18, and 98% of women in sexual slavery have been sexually abused before their enslavement. We all know more than 3 women. Likely, we've all had contact with someone in slavery and didn't even know it. We are riding for the 2 million girls and women enslaved today who can't speak out or aren't heard because of the circumstances beyond their control. We believe that if more people were aware of slavery, trafficking, and forced prostitution and the faces these crimes take, that more women would be rescued and rehabilitated for a healthier future.

If only one woman gained freedom from our riding 3100 miles in 2 months, we'd do it, but we believe many more will get the help they so desperately want. Most importantly, we believe that if we proclaim to have faith and know our loving God, we need to give our lives to acting in that faith and by that love. In faith we know we'll finish the trip strong and make a difference. In love for God, enslaved people, and each person we meet we look forward to bringing awareness and love to the folks who support our mission and whose paths we cross on our trip. 

Our route will take us along I-10 from San Diego, CA to Phoenix, AZ, El Paso and Austin, TX, Poplarville and Hattiesburg, MS, Mobile, AL, Pensacola, Tallahassee, and Gainesville, FL and end in St. Augustine, FL. That's over 3000 miles in 7 or 8 weeks.

What We Need & What You Get

We want to raise $5,500 through this campaign for the trip, which benefits the Annex Network, a daughter program of Source MN in Minneapolis. They have a transitional home with three beds in one apartment for transitional women sandwiched between two apartments with mentor volunteers. The volunteers are all young women 20-35 years old who provide mentoring in spiritual, physical, and social care/skills and are like big sisters to transitional women. The program is not only a transitional home. As the Annex Network serves their transitional women, they are also mentoring other groups in starting their own transitional homes. The vision is to have many small homes across the midwest to support life changing growth in a small family setting for women coming out of trafficking and sexual slavery. Funds will be used to have a full time social worker who will serve several homes and expenses associated with mentoring and starting transitional homes such as travel expense, program start up in individual transitional homes, and moving women into their new home and family. This also includes groceries, school supplies for those finishing high school and college, and events such as art nights or camping that center on healing and therapy for women involved. 

From donating, you will know that you have helped free enslaved people and educated hundreds of people about modern underground slavery. You can also receive updates on Source's work by emailing them at sourcemn.org and asking to get on their update list, which includes Annex Network updates. That's on top of the souvenirs you receive from donating. For donating $15, we'll send you a post card from a town we're staying in during our ride and let you know how the day went. If you can donate $30, you'll receive a piece of handmade jewelry donated by someone who supports this cause. It could be a set of beaded earrings, a clay bracelet, or a number of other items. We'll make the selection, but we're sure you'll be happy with your piece! For a $100 donation you can get a clay bracelet hand made by a close friend and co-intern from Source who couldn't ride but wants to do anything else she can. We'll also send you two post cards from different stops on our trip with the adventure of the day. One $1000 donation will receive a signed hostbook from the trip. We'll ask every host we stay with and each host of places we speak along the route to sign the notebook and we'll send it to you when we've finished in March 2014.

Other Ways You Can Help

There are other ways you can help if finances are too tight. If you have experienced prayer working, please pray for us! We strongly believe that when we ask in faith with the right intentions, God answers. Please pray for strength, safety, effectiveness, and being able to love each and every person as much as they should be loved.

You can also help by getting the word out. Share this link on all the social networking sites and let us know if you know someone along the route that would like us to stay with them overnight or speak at their church, school, small group, coffee meeting, business, etc. For a complete route and list of nightly stops, please contact me through the blog and website at http://faithinactionblog.org/.

The vision is to have many small homes across the midwest to support life changing growth in a small family setting for women coming out of trafficking and sexual slavery. Funds will be used to have a full time social worker who will serve several homes and expenses associated with mentoring and starting transitional homes such as travel expense, program start up in individual transitional homes, and moving women into their new home and family. This also includes groceries, school supplies for those finishing high school and college, and events such as art nights or camping that center on healing and therapy for women involved. 
From donating, you will know that you have helped free enslaved people and educated hundreds of people about modern underground slavery. You can also receive updates on Source's work by emailing them at sourcemn.org and asking to get on their update list, which includes Annex Network updates. That's on top of the souvenirs you receive from donating. For donating $15, we'll send you a post card from a town we're staying in during our ride and let you know how the day went. If you can donate $30, you'll receive a piece of handmade jewelry donated by someone who supports this cause. It could be a set of beaded earrings, a clay bracelet, or a number of other items. We'll make the selection, but we're sure you'll be happy with your piece! For a $100 donation you can get a clay bracelet hand made by a close friend and co-intern from Source who couldn't ride but wants to do anything else she can. We'll also send you two post cards from different stops on our trip with the adventure of the day. One $1000 donation will receive a signed hostbook from the trip. We'll ask every host we stay with and each host of places we speak along the route to sign the notebook and we'll send it to you when we've finished in March 2014. 




Other Ways You Can HelpThere are other ways you can help if finances are too tight. If you have experienced prayer working, please pray for us! We strongly believe that when we ask in faith with the right intentions, God answers. Please pray for strength, safety, effectiveness, and being able to love each and every person as much as they should be loved. You can also help by getting the word out. Share this link on all the social networking sites and let us know if you know someone along the route that would like us to stay with them overnight or speak at their church, school, small group, coffee meeting, business, etc. For a complete route and list of nightly stops, please contact me through the blog and website at http://faithinactionblog.org/.

story:
Our Story

New Community Youth Development Corporation (YDC) will start a take away cafe (and later an eat in cafe) at 1516 20th Street West (the former site of our Pleasant Hill bakery). The cafe will achieve a number of community goals in self sustaining fashion.  The cafe will be partially run by our students and will provide instruction in commercial cooking and provide sheltered employment.  The 20th street corridor has rapidly gentrified and the commercial area has rapidly become unaffordable for local residents.  The cafe will offer several daily lunch specials all priced between $4-6/each.  At least one of these will be Diabetic Friendly.

The cafe will be a natural extension of the bakery business that we already operate.  This will allow us limited risk in the start up phase and significantly reduce operational costs. This will significantly increase the opportunity for success from a financial and program point of view.  The facility already has a public health license and has all zoning and approval.

The money through crowdfunding and additional fundraising will allow us to complete the required renovation to have people eat in, purchase equipment necessary for growth, and for promotion and branding.

About Us

YDC is a unique organization.  We are an accredited school, social enterprise, a non-profit, and a sheltered workplace.  This unique combination of attributes allows us to work with and succeed with some of the most highly at risk young people in our society.

At our core, we are a school; we strive to provide an education to those that have no other remaining options.  We are an independent high school, aligned with neither the public or separate school boards. We are small with an anticipated enrollment of just 25-30 students in 2015-2016 ; we are fully accredited and offer a full high school program.  This past year, we had our first graduating class. It is highly unlikely that these students would have ever graduated somewhere else.  We offer students an effective mix of academic subjects, practical subjects and concurrent sheltered employment.  The businesses that we run were generated as a natural expense of our curricular offerings.

Community Learner's High School – Saskatoon's Newest and Most Innovative High School
 
As the old adage goes, teach someone to fish and you feed them for a lifetime. Our school teaches our students skills to live a better life and build better families and communities.  They go to school but also learn cooking, mechanics, screen printing, carpentry and so on.

Community Learner's High School is unique in the province.  It provides provincially accredited academic programs, employment skill training and part time work.  We have operated in Saskatoon for seven years.  We know that our work changes lives!


Cooking up a Better Future, Feeding our Community.
We're going to expand our commercial cooking program to create a sit down community cafe!  Community Learner's High School has operated Nestor's Community Bakery for five years in Saskatoon.  Countless young people have received their first job and a better start in their work/career as a result of Nestor's training program.  In April 2015, CLHS purchased Pleasant Hill Bakery.  The bakery has been converted into a school and a student run cafeteria.  The cafeteria serves an affordable lunch of just $5.00 to anyone. Our cafeteria teaches real skills and helps young people prepare for a better future.  We will expand the cafeteria to include a full restaurant and cafe.  Our students will work with professional chefs and commercial cooking teachers in the restaurant to prepare them for other jobs in the service industry. 

Change is not Cheap. Nor is Equipment and Renovation.
We need your help! Whether it is $2.00 or $500.00.  The money raised in this campaign will allow us to buy equipment, perform necessary renovations, and other necessary changes to allow us to expand our cafe to meet its goals of educating our students and feeding the community.

 

Tell a Friend.  Tell the World!  Help us!
Money isn't everything, but it can change our little piece of the world.  Tell a friend. Share on Facebook or twitter. Take a friend for a coffee and a donut.  Every dollar is just as important because every dollar counts.

What's 20 feet long, covered in icing, and can change the world?  The world's longest donut, of course!  

As part of our campaign, we are making the world's longest donut.  Our record attempt is registered with the Guinness Book of World records.  We will be attempting to make a donut 20 feet long.  You can come see the donut made.  Buy donuts for your office, friends or school.  An exclusive perk is to be an offical chef for the event.  Your name will be forever associated with the Guinness Book of World Records!

Donut Wall of Fame!
For every contribution, we will place a brightly coloured donut cut out with your name in our window.  Help us fill our windows.  Watch us post updates on facebook as the windows fill up.

Impact

  • Increased training position in school- We anticipate that this will create  eight training positions in year one and 12 in years two and three.
  • Increase in the number sheltered work placements -The Cafe will create approximately four part time jobs in year one and six to eight in year two.
  • Increase revenue to support school and other social beneficial activities – Although it is hard to budget at this point, we are hoping that the cafe will over time generate profits that can assist the operation of our school.  We are paid 50% of the provincial funding average per student.  Our students are very need intensive and our program is not inexpensive. Our students,  unlike the students at other private schools, can not afford to pay tuition.  As such, the profits from our social enterprises are key to us being able to offer a quality educational program to our students and meet their diverse needs.

Our Track Record

YDC has and continues to operate a number of significant social enterprises over the years.  These social enterprises have had large impacts in the community.  YDC is a leader in development and the operation of social enterprises.  These include:

Nestor's Bakery: Nestor's Bakery is by far the largest social enterprise  that we run.  It is projected to generate $750,000 this year.  It provides sheltered employment to at-risk youth and education in commercial cooking.

BHP Billiton Small Motors Program:  This program was built on the successful model of our Computers for Kids program.  The general public donates old lawn mowers, snow blowers, etc.  Young people are trained to fix them as part of a school based program.  They are they are able to sell the item when it is finished.

Spilt Ink:  YDC has purchased equipment for a youth run screen printing business.  The program is set to start in the fall of 2015.

Youth Build: YDC ran a successful trades mentoring program for several years.  We did a variety of work for contractors.  Young people shadowed trades people and worked alongside them. The program generated several hundred thousand dollars over its life however it ended because it did not fit within the model set out for the school by the Ministry of Education.

Computers for Kids:  C4K was managed by YDC for the last five years of its operation.  The massive drop in the value of second hand IT products and the rapid rise in the costs of lease/land in Saskatoon made it impossible to continue to run C4K on a large scale.  C4K over its life recycled/repurposed ten of thousands of computers. C4K continues to operate on a strategic level.  We no longer have a stand alone store front.  We continue to refurbish and donate computers and sell computers using external partners to do to most of the work.

Budget Breakdown

Capital Equipment- To grow in scope of the things that we can make in our kitchen, the efficiency and scale of operations we will upgrade ovens and cooking surfaces.  This will require a significant expense to purchase those items, but the accompanying ventilation and air exchange will be even more costly


Budget: $25,000

Marketing – Over the first year, we plan to market the cafe in a variety of ways to ensure that we capture the necessary traffic.  We plan to use print and social media to target our consumer.

Budget: $15,000

Renovation – The building will require some changes to allow people to sit down and eat.  The side and rear of building could accommodate an outdoor patio and seating however significant landscaping and grading would be required first as well as alterations to the access and  fencing at the alley.  The interior of the building already has had two wheel chair accessible washrooms added to have it as applied use changed to A2 ( assemble style occupancy).  However the kitchen is situated at the front and seating at the rear.  This would rear some modification to the building layout and entrance.  Considerable cosmetic work is required as well.  Significant upgrades to the buildings ventilation will be required to increase the type of equipment that could be in the building and the buildings occupancy load.

Budget: $50,000

Great Perks.  Great Cause.  Great Value.
We have cool perks.  Everything from a coffee and donut or muffin, to a house concert, or gourmet authentic Italian meal made by a chef from Italy. Each vote, each dollar, each perk get us a little closer to our goal.

story:
Sarah's Campaign:

 

- - - - - - - - - - - -  UPDATE!!  - - - - - - - - - - - - 

(as of June 2, 2013)

Wow, what a process this has been.  In just 11 days, I have met my goal: to raise 75% of the cost to travel to Toronto this July and study with Michael Stone.  I am overwhelmed by the outpouring of generosity, support, & love from my community of Yogis near & far.

Thank You, my beloved Yoga Family.  

Your gift to me has planted such an inspired seed inside of me.  I am tremendously grateful and motivated to see it grow.

In addition to the monetary contributions you can see on this site, another major donation was made to this fundraising effort by a fellow Yogini, Vikki Ott.  She has very generously donated airline miles to get me to Toronto & back.  Incredible.  Thank you Vikki.

As of today, June 2nd, you can also see some updates in the section below titled "What I Need & What You'll Get".  The budget has been adjusted to reflect costs that are now more finalized, other costs that have surfaced since the initial campaign began, and recognition of Vikki's donation.

Therefore, please note that Any Contributions Made AFTER JUNE 2nd will cover the remaining 25% of the cost of the training.

Lastly, I would love to have a full house for the Sunday, August 18th class I'll be teaching upon my return from training.  Its going to be really special: full of inspired learnings, accompanied by amazing live music in Hale Holistic's beautiful wood-floored 2nd story studio, with a rooftop patio atop which to linger about afterward.  I'm so excited.  So if you still want to contribute, consider purchasing that "VIP Class @ Hale Holistic" Perk!

Update you again soon Yogis.

Much LOVE,

Sarah

 

 

Seeking Teachings - Study with Michael Stone

  • WHO AM I?  My name is Sarah Clark and I am a full time Yoga teacher.  I began teaching 7 years ago, mostly at OM Yoga Center in New York City, and now throughout San Diego, California.  

Teaching a complete Yoga practice to my students & practicing that myself provides me with an unparalleled sense of purpose in this life- not just the challenging beautiful poses (those these are tremendous teachers), but also other aspects of Yoga, from meditation to non-grasping to refined control of my breath.  I am keenly aware of what a privilege it is to make a life's work out of these practices that more intimately connect each of us to ourselves and each other.  I'm looking to further mature my abilities.

  • WHAT AM I SEEKING?  Michael Stone's teachings have always strongly attracted me.  His offerings are exquisitly sophisticated; he is a psychotherapist, yoga teacher, Buddhist teacher, author, activist, husband and father, committed to the integration of traditional teachings with contemporary psychological and philosophical understanding.  I've been learning from him through books and podcasts and video content for years now, but have never had the chance to study with him- until now.

Michael is offering a 5-day intensive at the Centre of Gravity, his space in Toronto, Canada, which is dedicated to the integration of committed formal practice and modern urban life.  I have applied to this rarely offered program and have been accepted.  It is an exceptional opportunity.

(see video of Michael Stone in action: http://youtu.be/GVdGh_uzoQc)

  • WHY IT MATTERS TO ME.  I am not a fly by night Yoga teacher.  I take on this path and my work with tremendous respect and humility.  To me, the full scope of Yoga is a refined, subtle art whose power can greatly affect not only an individual, but the entire ecosystem of surrounding communities, small and large.  I have a deep sense that this intensive study with this brilliant teacher is imperative to my growth as a teacher, that it will accelerate my development so that I might be more impactful, more skilled, STRONGER in my ability to be a force of good in this lifetime. 

 

What I Need & What You'll Get

(updated on 6/2/13)

The cost of the training & travel expenses totals approximately $2,689.  Here's how it breaks down:

Tuition = $604

Room Rental (6 Days) = $410

Airfare = $700 **DONATED in Airline Miles by Vikki Ott!**

Food & Public Transit (6 Days) = $303

Taxes & Fees on Campaign = $502

Passport Renewal = $170

 

**Because the airfare has been donated, the new total cost for my trip = $1,989. 

 

As of JUNE 2nd, this campaign has raised $1,486!

Incredibly, we have already surpassed my intial GOAL, and in doing so, we have raised 75% of the total cost of my training!

THANK YOU to All who Contributed!!  

 

This means that any further contributions will help cover the remaining 25% of the cost of my training.  In return for your donation, please consider accepting one of the following *perks* as a show of my appreciation!

  

 - - - PERKS! - - -

  • VIP Yoga Class upon my return from training, complete with Live Music and Rooftop Refreshments @ Hale Holistic.
  • Private Yoga teaching in your home with Aromatherapy.
  • Yoga Care Package of Lavender & Music, for Yogis outside of San Diego.

  

The End Result

Let me just say it plainly: I have big plans for the impact I hope to make in my Yoga community & beyond, grand ambitions, bold dreams.  

I wish to offer things that I think deeply matter to this brave new world in these strange new times.  This training will help make these ideas a reality. 

 

Other Ways to Help

  • If you would so kindly, spread the word out about this campaign!
  • Use 'share' tools- facebook, email, tweet, & talk to your people.

story:
The Rose International Fund for Children (TRIFC)

“Fostering Hope, Compassion and Opportunity for Individuals with Disability in Nepal”

From Students with Blindness in Nepal:

Help us read books with pictures, maps and diagrams.  Here in Nepal, we people with blindness face many obstacles to having a quality life. Not only do we face discrimination since our blindness is considered a sin from a past life, not only are we limited in our ability to be successful in school due to the lack of school supplies, Braille paper and resource teachers, but the only Braille books available are text only without any tactile pictures.  How can I learn about the world without being able to touch a map?  How can I learn geometry without diagrams that I can feel? How can I learn biology without Braille embossed pictures as examples? How can I keep up with my sighted peers in classes?  We all know that education creates an opportunity for a better life.  NAWB (Nepal Association for the Welfare of the Blind) provides textbooks for us throughout the country of Nepal and they are in need of a Braille embosser/printer to create books with maps, diagrams and photos that we can touch and feel!   Please help us raise the remaining $8,500 needed to purchase the printer to print the books we so desperately need to be successful in our schooling.  With many thanks from all the students with blindness in Nepal.  Namaste! 

What is TRIFC's mission and vision?

The Rose International Fund for Children (TRIFC) is a US Government registered 501(c)3 non-profit organization.  The primary mission of TRIFC is to improve the lives of children in Nepal, particularly those who have a disability.  We raise awareness of these children’s conditions by documenting and publicizing our work.  We raise funds to support qualifying non-profit organizations in Nepal.  Through our projects, we seek to create disability awareness, uplift the lives of people with disabilities and contribute to meaningful long-term social change for generations to come. TRIFC is a non-profit organization that believes in the value of sharing resources with those less fortunate. 

TRIFC is a nonsectarian and nonpartisan organization that provides help solely because the need exists, with no expectation of any benefit coming in return.

What we need:

Thanks to substantial funding from local Rotary Clubs ($12,000), we only need $8,500 of the $20,500 price tag for a Tiger brand Braille Embosser/Printer.  By funding this project we will be providing every single Blind/Visually-Impaired (BVI) student in the ENTIRE country of Nepal with textbooks containing tactile pictures and graphics.

  • Total cost includes shipping costs to Nepal
  • Funding will be wired by TRIFC to the Rotary Club of Kasthamandap in Kathmandu, Nepal
  • Project oversight will be provided by the Rotary Club of Kasthamandap
  • The Braille Embosser/Printer will be operated and maintained by the Nepal Association of the Welfare of the Blind (NAWB). Nepal Association for the Welfare of the Blind (NAWB) established in 1985 is a National level non-profit created for the rehabilitation of the persons with blindness and visual impairment (PBVI). It is non-governmental, non-profit, non-sectarian and non-poilitical organisation (www.nawbnepal.org).
  • TRIFC will provide any remaining funds needed to complete this campaign.

Impact:

  • TRIFC has been providing help, hope and love to children and adults with disabilities in Nepal since 2006
  • We provide children and adults with disabilities with surgeries and prosthetics, nutrional support, school supplies, educational sponsorships and much more!
  • This Braille Embosser project will impact the lives of thousands of BVI students.

Other Ways You Can Help:

You can help spread word about our organization by:

  • Forwarding our website - www.trifc.org to your friends and family
  • Visit our Blog:  www.trifc.blogspot.com
  • Like our Facebook page - www.facebook.com/TRIFC.org 
  • Check out the videos on our YouTube - www.youtube.com/TRIFCdotORG
story_txt:
The Rose International Fund for Children (TRIFC)
“Fostering Hope, Compassion and Opportunity for Individuals with Disability in Nepal”
From Students with Blindness in Nepal:
Help us read books with pictures, maps and diagrams.  Here in Nepal, we people with blindness face many obstacles to having a quality life. Not only do we face discrimination since our blindness is considered a sin from a past life, not only are we limited in our ability to be successful in school due to the lack of school supplies, Braille paper and resource teachers, but the only Braille books available are text only without any tactile pictures.  How can I learn about the world without being able to touch a map?  How can I learn geometry without diagrams that I can feel? How can I learn biology without Braille embossed pictures as examples? How can I keep up with my sighted peers in classes?  We all know that education creates an opportunity for a better life.  NAWB (Nepal Association for the Welfare of the Blind) provides textbooks for us throughout the country of Nepal and they are in need of a Braille embosser/printer to create books with maps, diagrams and photos that we can touch and feel!   Please help us raise the remaining $8,500 needed to purchase the printer to print the books we so desperately need to be successful in our schooling.  With many thanks from all the students with blindness in Nepal.  Namaste! 
What is TRIFC's mission and vision?

TRIFC is a nonsectarian and nonpartisan organization that provides help solely because the need exists, with no expectation of any benefit coming in return.
What we need:


Thanks to substantial funding from local Rotary Clubs ($12,000), we only need $8,500 of the $20,500 price tag for a Tiger brand Braille Embosser/Printer.  By funding this project we will be providing every single Blind/Visually-Impaired (BVI) student in the ENTIRE country of Nepal with textbooks containing tactile pictures and graphics.

Total cost includes shipping costs to Nepal

Project oversight will be provided by the Rotary Club of Kasthamandap
The Braille Embosser/Printer will be operated and maintained by the Nepal Association of the Welfare of the Blind (NAWB). Nepal Association for the Welfare of the Blind (NAWB) established in 1985 is a National level non-profit created for the rehabilitation of the persons with blindness and visual impairment (PBVI). It is non-governmental, non-profit, non-sectarian and non-poilitical organisation (www.nawbnepal.org).
TRIFC will provide any remaining funds needed to complete this campaign.

Impact:



TRIFC has been providing help, hope and love to children and adults with disabilities in Nepal since 2006
We provide children and adults with disabilities with surgeries and prosthetics, nutrional support, school supplies, educational sponsorships and much more!
This Braille Embosser project will impact the lives of thousands of BVI students.

Forwarding our website - www.trifc.org to your friends and family

story:
O KINTARI PROJEKTU (In English please read below)

------------------------------------------------------------------

Společně s Vámi můžeme dát chudým studentům z Indonésie šanci na lepší budoucnost.

          Dewi Sartika je jednou z prvních dívek z chudé části ostrova Lombok, která se dostala na univerzitu. Student Karte pochází z tak chudých poměrů, že studium na střední škole si může dovolit jen díky podpoře ze strany Kintari. Učitel Mohamad Suhaidi pomáhá s výukou dětí v základní škole Ngolang, kterou Kintari podporuje od roku 2006, aktivně pomáhá při realizaci všech rozvojových projektů Kintari a je prostředníkem mezi místními a dobrovolníky z Kintari, kteří odlétají na Lombok celoročně vyučovat anglický jazyk a obecné vzdělání.

            Intenzivní kurz angličtiny v Čechách, kde obdrží mezinárodní certifikát, včetně kulturně vzdělávacího programu, který pro ně Kintari připravilo, jim pomůže v jejich budoucím studiu a práci. Tito tři mladí lidé patří mezi nejchudší obyvatele jižního Lomboku, přesto se vymykají svojí chutí se vzdělávat a mnohaletým snažením a ochotou pomáhat druhým a být jim vzorem. Proto byli vybráni, aby se účastnili tohoto programu, kdy po návratu budou napomáhat k rozšíření vzdělanosti v této oblasti Indonésie a budou vzorem dalším studentům.

I malé přispění z Vaší strany může znamenat velkou pomoc

pro realizaci tohoto projektu potřebujeme Vaši pomoc. Vaše příspěvky přispějí na pokrytí:
 
1) Zpátečních letenek z Indonésie.
2) Cestovní pojištění.
3) Poplatky spojené s vyřízením cestovních dokladů, oficiálního pozvání aj.
4) Ubytování, strava a transport po celou dobu jejich pobytu v Evropě.
5) Jazykový intenzivní kurz angličtiny s mezinárodním certifikátem.
 

O Kintari foundation

Kintari foundation již od roku 2006 aktivně přispívá k rozvoji vzdělanosti na ostrově Lombok. V Čechách sdružení prezentuje indonéskou kulturu a umění formou přednášek, tanečních vystoupení, výstav a workshopů, čímž získává potřebné finance na realizaci rozvojových projektů v chudé oblasti ostrova Lombok.

Na Lomboku v minulých letech Kintari zrekonstruovalo kompletně základní školu v Ngolangu, kde navíc vystavělo umývárny, toalety a studnu, a dále zde postavilo školku, v níž zaměstnává tři místní učitele. Školu i školku nejenže podporuje výukovými materiály, školními potřebami, ale také sem vysílá celoročně dobrovolníky v rámci svého help campu, kteří zde vyučují angličtinu, zeměpis a malování.

 

Všechny peníze, které přesáhnou požadovanou částku na tento projekt budou v plné výši použity pro potřeby školy a školky Kintari na Lomboku.

 ------------------------------------------------

ABOUT THE PROJECT IN ENGLISH

-----------------------------------------------------------------

Together with your help we can give a chance to poor Indonesian students for a better life.

Dewi Sartika is one of the first girls from the impoverished part of the island to be accepted to a university. Karte, the high school student, comes from such a poor background that he can afford his high school studies only thanks to Kintari financial support. Mohamad Suhaidi, the elementary teacher, helps to educate children at Ngolang elementary school, which Kintari have been supporting since 2006, and actively helps with realization of  all Kintari’s developmental projects. He also functions as the mediator between the locals and Kintari volunteers who come to Lombok throughout the whole year to teach English and general education.

An intensive English language course in Czech Republic including an international certificate along with the culture educational programme will help those three young people not only with their studies but also with building their careers. Despite the fact that they count among the poorest inhabitants of Lombok these three young people show an outstanding motivation and long-standing efforts to educate themselves, help and serve others as an example. For these reasons they have been chosen to participate in this programme so that after their return they can help to spread the education in this particular part of Indonesia and set a good example to others.

Even a small contribution can be a big help

For realization of this project we are looking for your kind help. Your contribution will help to cover:
 
1) Air tickets from Indonesia to Europe and back.
2) Travel insurance.
3) Visa fee.
4) Accomodation, food and transportation throughout their stay in Europe.
5) Language intensive course including international certificate.

About Kintari foundation

Since 2006 Kintari foundation has been actively contributing to the progress in education on the Lombok Island. In the Czech Republic Kintari presents Indonesian culture and art through organizing various lectures, dance performances, workshops and exhibitions by which we are able to obtain the finances needed for the realization of the developmental projects in the impoverished part of the Lombok Island.

            In the past years Kintari has completely rebuilt the Ngolang elementary school on Lombok. Moreover Kintari have built a washroom, a well, and toilets as well as an adjacent kindergarden where three local teachers are employed. Not only are both the school and the kindergarden given educational materials but Kintari also send volunteers, participants of Kintari help camp, who come there throughout the whole year to teach English, geography and  painting.

All money over our goal we will use for Kintari school and kindergarden in Lombok.

story:
Short Summary

Our names are Spencer, Hayley, Brendan, and Elizabeth. We are a group of college students at Baldwin-Wallace University in Berea, Ohio. This idea started as a project idea we came up with during a class we all attended, but grew into much more. The class we took was based around researching a global problem that we felt had the most impact on us individually. We found ourselves equally disturbed at increasing rates of human trafficking instances in our world. As we researched and learned more, we found human trafficking was more impactful, and problematic than any of us had ever anticipated. One goal of the class was to find a solution to human trafficking. After weeks of thought and problem-solving, we realized that stopping human trafficking was something we could never accomplish on our own, but decided we would try to do anything we could. We looked over many non-profit organizations who do their best to prevent human trafficking, and found the Nomi Network was one of the best in the world. Their main goal is to create economic oppuritunities for women that are at risk of sex trafficking. The Nomi Network opens businesses that make clothing and other apparrel and those employed are the people at risk of sex trafficking. They have businesses/factories in several countries such as Cambodia and the United States. Their profits go towards proper salary for workers, programs for those who work there, and the opening more factories around the world. As the funds go directly to the Nomi Network, your money will go directly to keeping those at risk of human trafficking out of harms way. Your donations can change the lives of so many, and help transform the world into a better place. 

What We Need & What You Get

 Although it might seem our small goal of 500 dollars will not have a large impact, every dollar counts and does more than you think. As we talked to the Nomi Network more, we found that they are trying to open a new factory in India. And even the smallest amounts of money can help create this new business, and help stop human trafficking in india. This money will go to buying new equipment for the factory such as machines, work benches, and building materials. It will aslo go towards paying the salaries of the workers in this factory. Every little bit we earn, even if we dont meet our goal, helps prevent human trafficking in all of the areas they have factories to help those at risk. The more money we can earn, the larger impact we can have and the greater chance we have at stopping human trafficking.

The Impact

Even the smallest amount of money can have a giant impact on those at risk of human trafficking. No donation is ever too small! Those who are employed by the Nomi Network are kept out of risk by having a safe and secure job at one of the many clothing factories they have around the world.

HOW YOUR MONEY HELPS:

1) $120 buys a machine for the factory

2) $1,000 provides a job for an entire year

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Don't worry if you cant donate either! Spreading the word to your friends and family is just as helpful as donating! Send it to anyone who you think can help! Hopefully we can make a change in the world one step at a time!

story:
My name is Morgan Celik. I am the advisor of the Chicagoland MUN Club and I want to raise money for their scholarship. CMC is a small non-profit organization that provides students with the oppurtunity to learn more about negotiations, diplomacy, and International Relations, while building life-long friendships.

 

Our campaign is to raise money for a scholarship that will be awarded to our most deserving student. When Elena goes off to college we will all miss her very much. She has brought to this club laughter, dedication, and an incredibly strong sense of ethics. Please help us give her something in return.

 

Also, we can provide funders with tax deductible receipts for the scholarship.
